PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The proposed cuts in funding to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme will have serious effects on the viability of many family chemists, leading to increased charges and reduction in services and availability of medicines to the community.
We therefore call on the Federal Government to reject the findings of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal and maintain the level of funding existing prior to the Tribunal's findings.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

This humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully draws the attention of the Senate to the Government's attack on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, which has severely affected the viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide the quality and quantity of services to which we as Australians have a right.

Your petitioners respectfully request the Senate to urge the Government to guarantee an adequately funded Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, so as to ensure the continued viability of neighbourhood pharmaceutical services through our local community pharmacies.

PETITION.TITLE: Privacy Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
The Hawke Labor Government's Privacy Amendment Bill concerning credit reference reporting will-

(1) Prohibit many legitimate uses of credit information by organisations such as insurance companies, real estate agents, businesses selling goods on credit, and companies renting or leasing goods and equipment.
(2) Add to the cost of business and increase interest rates and insurance charges and lead to over commitment by borrowers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
Reject Labor Government's Privacy Amendment Bill to enable businesses to have access to credit information they require to make sensible commercial decisions.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Home Ownership
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Recent huge rises in mortgage interest rates have pushed the cost of buying their own home beyond the reach of most Australian families.

Those Australians already paying off home mortgages are now suffering severely and unfairly through increased mortgage payments or longer repayment times so that many will never pay off their mortgage and go further and further into debt unless interest rates fall substantially.

Now, therefore, your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled require the Hawke-Keating Government to cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon and instead to use other measures which would allow interest rates to return to levels that do not force most Australian home-seekers out of the housing market-and many Australians out of their homes-so that the traditional right of home ownership is returned to average Australian families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned, having great concern that Canberra is now the ``Porn Capital'' of Australia and because of the spread of moral pollution in our nation, call upon the Federal Government to introduce immediate legislation in support of existing State legislation:

1. To provide strict controls over the importation, production, sale, hire or mailing of video-cassettes particularly in the Australian Capital Territory, with the open sale and/or hire of only ``G'', ``PG'' and ``M''-rated video cassettes; and the total prohibition of the sale or hire of ``R''-rated video-cassettes, so that ``R''-rated films can only be viewed in an adult theatre by persons over 18 years. We totally reject the concept of ``X''-rated or ``NVE''-rated video-cassettes, which would allow the legal sale and hire of hard-core pornographic videos for viewing in the homes of our nation, which would endanger our children; and
2. To give whole-hearted support to Senator Walters' Private Member's Bill to implement the recommendations of the Select Committee on Videos; and

3. To dramatically improve the Federal Attorney-General's Guidelines for Classification of video tapes/discs, which restrict the importation, production, sale or hire, screening in private homes and especially mailing by Australia Post, so as to include the total prohibition of any pornographic, obscene or blasphemous video-cassette, or film which exploits or degrades women as sex objects, or which contain child pornography, bestiality, sodomy, group sex or violent sex acts with women, such as rape and pack rape, sadism and torture, etc., or which promotes homosexuality or lesbianism.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will protect our society, especially women and children from moral pollution and its harmful effects.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated and Violent Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:
The petition of citizens of Australia points out:

that all State Governments, States Attorneys-General, most women's groups and the majority of men in Australia, including significant numbers of members of Parliament, are totally opposed to the importation and distribution of `X' and excessively violent `R'-rated video pornography in Australia;
that most `X'-rated material available in Australia is imported;

that the Federal Government, by its Customs power under the Constitution, and not the Australian Capital Territory Government, is solely responsible for controlling the importation of this pornographic material;
that by continuing to allow the importation of such pornographic material, the Federal Government is neglecting its responsibility to the women, children and families of Australia.
Your petitioners, therefore, request the Senate to:
1. Ban `X'-rated pornographic material at the point of entry into Australia.
2. Exclude from the `R'-rated all gratuitously violent material.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care for the Elderly
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Australia's population is ageing and most people require more health services as they grow older.
If open not-for-profit health funds are to be able to meet the costs of providing benefits to their older members at affordable rates, they need to share these costs equitably.
Some health insurance organisations are being allowed to avoid meeting the health costs of sick and elderly people.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
take the necessary action to reverse rising cost trends and provide positive incentives to encourage all health funds to share the cost of health care for sick and elderly Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tax Incentives, Solar Heating Equipment
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that there is widespread community concern regarding:
1. the almost total dependence in Australia on fossil, fuel and their deleterious effects in producing the greenhouse phenomenon in the environment;
2. the proposal to spend millions of dollars on research into nuclear power, the production of which has in other countries proven expensive and dangerous; and
3. the lack of adequate funding for research into, and promotion of alternative renewable sources of energy, in particular, solar power.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
1. fund adequate research into production of large scale solar energy for industry; and
2. encourage the use of known technology for hot water and space heating by tax incentives on solar heating equipment for houses and commercial buildings.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that there is widespread concern by farmers and consumers about the proposal to irradiate food in Australia.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
(1) block the introduction of food irradiation into Australia;
(2) ban the import of Cobalt-60 and Cesium-137 and Cesium-134 to be used to irradiate food products;
(3) ban the import of all machinery used for food irradiation (electron beam, X-ray etc.);
(4) ban the importation and sale of irradiated food in Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Company Tax Collection Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Government's Budget decision to change the company tax collection system will be a crippling blow to many small businesses, already suffering as a direct result of the Hawke Labor Government's high interest rate policy.
The earlier remittance of company tax payments to the Government will substantially reduce the cash-flow position of thousands of small businesses.

Many small businesses will be driven under as a result of the Government's decision-unable to find funds for both tax commitments and new stock, only able to borrow at record high interest rates and unable to claim any tax relief on such borrowings to meet their tax commitment.
The Government's proposed changes to the company tax collection system has only been introduced as a greedy grab for more tax revenue.

The small business community would prefer the Government to completely abandon the proposal rather than make only minor alterations to the original Budget decision, which are not likely to alleviate the situation to any significant extent.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Deregulation of Television Content
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal continues to regulate Australian content on television;
that it increases the quota of first release prime-time drama to 365 hours a year per station, over the next three years;
that it ensures the TV networks provide Australians with a variety of Australian television drama including serials, series and plays;
that it increases the quota of children's programmes;
that it encourages regional TV production.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the honourable members will oppose any deregulation of television content.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Notice of Intention to Withdraw Notices of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice of intention to withdraw notices of motion on behalf of Senator Collins, Chairman of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. Pursuant to standing order 109a I give notice that, at the giving of notices on the next day of sitting, I shall withdraw Business of the Senate, Notices of Motion Nos 1 and 2 standing in Senator Collins's name, for three sitting days hence, for the disallowance of Lotteries Ordinance 1989, as contained in the Territory of Christmas Island Ordinance No. 4 of 1989 and made under the Christmas Island Act 1958 and the Determination of Australian Design Rules as National Standards Order, as contained in Determination of Motor Vehicle Standards-Order No. 1 of 1989 and made under section 7 of the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989. Mr President, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a brief description of the Committee's scrutiny and its correspondence, for the information of honourable senators and others.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
Lotteries Ordinance 1989, as contained in Territory of Christmas Island Ordinance No. 4 of 1989

The Ordinance legalises approved public lotteries and approved betting schemes and provides for their control. The Committee was concerned, however, at some aspects of the operation of the general scheme of supervision as provided in the instrument.

The core provision of the Ordinance is that the Minister may grant or refuse approval of lotteries and betting schemes and impose conditions or requirements on such approval. There are no detailed criteria to guide the exercise of this discretion, although there are some broad guidelines. More importantly, however, there is no right of review of a decision of the Minister. The Ordinance seems to contemplate approvals of lotteries and betting schemes operated for charitable or recreational purposes by sporting or social clubs, although the Explanatory Statement gives no indication of this.
In such situations, where there is a multiplicity of applications, approvals and conditions, a right of review of the merits of a decision will often be appropriate.
The Committee looked particularly closely at these present provisions as there is express provision for the Minister to delegate this discretion, apparently to any person at all.
Where the Minister is empowered to delegate decision making power to a public official or even, as here, to any person, then the Committee believes the case for independent review is stronger.

The Committee noted with approval ``reasonability'' requirements in provisions which require the production of documents to an authorised person. There is, however, one provision which empowers an authorised person to demand information and to require the answer to questions, with only the subjective proviso that the information is considered necessary for an audit. Failure to comply is an offence punishable by fine or imprisonment. In such cases the Committee believes the objective expression ``reasonably considers necessary'' is preferable.

Similarly, a provision which deals with directions for the conduct of a lottery includes some ``reasonability'' requirements but in one case provides the subjective ``considers necessary'' rather than the objective ``reasonably considers necessary''. Contravention of a direction is punishable by fine or imprisonment.

Finally, an authorised person, who apparently need not even be a public official, is authorised to enter any place where a lottery is to be drawn, with no restriction on this power of entry by reference to a warrant or to a time of day or night when entry may be effected.

The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, the Hon Clyde Holding MP, agreed to amend the Ordinance to meet the concerns of the Committee. The Committee is grateful to the Minister for this co-operation.
16 October 1989
The Hon Clyde Holding, MP
Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister,

I refer to the Lotteries Ordinance 1989, Territory of Christmas Island Ordinance No 4 of 1989, considered by the Committee at its Meeting of 5 October 1989. The Committee was concerned with several aspects of the Ordinance.

Section 4 of the Ordinance provides that the Minister may grant or refuse approval of lotteries and betting schemes subject to any conditions or requirements. The Ordinance does not appear to provide any detailed criteria for the exercise of this power, nor does there seem to be a right of review of the Minister's actions. In addition, there is provision in section 19 for the Minister to delegate this power, apparently to any person. The Committee notes that permission to operate a lottery may be of considerable commercial value.

Section 12 provides for the production of documents to an auditor. These provisions include some ``reasonability'' requirements but under s. 12 (3) a person may be required to produce any information in that person's possession or to which that person has access ``that the authorised person considers necessary for the purposes of the audit''. The Committee believes that such provisions should be ``reasonably necessary''.

Section 17 similarly includes some ``reasonability'' requirements and the Committee asks whether the provision for directions given under s. 17 (2) (b) could not be amended to limit these to ``reasonable directions''.

Section 17 (2) (a) provides that ``A person authorised to supervise the conduct of a lottery may . . . enter any place in which the lottery is being, or is to be, drawn''. There appears to be no restriction on this power of entry. There is, for example, no requirement that entry be on the basis of a warrant, or any limitation on the time of day or night when entry may be effected or any requirement for reasonable entry.

The above are important concerns and the Committee awaits your advice. On a somewhat lighter note the Committee noted the definition of ``unlawful game'' in section 2. While all Members are aware of the game of ``two-up'' from its importance in Australian history and while some Members admit to having heard of ``dominoes'', ``gin-rummy'' and ``poker'', there is some difficulty with ``belankes'', ``chap jee ku'', ``fan-tan'', ``pakapoo'', ``punto banco'', ``swy'', ``thimble rig'', ``two pairs'' and ``unders and overs''. The Committee would welcome your advice that these games do not require further definition.
Yours sincerely,
Bob Collins
Chairman
15 November 1989
The Secretary
Senate Standing Committee on
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Collins
I refer to your letter dated 16 October 1989 concerning the Lotteries Ordinance 1989 of Christmas Island.
I propose to address each of the points the Committee raised.
Section 4

Under this section the Minister is empowered to grant or refuse approval for the application to conduct a lottery or pool betting scheme on Christmas Island and to impose any condition or requirement having regard to the need for it to be conducted fairly and for the interests of the subscribers to be protected.
The Committee commented on:
(i) the absence of detailed criteria for the exercise of this power.
(ii) the absence of a provision for right of review of the Minister's actions.
(iii) the propriety of the delegation of the Minister's power apparently to any person (section 19).

I undertake to amend section 4 to provide for the right of review of the Minister's action as desired by the Committee, preferably using section 112 of the Casino Control Ordinance No. 4, 1988 of the Christmas Island as a model and to incorporate a provision for detailed criteria for the exercise of the Minister's power under section 4.

I also undertake to amend the delegation provision (section 19) to limit the persons to whom the Minister may delegate his or her powers to the Administrator, the Official Secretary or to an SES officer of the Department. I also undertake to amend the delegation provision to limit the persons to whom the Administrator may delegate his or her powers to the Official Secretary or to an SES officer of the Department.
Section 12

This section deals with the production of a statement and documents in relation to the conduct of a lottery for the purposes of an audit. I agree to amend subsection 12 (3) of the Ordinance so that the authorised person may require information that he/she considers reasonably necessary for the purposes of the audit.
Section 17

This provision empowers the person authorised by the Administrator to supervise the conduct of a lottery to enter any place in which the lottery is being, or is to be, drawn and to give such directions as he/she considers desirable.
The Committee commented that:

(i) there appears to be no restriction on this power of entry. There is, for example, no requirement that entry be on the basis of a warrant, or any limitation on the time of day or night when entry may be effected or any requirement for reasonable entry.
(ii) paragraph 17 (2) (b) could be amended to limit the directions to be given by the person authorised to supervise the draw to such directions as are reasonable.

The purpose of paragraph 17 (2) (a) is to allow an authorised person to enter a place in which the lottery is being, or is to be, drawn to ensure that the lottery is conducted fairly. To meet the Committee's concerns, I undertake to amend paragraph 17 (2) (a) so that the authorised person's entry must be reasonable.
I also accept the Committee's comments in relation to paragraph 17 (2) (b) and undertake to amend that provision to insert ``reasonable'' before ``directions''.
Section 2
This section contains definitions used in the Ordinance, including the definition of ``unlawful game''.

The Committee sought my advice that some of the games referred to in the definition of ``unlawful game'' (for example ``belankes'', ``chap jee ku'', ``fan-tan'', ``pakapoo'', ``punto banco'', ``swy'', ``thimble rig'', ``two pairs'' and ``unders and overs'') do not require further definition. I am advised that these games do not require further definition and that these terms are well understood in the Territory.
I thank the Committee for its comments.
Yours sincerely
(Clyde Holding)
Determination of Australian Design Rules as National Standards Order, as contained in Determination of Motor Vehicle Standards-Order No. 1 of 1989

This Order was made under the National Standards Act 1989, which was intended to establish national uniform safety and environmental standards applying to the design and construction of all road vehicles, including trailers, supplied to the market for the first time, whether manufactured in Australia, imported new vehicles or imported secondhand vehicles.

The parent Act and Regulations made under its authority provide for monitoring all suppliers to the Australian market to ensure that vehicles not only conform, but continue to conform, with the applicable national standards.

From their comprehensive application and effect it is obvious that the standards are of great importance to the entire motor industry and have major commercial implications. The Order sets the Standards not by direct legislation but rather by incorporating material from a publication entitled ``Australian Design Rules for Motor Vehicles and Trailers-3rd Edition'', issued by the Department of Transport and Communications as at 31 July 1989. The Order itself is two pages long but the incorporated material is some 2,900 pages long. It is stressed that these 2,900 pages are included not merely as an external guide or reference but actually are the standards themselves, with provision for numbering and citation. This lengthy material is, of course, Commonwealth legislation with a general effect no less than an Act or regulations.

The Committee emphasises that it has no difficulty with length as such. In the present standards, for example, much of the material is technical in nature and it is unlikely that the Senate would wish to debate such provisions as part of a Bill. Nevertheless, the Committee was concerned at a discretion granted to the Minister by the Order to deem a vehicle or component to comply with the national standard even though the vehicle or component meets a requirement by means other than those included in the standard. This discretion confers a power on the Minister to nullify the standards themselves as far as they specify the means of complying with a requirement.

There are no criteria to guide or limit the exercise of this power and to that extent the power is unfettered. There are no requirements for tabling or disallowance or of any other form of publicity, scrutiny or control of any decisions of the Minister in regard to the power. There is no provision for any right of review of the merits of an adverse decision taken by the Minister. Any decision of the Minister pursuant to this power could have serious consequences for an individual manufacturer or even for the motor trade generally. The Committee had noted earlier that the parent Act provided wide review powers to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Similarly, during the Committee's scrutiny of the Regulations made under the Act the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support, the Hon. Bob Brown MP, undertook to provide that discretions exercised under the Regulations are also subject to AAT review. In the present instance the Committee wished to see that the same safeguards that existed in respect of the Act and Regulations were extended to the Orders. The Committee believes that safeguards in delegated legislation should not be less than those included in the parent Act.
The Minister agreed to amend the Orders to provide that the discretion of concern to the Committee should be subject to AAT review. The Committee thanks the Minister for this co-operation.
27 October 1989
The Hon Bob Brown MP
Minister for Land Transport and
Shipping Support
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister,

I refer to the Determination of Australian Design Rules as National Standards Order, Determination of Motor Vehicles Standards-Order No. 1 of 1989, made under section 7 of the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989. The Committee considered the Order at its Meeting of 26 October 1989.

The Committee noted that the order effectively incorporated the ``Australian Design Rules for Motor Vehicles and Trailers-3rd Edition'', issued by the Department of Transport and Communications as at 31 July 1989. This publication consists of some 2,900 pages of standards. The Committee has no difficulty as such with the length of these standards, as it is not concerned with the policy of an instrument. Indeed, the highly technical nature of some of the standards are examples of an appropriate use of delegated legislation. Members of the Committee agreed that Parliament may not wish to debate that the wheels of a vehicle with a Nominal Tyre Size of 1400 X 20 should revolve 265 times per kilometre while wheels with a Nominal Tyre Size of 1400 X 24 should revolve 225 times per kilometre (ADR44/000 page 5).
The Committee is, however, concerned at a provision of the short (two page) instrument itself. Paragraph 5 determined that:
``(1) where a national standard imposes a requirement for the performance of a vehicle or component, and
(2) a particular vehicle or component meets that requirement but does so by a means other than that specified in the national standard,
the vehicle or component may be deemed by the Minister to comply with the national standard''.

This provision confers an important discretion on the Minister. There are no criteria for its exercise and there appears on its face to be no external right of review of an adverse exercise of the discretion. The Committee notes the wide review provisions to the AAT in s. 39 of the parent Motor Vehicles Standards Act 1989 and asks whether these cover a paragraph 5 decision. If it does not the Committee would appreciate your comments on the suitability of a right of review to the AAT in relation to adverse decisions on these matters, which could have important commercial and livelihood implications. In this context the Committee notes that the standards apply to all road vehicles, including trailers, supplied to the market for the first time, whether manufactured in Australia, imported new or imported second hand.
Your advice would be appreciated.
Yours sincerely,
Bob Collins
Chairman
15 November 1989
Senator Bob Collins
Chairman, Senator Standing Committee on
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Collins,

Thank you for your letter of 27 October 1989 relating to the concerns of your Committee about certain aspects of Order No. 1 under the Motor Vehicle Standards Act. Specifically, you questioned whether or not the decisions under paragraph 5 of the order should be subject to external review.

As indicated in my letter of 26 October 1989, it has been my intention to provide that decisions taken under the Act were appellable. An amendment to the Act has recently been submitted to the Parliament within the portfolio Omnibus Bill, which seeks to achieve this aim.

I note your specific concern about paragraph 5 of the Order, and I shall also undertake to amend the Order to make any decisions under this provision appellable in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
Yours sincerely,
Bob Brown

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON THE ETHICAL BEHAVIOUR OF MEMBERS OF PARLIAMENT

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Macklin) put:
(1) That a joint select committee be appointed, to be known as the Joint Select Committee on the Ethical Behaviour of Members of Parliament.
(2) That the Committee:
(a) inquire into and report upon the ethical standards of behaviour to which Members of Parliament should conform;
(b) draw up and publish a code of ethics to be considered for adoption by each house of the Parliament; and

(c) on adoption by a House of a code of ethics, report to that House, on the first sitting day of that House that is not more than 12 months after the date of adoption of the code by that House, and thereafter not less frequently than every 12 months, on:
(i) the general operation of the code of ethics, and
(ii) whether any changes should be made to the code, and, if so, what those changes should be and why they are needed.
(3) That the Committee consist of 10 members, as follows:
(a) 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b) 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate;
(c) 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats;
(d) 3 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by or on behalf of the Prime Minister; and
(e) 2 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition.
(4) That the Committee may proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.

(5) That if, within 5 sitting days of the House of Representatives after transmission of this resolution to the House, the House of Representatives has not concurred in this resolution, or no members of the House of Representatives have been appointed to the Committee, then the Committee operate as a select committee of the Senate with a quorum of 3, and this resolution be read accordingly.
(6) That the Committee elect as Chairman one of the members nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate or the Prime Minister.

(7) That the Chairman of the Committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the Committee, being a non-government member from the other House, to be the Deputy-Chairman of the Committee, and that the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(8) That, in the event of the votes on any question before the Committee being equally divided, the Chairman, or the Deputy-Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(9) That the quorum of the Committee be 5 members.

(10) That the Committee, and any sub-committee, have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, and the Committee have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations as it may deem fit.

(11) That the Committee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of 3 or more of its members, and to refer to any such sub-committee any of the matters which the Committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a sub-committee be all the members appointed to the sub-committee.

(12) That the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the Committee with the approval of the President.
(13) That the Committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.

(14) That the Committee report to each House of Parliament on or before the first day of sitting of that House in April 1990 on the matters referred to in subparagraphs (2) (a) and (b) of this resolution.
(15) That, subject to paragraph (5), the Committee cease upon the dissolution or expiration of the House of Representatives.
(16) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.
(17) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution be communicated by Message to the House of Representatives with a request for the concurrence of that House in the resolution.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN HERITAGE COMMISSION (NATIONAL ESTATE PROTECTION) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Dunn) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act relating to the protection of the national estate of Australia.
Motion (by Senator Dunn) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.
SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 to give effective protection to places listed in the Register of the National Estate. The Bill seeks to achieve this by making it possible to regulate to control actions by corporations that might adversely affect the National Estate.
Preamble

At present the Australian Heritage Commission Act, which has the long title `An Act to establish an Australian Heritage Commission', primarily concerns the identification and registration of National Estate areas and property by the Australian Heritage Commission. Most of the Act concerns the establishment, meetings, officers and finances of the Commission. Of the eight parts of the Act only one (Part V) deals with the actual protection of the National Estate and this Part presently only obliges Federal Ministers to apply existing relevant laws to restrain the Commonwealth and Commonwealth authorities from adversely affecting the National Estate unless he or she is satisfied that there is ``no feasible and prudent alternative''.

These provisions in the 1975 Act are not without value and I have left them unaltered in this Bill. However, it is abundantly clear that there is a need for legislation which allows specific prohibition of damaging activities by bodies other than the Commonwealth and Commonwealth authorities and with appropriate penalties to encourage compliance. As long ago as 1974 the Hope Committee of Inquiry into the National Estate, while recommending the establishment of the Commission and the basic structure of the present Act, commented in some detail upon the wide Constitutional powers available to the Commonwealth. The Committee noted that powers such as the external affairs powers, the power relating to people of a particular race, and the trade and commerce power could be used to protect National Estate areas within the States which were not owned by the Commonwealth.

And in the 1983 High Court decision on the Tasmanian Dams case, a majority of the judges held that the Commonwealth has the power to make a law regulating actions carried out for the purposes of the trading activities of trading corporations; for instance, logging to make woodchips.

More recently, Government Ministers have alluded to the powers latent in the Constitution and have threatened to apply them to specific disputes concerning National Estate areas. On the 25th of July, Senator Richardson, the Minister for the Environment, threatened to use the corporations power to over-ride the NSW Government if they broke an agreement-negotiated by Resources Minister Senator Cook-to abide by the recommendations of a Biological Resources Survey into the impact of logging on National Estate areas in the South East Forests of NSW.

Senator Richardson also threatened to use Constitutional powers to protect the rainforests in Northern Queensland. He said that the exercise of these powers would cause disquiet in the states-including Labor governed states-but that his Government had the courage to do it if necessary. He also claimed that his sudden awareness of the effectiveness of Constitutional powers to conserve the environment was the result of new legal advice supplanting a prior opinion that these powers would be ineffective. It is hard to believe that Ministers of the Crown are so ill-advised; it is hard not to believe that it is the ``courage'' to take responsibility for protecting Australia's national assets that has been lacking.

Strong words have been the only evidence of courage so far. In a speech at an ALP dinner on the 22nd of August the Prime Minister said, referring to the NSW Government, ``If the State Government doesn't co-operate fully in the biological studies and in a full examination of alternatives to logging the South East National Estate Forests, my Government will bring down the full weight of its constitutional powers-including the corporations power-to achieve a solution''.

The Federal Government has had ample opportunity to consider legislating on the basis of Constitutional powers to protect the environment. In a letter to the Prime Minister before the July ``Statement on the Environment'' Mr Phillip Toyne, Director of the Australian Conservation Foundation, made explicit mention of the potential of the Constitution's corporations power. The ``Statement on the Environment'' would have been considerably enhanced if the Government had included a statement of intention to legislate on this basis to protect areas acknowledged to be of special value and significance.

Since our Government has not done this, I offer the instrument embodied in this Bill to its reluctant hands. There is no obligation in the amendments proposed by this Bill to exercise the powers it expresses, but it will realise these powers so that when needed they can readily be applied through regulation. We will no longer have to listen to Government Ministers speaking about nebulous Constitutional powers. Brave words will be replaced by responsible action.

This Bill will not affect the general operation of the Australian Heritage Commission. It introduces a two-tiered approach to the National Estate which leaves the functions of the Commission intact while giving powers to the Commonwealth to regulate the actions of corporations within National Estate areas. The Commission will continue to keep a Register of the National Estate and comply with existing requirements for public notification of proposed listings and removal of listings in the Register.

The interaction of the Australian Heritage Commission Act with the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 is maintained. The Bill does not affect s. 44 of the Australian Heritage Commission Act which presently allows the Minister administering the Impact of Proposals Act to direct inquiries into ``matters relating to the national estate'' and also empowers the Commission to request that Minister to direct the holding of such an inquiry.
Outline of the Bill

This Bill is concerned with protection of the National Estate. It amends the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 to achieve this aim. The fundamental change proposed in the Bill is the insertion of provisions which will allow the regulation of the activities of corporations in areas listed in the National Estate Register. This is achieved by reliance on the Commonwealth's power with respect to foreign corporations and trading or financial corporations (s. 51xx of the Constitution) and its powers with respect to the peoples of the Aboriginal race (s. 51xxvi of the Constitution).
Clause 3 inserts into the Principal Act a definition of the types of corporations which will be subject to regulation for the purposes of the Bill.

At present the Act merely requires the Australian Heritage Commission to identify places and objects worthy of inclusion in the Register, to advise the Minister for Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories in respect of the National Estate and furnish reports to the Minister on certain matters.
The Bill sets up a two-tier form of protection for the National Estate.
Retention of Existing Provisions

Firstly, it retains-with a minor amendment-the present provisions ss. 28-30 dealing with the responsibilities of the Commission and Commonwealth Ministers. It inserts a new heading ``Division 1-Responsibilities of Commission and Ministers'' to make this clear and inserts a new s. 28a stating that when regulations are in force the powers conferred by Division 1 will be exercised in a manner consistent with those regulations.
Protection of the National Estate by Regulation

Secondly, the Bill adds a new Division to Part V of the AHC Act headed ``Division 2-Prohibition of certain acts in the National Estate'' which empowers the making of regulations by the Governor-General to prohibit a corporation from taking or causing or permitting to be taken any action whether within or outside a place on the Register that adversely affects or might adversely affect to a significant degree a place in the Register. Corporations which contravene this provision would face a fine of $100,000.

Proposed sub-section 30a (1) empowers the Governor-General to make regulations prohibiting corporations from doing certain actions in any place in the Register where the Governor-General is satisfied that the doing of any such acts will adversely affect that place.

Proposed sub-section 30a (2) empowers the Governor-General to make similar regulations prohibiting actions outside any place in the Register which may adversely affect a place in the Register. Some environmental effects will not be stopped at the line on the map marking the boundary of an area listed in the National Estate.
A corporation infringing the proposed sub-sections 30a (1) and (2) will be liable to a penalty of $100,000.
Protection of Aboriginal Sites

The Bill gives specific protection to Aboriginal sites in National Estate areas. Proposed sub-sections 30b (3) and (4) empower the Governor-General to make regulations protecting Aboriginal sites that are situated within a place that is in the Register which are of particular significance to Aboriginal people. The penalty for contravening regulations is a fine of $100,000.
Absolute and Conditional Prohibitions
Proposed s. 30c provides that regulations made under the Act may prohibit the doing of an act absolutely or may allow certain actions where specified conditions or restrictions are complied with.
Injunctions

In proposed s. 30d of the Bill there is provision for certain parties to obtain injunctions and interim injunctions from the Federal Court restraining a corporation from breaching s. 30a. The parties that can seek injunctions include the Minister, a person whose use or enjoyment of any part of a place in the National Estate may be adversely affected and interested organisations whose activities relate to the conservation and protection of the National Estate.

The granting of standing to such persons and groups is vitally important in laws dealing with the protection of the environment. Conservation groups may have specialised knowledge of the environment of particular areas. Legislation must include mechanisms to ensure that all relevant information is brought forward before decisions are made about places in the Register.
Responsibility of Corporation Employees

Another important provision in the Bill is the proposed s. 30e which makes officers or employees of a corporation who are `in any way, by act or omission directly or indirectly knowingly concerned in or party to ``a corporations contravention of certain provisions guilty of an offence punishable by a fine not exceeding $2000 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 6 months.''
Daily Penalties
Proposed s. 30f provides for the imposition of daily penalties of up to $20,000 for each day where a corporation contravenes the Act for 2 or more days.
Application to the Commonwealth and Territories and Authorities of the Commonwealth and Territories

The final important provision in the Bill is proposed s. 30g which provides that regulations to protect the National Estate shall be binding on the Commonwealth and Territories and authorities of the Commonwealth and Territories. Although contravention of regulations made under the Act would not lead to conviction, injunctions can be sought to restrain these bodies from contravening or continuing to contravene regulations.
Comments on the application of National Estate Protection Legislation

In a slightly more ideal world this legislation would not be necessary. Instead a referendum featuring broad political agreement would be held and the Constitution would be amended to give the Federal Government direct powers to protect and conserve areas, places and objects that are important parts of the natural and cultural inheritance of all Australians. This conservation role ought to be the responsibility of the Federal Government and our national assets should not be subject to baronial decisions by State Governments.

As it is, the States make short-sighted decisions and the Federal Government is happy to ignore the damage until they are dragged reluctantly into disputes by widespread public concern. In 1979 the former president of the Australian Council of Trade Unions described our Federal system as `absurd folly, and `anachronistic lunacy' and looking at the management of the environment under this system it is easy to see why. And since a referendum is likely to remain merely a twinkle in the avuncular eye of Senator Richardson for a very long time, we will have to accept the next best thing; legislation based on existing powers in the Australian Constitution.

I first began considering the possibility of proposing legislation to protect the National Estate based on the corporations power in the Australian Constitution early this year during a visit to Kakadu. I was given a paper that suggested the application of these powers, through legislation, to Kakadu. Subsequent events demonstrated a much more widespread application; the developing dispute between the NSW State Government and the Federal Government about logging in National Estate areas of the South East forests being a particular case in point.

I scarcely need to advise the Government on how it ought to apply the legislation proposed by this Bill to the National Estate areas of the South East forests since Ministers have been threatening to use these powers on a regular basis; in a syncopated response to belligerent `we will cut the forests down' statements from NSW Natural Resources Minister Mr Causley. I would only suggest that they will find it easier if the powers are first embodied in legislation.

As a symbolic exercise to accompany this Bill I have prepared National Estate nominations for two places of particular cultural importance for Australia. They are Bondi and Manly beaches; sadly notable today for the horror stories of faecal and industrial pollution that appear almost daily in Sydney's media. I quote from the Statement of Significance that will be included in my nominations.
``Statement of Significance

This nomination is one of two simultaneous nominations that propose the listing of Bondi and Manly beaches in the Register of the National Estate. Although these are different beaches, the qualities that make them both worthy of inclusion in the Register are essentially the same and these comments will be entered in both nomination application forms.

Bondi and Manly beaches are central to an important aspect of traditional European Australian culture. Criterion A.4 easily have been written with these beaches in mind; they are indeed important ``for their association with events, developments or cultural phases which have had a significant role in the human occupation and evolution of the nation''. They are also locations that are typical of ``a distinctive way of life that is locally in danger of being lost''-or severely curtailed (criterion B.2).

These beaches have been recreational sites since the early days of the colony and are historically central to the progressive introduction of daylight swimming, recreational beach culture, surf life-saving (and its associated ocean-beach sports) and board surfing into Australian culture (the attached bibliography contains detailed histories of both beaches.).

Australia's outstanding record of achievement in water sports owes much to the outdoors culture that grew from these beaches. They generated one version of the ``Manly'' bronzed Aussie myth and are also associated with an easygoing hedonism and a determination to balance endeavour relaxation that is still identified as a feature of the Australian character.

However, the beach was also the place where urban Australians grappled with nature face to face. The role of the beach as a source of challenge and self-affirmation is confirmed by the professionalism of the surf life-saving organisations. One of the occasional hazards of beach swimming, the shark, has become a powerful cultural symbol.

Some of these observations apply to many Australian beaches but Bondi and Manly have historical primacy. They are among the most famous beaches in the world and their locations close to the centre of Australia's largest city is a vital part of their mythic significance.

These beaches have been subject to pollution by sewage for many years, but the rapid increase in the size of Sydney, coupled with a greater scientific and popular appreciation of the risks posed by both sewage and industrial waste, has led to widely publicised disgust and apprehension. Existing Water Board sewage processing practices and the current outfall modification will continue to degrade these valuable natural assets.''

I was surprised to find that these beaches were not already nominated since the criteria for listing in the Register could almost have been written to describe them. However, the loss we suffer by the current degradation of these beaches is representative of the malaise in our system of government that is allowing important parts of our natural and cultural heritage to be lost.

Nowhere in Australia is raw growth more evident than in Sydney; nowhere is it less productive of real products of the type we are told we need; ships full of empty containers sail out of Sydney harbour. Successive State governments have failed to plan for this growth and this is particularly evident in the primitive arrangements for the disposal of Sydney's wastes. Necessary improvements have been constantly postponed and when action was taken it was always the stop-gap solution that was chosen-like the current outfall modification that may lessen but will not solve the problem.

Meanwhile the Commonwealth Government feels free to ignore problems that are nominally the responsibility of the States, even when our internationally famous beaches are being degraded-and vilified in the international press. The July ``Statement on the Environment'' said nothing about this problem and when the State Government decided to score some cheap points by rudely demanding that the Federal Government hand over to them the land formerly occupied by the ANZAC rifle range at Malabar so that they could build a sewage treatment plant, the Federal Government response was the equivalent of a short expletive. On neither side was there any intention to seek a real solution to the problem.

This has to change and one step in the right direction is the extension of Commonwealth responsibility over places of national importance. By nominating our two most famous beaches for listing in the Register of the National Estate, I am not suggesting that regulations should immediately be passed to block off the flow of sewage and industrial waste through the ocean outfalls, but that the Commonwealth Government become involved in a real search for a permanent solution. In theory it might be possible to act against the Water Board; it's a moot point. It might also be possible to seek injunctions against identifiable industrial polluters even if they were legally dumping under New South Wales law. But the use of punitive provisions in legislation does not itself provide solutions to the problem.

It is something of a paradox that our Minister for the Environment also holds in his capacious portfolio the responsibility for tourism. Before the airline strike the Golden Tourist was the migratory species that was going to solve our economic problems; enticed by our natural wonders this creature could be stroked to exude a copious flow of foreign exchange which could be used to soothe the bleeding sore of our current account deficit.

Meanwhile we are laying waste the very natural assets that are meant to attract this beneficient creature; wasting not in an impulse of enthusiastic barbarism, but in a desperate and sneaky way like a child drug addict raiding its mother's handbag. We need the next cash fix and then we will be able to be responsible about our resources.

In his speech on the 22nd of August the Prime Minister asserted that ``we can only have economically sustainable development if that development is environmentally sustainable''; the legislation proposed by this Bill will assist him by enabling him-or his successor-to protect our valuable National Estate areas from environmentally unsustainable development.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robert Ray) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

I am extremely pleased to introduce this Bill, which includes measures providing for the grant of secure title to land to Aboriginal people in the pastoral areas of the Northern Territory. These measures are part of a package agreed to recently by the Commonwealth and Northern Territory Governments-an agreement which represents a significant breakthrough in obtaining land justice for Aboriginal people who either live or recently lived on pastoral properties, or whose traditional lands are on pastoral leases.

These people have had a long and until now virtually fruitless struggle to obtain secure title to land. Many live on pastoral properties or town camps in conditions equal to those found in third world countries. It is to the discredit of this nation that such conditions have been tolerated for so long. The provision of secure title to land is essential before these communities can be provided with the infrastructure and facilities necessary to improve their living conditions.
Before describing the measures contained in the Bill, Mr President, let me review the long history of failed attempts by Governments to address this problem.

The 1971 report of the Committee to Review the Situation of Aboriginals on Pastoral Properties in the Northern Territory, the so-called Gibb Report, recommended the excision from pastoral leases of community living areas. These living areas were envisaged as relatively small areas of land sufficient to meet the basic living needs of an Aboriginal community and to provide that community with a measure of autonomy.

In the second report of the Aboriginal Land Rights Commission in April 1974 Justice Woodward again drew attention to this need. Since that time, numerous Government Committees and independent inquiries have pointed out the urgent need to provide secure title to land to Aboriginal people in pastoral areas.
The over-riding problem has been that most land in the pastoral areas of the Territory is land leased from the Crown by pastoralists.

The Aboriginal Land (Northern Territory) Bill 1975 introduced by the Whitlam Government included provisions to authorise an Aboriginal Land Commissioner to recommend the grant of land on a needs basis in certain areas including land under pastoral lease.

The Fraser Government did not proceed with this proposal. Thus the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 (the Land Rights Act) provides for Aboriginal people to claim only unalienated Crown land or alienated Crown land held by or on behalf of Aboriginal people. As a consequence, several thousand Aboriginal people missed out on the right to acquire title to land in pastoral areas.

When this Government came to office in 1983, the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the Hon. Clyde Holding, initiated discussions with the Northern Territory Government to facilitate the granting of community living areas on pastoral leases.

Initially, in 1983, the Northern Territory Government proposed a Community Living Areas Bill. The then Chief Minister, Paul Everingham, acknowledged that for some time the Northern Territory Government had recognised the need for a proper legislative mechanism to enable excisions of community living areas to be achieved more smoothly. At that time only 12 excisions had been granted. However that Bill was not enacted.

Following extensive negotiations by the Commonwealth, in April 1985 the Northern Territory introduced administrative guidelines for excision applications, and undertook to accelerate the process of dealing with those applications.
For its part, the Commonwealth undertook to amend the Land Rights Act to limit the right of Aboriginal people to claim stock routes and reserves.

These amendments were enacted in June 1987. However, the Commonwealth said that they would not be proclaimed until arrangements were made for the granting of land to Aboriginal people ineligible to apply for excisions under the Northern Territory's guidelines. The proclamation of the amendments would have resulted in the immediate withdrawal of most land claims over stock routes and reserves from the jurisdiction of the Aboriginal Land Commissioner.

When Mr Hand first became Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in 1987, he began negotiations with the then Northern Territory Chief Minister, the Hon. Steve Hatton, to try and speed up the very slow progress on the provision of living areas. Unfortunately the Working Party established then to resolve the delay was later disbanded.
By early 1989 it had become clear that the rate of progress in issuing titles was unsatisfactory.

The real losers in the failed attempts by Governments to achieve a satisfactory resolution to this problem were of course the Aboriginal people themselves. People who had in many cases seen other Aboriginal people obtain land justice through the land claim processes available under the Land Rights Act were forced to endure years of protracted negotiations with little or no result.

Finally, the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory recommenced negotiations earlier this year. In September the two Governments reached an historic understanding when a Memorandum of Agreement was signed by the Prime Minister and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory.

This Bill fulfils the Commonwealth's commitment under that agreement. For its part the Northern Territory has passed legislation which will provide a statutory mechanism to allow certain Aboriginal people to make applications for community living areas on pastoral properties. Land granted under that arrangement will be under freehold title in accordance with Territory Law.

Under the terms of the Memorandum, the Commonwealth undertook to amend the Land Rights Act as a matter of priority, to provide for the granting of certain parts of existing land claims to stock routes and reserves. At the same time the earlier amendment to the Act limiting claims over stock routes and travelling stock reserves will be proclaimed. The selection of the areas to be granted has been determined after consultation with the Northern Territory.
In deciding on the areas to be granted the Government has been concerned to ensure that the terms of the Memorandum of Agreement are adhered to.
The areas to be granted represent only a small proportion of the land subject to existing claims over stock routes and reserves.

Mr President, the total area of all of the parcels of land described in the Bill, some 2,312 sq km, represents only approximately 26% of the total stock route and reserve claims. Looking at the stock route component, the total area of the portions of stock routes to be granted represents approximately only 6% of the total stock route claims.
The area of land to be granted is about 0.17 per cent of the total area of the Northern Territory.

The Government has taken steps to ensure that pastoral operations are not unreasonably interfered with by the granting of these areas of land. Where appropriate the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has sought relevant undertakings from the Aboriginal claimants for the continued use of station roads, bores or infrastructure by the pastoral lessees. In some instances, the areas have been amended to exclude access corridors or areas of particular concern to pastoralists or the Northern Territory Government.
Before I go into the detail of the undertakings that have been given, or the land which has been given up by claimants, I want to make two general observations.

Firstly, these undertakings are really about sharing the country and the resources. In acceding to the requests of Mr Hand for undertakings, the Aboriginal claimants have again demonstrated a willingness to share their land with pastoral operations. This continued willingness to share, and to compromise, is a real tribute to the Aboriginal people.
Secondly, where possible, every effort has been made to resolve issues of particular concern raised with Mr Hand by the Northern Territory by a letter of 25 September, 1989.
I want to detail the undertakings they have given.

Perhaps the most important undertaking in respect of continuing pastoral operations relates to continued access to water resources. Claimants for the areas at Ammaroo, Alice Well, Black Tank Bore (on Bond Springs), Finke, Mount Peachy (on Maryvale), Henbury/Orange Creek, Mount Kathleen (on Loves Creek) and Undoolya Bore and Williams Bore (on Undoolya) have given undertakings to share access to bores with pastoralists.

In order that pastoral operations will not be inconvenienced by access problems, the claimants for areas at Ammaroo, Ranken River, Undoolya Bore, Forster Range (on Stirling), Mt Peachy, Henbury/Orange Creek and Mt Kathleen have given undertakings relating to the continued use of station roads which may cross the areas to be granted by the pastoralists concerned.

Where there appears to be major station infrastructure situated on reserves, at Ammaroo, Mt Peachy and Ooratippra, claimants have undertaken to allow continued access by pastoralists to that infrastructure. As well, an undertaking has been given for the continued access across a stock route for cattle operations at Lorne Creek.

Undertakings have also been given relating to allowing the construction of a water pipeline through Undoolya Bore, the continued use of areas at Mt Solitaire (on Hamilton Downs) by the CSIRO, the grant of easements for the gas pipeline at Birdum (the Jommet Block) and at Elliott, and for the continuation for a reasonable period of a grazing licence affecting part of the land at Birdum.

The specifics of the undertakings which have been given will be discussed with the lessees of the relevant pastoral properties. I also put on notice that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs will consider any requests for further undertakings which may be put to him by affected pastoralists or the Northern Territory Government.

In the course of Mr Hand's consultations with the Northern Territory Government, four areas, previously identified, have been excluded from this scheduling process because, in terms of the Memorandum of Agreement, agreement had been reached that the claimants' needs could be satisfactorily met by a grant under Northern Territory title of a portion of stock route and an adjacent excision.

Mr Hand has also agreed to amend the descriptions of some of the areas to be granted to take into account particular concerns expressed to him by the Northern Territory. In particular, I ask honourable senators to note the following examples.
The southern boundary of the area to be granted in the Birdum locality has been amended to provide a greater distance between the area, and the town of Larrimah.

The south-east section of approximately 19 hectares of the area at Newcastle Waters has been excluded from the scheduling process because the claimants recognised the importance of that area in terms of the water needs of the town and surrounding district.
In accordance with concerns raised by the Northern Territory, an area used for cattle yards and a dip at Elliott has been excluded from the area to be scheduled.
At Finke, the claimants have given up most of the two stock route portions previously included in this area, limiting scheduling to a small section of stock route only.

At Henbury/Orange Creek, the original claim was for a length of a stock route cutting across two properties. The claimants have agreed to the granting of four separate portions, representing a reduction of more than 50% of the original claim.

Claimants have agreed to the amendment of the southern boundary of the area to be scheduled at the 16 Mile (Bond Springs), at the request of the pastoralist, to provide an access corridor for cattle operations. As well, the area containing the airstrip used by the Alice Springs Gliding Club has been excluded from scheduling.

The conclusion of the agreement between the two Governments and the action to be taken because of it finally provides some certainty for Aboriginal people who have been living in appalling conditions for so many years. It is my hope that living conditions for these people can now be quickly improved.
Mr President

I turn now to the other provisions contained in this Bill. In 1987 complex new provisions streamlining processes relating to mineral exploration and mining on Aboriginal land were included in the Act.

This Bill contains a number of measures to fine tune those new provisions. Currently, the new exploration and mining provisions do not apply to the Coronation Hill Project Area and the remainder of the Kakadu Conservation Zone. The amendments remove this anomaly by providing for the new provisions to apply to these areas.

Other amendments to the exploration and mining provisions will allow for an agreement, entered into in relation to exploration, to continue after the end of exploration activity. This will allow for, among other things, rehabilitation of the land to be completed.

There are special provisions relating to the Eastern Areas on Groote Eylandt and the Coronation Hill Project area. These provisions will provide that, where land either is, or becomes, Aboriginal land, exploration licences can be issued without the Land Council's consent. However a terms and conditions agreement would be required to be entered into. The issue of mining interests on these areas will also be subject to a terms and conditions agreement.

In the case of the provisions that relate to the Eastern Areas on Groote Eylandt they will allow a person to apply for a mining interest even if he has not held an exploration licence in respect of that land.
In the case of the Coronation Hill Project Area I wish to make it clear that this provision will only affect that area if and when it becomes Aboriginal Land.

In relation to the payment of mining royalty equivalents into the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account, subsection 63 (3) of the Act is dependent for its operation on the provisions of the former Mining Act of the Northern Territory. However, the Mineral Royalty Act now sets the amount of mining royalties for hard rock minerals and has changed the system from an ad valorem to a profits based royalty system. Subsection 63 (3) will be amended so that it can now function within the new royalty regime operating in the Northern Territory.

There is a provision which will allow for the modification by regulation of the boundaries of areas granted under the new parts of schedule 1. This power is provided to allow for minor correction of descriptions of the land where further survey or other evidence suggests that the boundaries have not been accurately described. The provision is not intended to permit major changes to the area of land to be granted and the power will not be available after the land has actually been granted.
There are a number of other amendments of a miscellaneous nature which are set out in detail in the Bill and the explanatory memorandum.

This Bill together with the Northern Territory legislation which has been passed by the Legislative Assembly provides some measure of justice for deprived groups of Aboriginal people. These proposals to provide land for Aboriginal people are an important achievement by this Government.
I hope this agreement heralds a new era of co-operation between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory Governments which can only lead to benefits for Aboriginal and non Aboriginal Territorians.
Mr President, I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.
