SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The votes for the Department of Finance would not, I think, normally be a very contentious area of the Appropriation Bills. The Department of Finance is one of the key coordinating departments of the Government and, as such, does not tend to have much in the way of what I might call clientele in the way that so many of the functional departments have. The role of the Department of Finance is rather, as its name perhaps implies, to administer, oversee, supervise and, I suppose, to a degree control on behalf of the Executive Government the expenditures of government. Although departments of finance, no more than departments of the treasury, can ever expect to be popular, nevertheless I do not think that there are very often charges laid-or at any rate, charges substantiated, as distinct from being laid-which are overly critical of that Department.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, there are some elements of the Department's appropriations and activities to which I want to make brief reference this morning. I begin by looking at the 1988-89 annual report of the Department of Finance, which was recently tabled in the Parliament. As I did not speak on that report at the time, I want to take the opportunity to congratulate the Department on the quality, presentation and general informativeness of its report. It is, I think, a credit to the Department, and that ought to be said.

I will not spend long on this particular point, but I cannot resist one minor digression. The chart on page 9 of the report sets out the management structure of the Department as at 1 June 1989. Looking at its divisional and branch structure, I notice many names which have a high degree of familiarity, although there are one or two in more elevated positions than I might otherwise have expected. For example, I notice that one of the deputy secretaries of the Department is now Mr Stephen Sedgwick, who I seem to recall was until recently an economic adviser to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Mr Sedgwick appears to have had a rather accelerated rate of promotion, which I am sure was thoroughly deserved, and I congratulate him on that degree of advancement.

Let me come to the Department's functions. In particular I want to say something about the Commonwealth superannuation scheme and other superannuation areas that are administered by the Australian Government Retirement Benefits Office and that, in policy terms, are the responsibility of the Department. I take this opportunity of saying that I regret that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is not here today. I regret his absence because I understand it is through illness, which is a matter for regret. But, as with many of his colleagues, I think the Minister is suffering from a degree of exhaustion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us settle this outside right now.

—I do not know about that. The honourable senator is bigger than I am. I do not think we have to have these things out on that ground. Let us debate the issue: the fact of the matter is that the Minister is exhausted and, if I may say so, so is Senator Ray.
—Not at all.

—Well, we will see. No, I withdraw that. I accept that the Minister is less exhausted than many of his colleagues, and I pay tribute to him on that count. But there is no doubt that the Minister for Finance is exhausted. In view of the problems that he and one or two of his more economically rational colleagues have been having to contend with in recent times, that is not surprising. Contending with a Prime Minister who has quite clearly taken it upon himself to give the kind of `leadership' which this country could well do without-the kind of leadership which, for example, involves the breaking of written promises to our major company, Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP), in relation to the development of the Coronation Hill deposit-would be enough to exhaust any Minister. That event subsequently led the Chairman of BHP, a most respected Australian, Sir Arvi Parbo, to say publicly on a radio program that, in the light of that and a number of other similar examples of prime ministerial leadership in recent times, Australia's name stinks in the world today, in Sir Arvi's words. I do not think anybody should take any pleasure from that comment by Sir Arvi; it is simply a sad reflection upon the position to which Australia has been led by a Prime Minister and, I suppose one has to say, his Cabinet generally-there is such a thing as collective responsibility-in their manic search for re-election, and to hell with the country in the process.

SPEECH.PARA: But I have digressed, and I am grateful to the Chair for its tolerance. I will now return to my initial remark, which was that the Minister for Finance is clearly exhausted and that has no doubt added to the health problems from which he appears to be suffering at the moment. I extend my sympathies to him in that regard.

I was about to say something about the Commonwealth superannuation scheme, in regard to which the Minister recently announced the outcome of a major review that has been undertaken over some time. That review is referred to in the Department's report but, as the report covers only the year 1988-89, it does not comment on the outcome of the review of the scheme. When recently announcing the outcome of that review the Minister made available a good deal of very useful and informative material for which I express the Opposition's gratitude. One element in the material that caught my eye-particularly in view of the fact that it was not very long after the Opposition's announcement of its Economic Action Plan-was the decision by the Government to tighten up very dramatically access by public servants covered by the Commonwealth superannuation scheme to the so-called invalidity provisions of that scheme. In announcing the outcome the Minister commented that retirements from Commonwealth employment under invalidity provisions have been running, in proportionate terms, at roughly five times those in the community generally. He went on to observe that in the case of Telecom Australia and Australia Post, whose employees are also at present covered by that scheme, the rate was as high as 10 times that in the community generally.

In the light of the announcement, quite clearly the Minister and the Government have concluded that a great deal of fraud and abuse of those invalidity provisions has been committed and that it is time to put a stop to those practices, or at least to exercise much greater control than has previously been the case.

I advert to that topic not only because of its intrinsic interest, which I think is considerable anyway, and the fact that it is highly relevant to the appropriations of the Department, but also because, in this area, the Government has acknowledged what the Opposition said by way of a more general set of observations in our Economic Action Plan in relation to the need for, and the fiscal worth of, cutting down on the fraud and abuse which is rampant throughout large areas of our whole social security system. The Opposition has indicated that it proposes to move in that area, particularly in relation to unemployment benefits and the invalidity area.

At the time of the release of that plan there was some suggestion from Government Ministers to the effect that, once again, here was the Opposition kicking the poor to give to the rich, or some other highly emotive and colourful phrase of the kind that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) comes out with from time to time. It took him a week to get his act together to say anything on the subject. I want to underline the fact that here is the Government, through the mouth of its own Minister for Finance, providing substantial evidence in a particular area of the truth of the basic position as set out in the cost cutting proposals of the Opposition's Economic Action Plan.

The other element of the Department's appropriations to which I wish to refer relates to the arrangements for natural disaster relief. As I very well recall, from the days when they used to be administered by the Treasury, those arrangements are of a fairly complex nature and have developed over a long period. To some degree it is fair to say that they have come into existence on an ad hoc basis and, I suppose, in a fairly arbitrary manner. They have come to reflect the accumulation of many decisions taken by successive governments in the light of particular circumstances such as, say, a cyclone in Darwin or the major flood in Queensland in 1974.

The matter to which I want particularly to refer is the fact that in its economic statement in April this year, the present Government decided to delete any provisions for drought relief from the arrangements for natural disaster relief. The strange thing about that is that-I think I am correct in saying this-it was drought relief, perhaps flood relief also, that was among the very earliest areas that brought these provisions into existence whereby the Commonwealth provided some assistance to State governments in relation to these natural disasters. These provisions really relate to areas which, strictly speaking, are within the constitutional responsibilities of State governments, which have responsibility to deal with flood damaged roads and culverts, major bush fires, and things of that kind. However, over the years a view developed that, where one had real disasters in these areas as distinct, say, from the normal acts of God, then it was probably proper, and certainly was found to be politically expedient by governments of both persuasions, to provide some additional assistance to State governments for dealing with these matters. I think I am correct in saying that drought relief was one of the very earliest areas where that came to pass.

It is extraordinary that the Government should have decided in April this year to delete drought relief provisions from those areas where the Commonwealth properly provides assistance in extreme circumstances. The Commonwealth does not pick up the whole bill for drought relief, and nor should it; but in relation to extreme and prolonged droughts, the Commonwealth Government has taken the view over the years that it should begin to come to the party at some stage in situations where State governments would be financially embarrassed if they had to pick up the whole bill.

It is regrettable that the Government has made this decision. It is true that it has put in hand a review of what Commonwealth involvement there should be in future drought relief. That review is supposed to be completed by March of next year-whether it is completed before or after the election remains to be seen-but in the meantime there is a hiatus in this area. Fortunately, at present Australia does not have much drought, except in localised areas and no doubt those situations will be handled by State governments. However, I draw attention to what is a rather petty and somewhat vindictive decision by the Government, deriving from some personal fixation-I would say that it is almost an obsession-on the part of the Minister for Finance in relation to some particular instance in the past in Queensland-about which the Minister has his facts wrong, anyway.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On that same matter, I can only concur with Senator Stone's remarks. I regret that people of my own State of South Australia are no longer able to gain any Commonwealth financial assistance during a time of a disaster such as drought. Happily, this year there have been good rains and drought is not on our agenda, but it certainly was on the agenda in the previous year and the year before that. My recollection is that at least $40m was made available during the previous financial year, but no provision has been made for drought during this financial year because of this obsession or fixation by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh). He happens to be a farmer who has a very disciplined approach to a number of areas, which is all well and good. But then he adds to that his obsession that the costs of drought should be built into the capital price of land.

SPEECH.PARA: After a couple of centuries of Australians having to deal with drought, he has just announced that there will be no more Commonwealth assistance for drought relief because he has an obsession that any land to be purchased for primary purposes should not be purchased at the market value of recent years, taking into account inflation and various trends. Instead, the value is to be discounted so as to take account of any drought that may come. There is a kind of obsessive logic about that because one can calculate that a serious drought may occur once in 10 years and that the failure of a certain piece of land to produce once in 10 years will be a loss of, say, $1,000 an acre, so one has to build that into the value of land at the point of purchase. Such a proposition is not acceptable to me. When it is clearly the outcome of the personal judgment of one Minister, without there being a satisfactory explanation at any point, we want to persist with gaining at least some wider rationale from Senator Robert Ray, who is in the chamber, and to ask him to take the matter back to the Government for review.

The Government has imposed limitations on entitlement to the isolated children's allowance and assistance schemes for students generally by introducing a capital means test. It is not just the recurrent income which is tested to determine whether those allowances are payable for children undertaking education. If a property owned by a family exceeds a certain capital value it will not be possible for that family to receive any such allowance for education. When it was put squarely to Senator Walsh that all properties can have a disastrous year at some stage, such as in a drought, his answer was along similar lines. Again he had this obsessive logic, which I believe is not acceptable to honourable senators, that drought must be taken into account in the value of the property on which the farming is being undertaken and that in the good years money has to be set aside for education, because in a drought year when income falls to zero or is negative there is no way that the Hawke Labor Government will allow an educational allowance to go to a family in those circumstances. I believe that that is the outcome of the obsessive fixation of the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, despite his other qualities. I ask Senator Ray to give a further explanation, if that is possible, and, if not, to take the matter to the Government for review.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Stone began his remarks by reviewing the organisation chart of the Department of Finance. I noted down the following point: `Stone warns of purge in Finance'. Taking the rest of his comments on board thereinafter, I think I will have to scrub off that point because he was not in fact doing so. Regarding Senator Stone's second point, it is part of the coalition's political agenda to argue that the Government is tired, that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is tired, et cetera. Ministers do get sick. Doug Anthony got hepatitis while he was a Minister. Peter Durack, unfortunately, suffered a heart attack as a Minister. I do not recall our making those points at that time. It is true to say that probably one of the most enervating jobs in government would be that of its Finance Minister. The Minister is required to attend not only Cabinet meetings but also Expenditure Review Committee meetings and every Cabinet subcommittee meeting. That is tiring and it may have contributed to Senator Walsh's illness. Who knows? I do not think necessarily that one can draw the conclusion that the whole Government is tired. I also suspect that Senator Walsh's irascibility in the early stages of his current illness and his more unorthodox treatment of it have probably delayed his return to the chamber somewhat, which is bad news for the winegrowers.

SPEECH.PARA: Both Senator Stone and Senator Teague raised the question of drought. Essentially, it is the Government's view-it is not just Senator Walsh's view-that that is a State matter. Of course, States rights do not become involved in this argument. It is usually the other side of the chamber that argues that. However, I can answer the point raised by Senator Teague. He asked whether the matter is sitting there in limbo. It is not. The Department of Primary Industries and Energy is heading up an interdepartmental committee to look at all these issues. If this one were ever to be resurrected it would be resurrected in Mr Kerin's area, one would think. That committee is due to report in March. Presumably at the next Estimates committee meeting Senator Teague will be able to follow it up to see what has happened. I note for the record that I have often seen graphs of rainfall. On the Australian average it has tended to be remarkably high, with some exceptions, from 1972 to 1975 and from 1983 to 1989. I often point out to farmers that there is a correlation between Labor governments and a lot of rainfall. How long that lasts depends on how long the Government stays in power, one would guess.

The only other remarks that I recall Senator Stone making were a few barbs at the Treasurer (Mr Keating). It was very cruel of him to do so. I can remember that when I suggested at the National Executive meeting of the Australian Labor Party in 1983 that we put a pink ticket in his pay packet he defended Senator Stone vigorously. I am sure that he has the same high regard for Senator Stone today as he had then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not normally rise again to speak to these estimates, but I must comment briefly on a couple of things the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) has said by way of his response. He mentioned that the view of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) in relation to drought relief arrangements is that it is a State matter. I think that I was careful in my remarks to say that it is, to a considerable degree, a State matter. There is no argument about that. It always has been. However, the reason for the institution of the Commonwealth arrangements for drought relief, as with other natural disasters which are also State matters, such as bushfires and floods, was that there comes a time in the development of these major natural disasters, including a major drought of a prolonged kind, when the view has been taken by governments of all political persuasions that the capacity for the States affected to carry the cost of that major disaster is inadequate and, therefore, the States concerned-of course, this varies from time to time, as it is rather unusual for a drought to cover the whole of Australia-have been provided with some supplementary assistance. That has been the basis on which drought relief has been provided in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: It is wrong for the Minister to suggest that this is or should be regarded as a matter of clean-cut State responsibility, because it is the Commonwealth's responsibility. Normally I would have a lot of sympathy for the view that too much confusion between these two areas of responsibility in financial arrangements has grown up in Australia over many years. The only other point I want to make is that when the Minister refers to a propensity to rain during the time of Labor governments, it seems to be more or less a suggestion of `apres nous le deluge'. I do not know what that really means in terms of the state of the economy which Labor administrations leave behind them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department of the Treasury is another of the departments to which I referred in my earlier remarks when I said that the Department of Finance is one of the major coordinating departments and that one therefore would not normally expect to find much to criticise within at least the purely administrative functions of the Department because it does not have much in the way of clientele. Nevertheless, because of the very wide policy responsibilities that the Department of the Treasury enjoys, if that is the right word, I think it is necessary to spend a few minutes discussing its appropriations. To some degree we have been assisted in doing so by a rather important speech made not long ago by the recently appointed Secretary to the Treasury, Dr Higgins, who addressed the Consult Australia Annual Forum on 16 November last. His speech has been widely reported and I want to spend a few minutes to note certain aspects of it. In particular, I want to draw the Committee's attention to some comments by Dr Higgins on the difficulties from which the Australian economy has suffered on occasions in the past when we have entered into recession.

SPEECH.PARA: I take the time of the Committee to do this for the following reason: we in the Opposition are accustomed to Ministers suggesting that the recession, particularly that of 1982-83, was in some way the responsibility of a conservative administration, if one can describe Mr Fraser's administration as conservative. Of course, economists have always understood that that recession was a direct result of the wage explosion of 1981-82 which immediately preceded it and which virtually destroyed at one stroke the profitability of Australian enterprises, which produced a remarkable lift in business costs and therefore a remarkable decline in Australia's competitiveness in the external world and hence a large rise in the balance of payments deficit and so on. From time to time the Government is prone to suggest that somehow Australia's debt problems from which we are suffering so grievously today all began in 1982-83 as a result of the policies of the previous Government and because in 1981-82 and 1982-83 the balance of payments deficit was quite large-as it is now. Dr Higgins has performed a most useful service in setting the record straight on this matter. On page 9 of the printed text of his address he says:
Both of Australia's two previous recessions in my generation, in the mid-1970s-
and I have not taken the time of the Committee to talk about that one-
and the early 1980s-were importantly attributable to massive increases in wages.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or the lack of a wages policy by the Government at the time.

—I am glad to hear the Minister interject along those lines because I rather expected that he would. Let us be quite clear as to the origins of the wage explosion that we are talking about. The origin was to be found in the fact that in or about July 1981 the then Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, now the Industrial Relations Commission, decided to abandon any further attempt to maintain a centralised wage system. It did that in the light of the total disregard of its decisions by a number of key unions-in particular, the Federated Storemen and Packers Union, which is Mr Simon Crean's union, I remind the chamber, the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union and a number of others. At that time the Commission was led to the view that it simply had to wash its hands of the whole performance, which had been reduced to the level of farce. Following that we had a carefully orchestrated campaign by the trade union movement in this country. It was orchestrated by two very prominent officials in the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) today-namely, the President, as I think he still is formally, Simon Crean--
—You will see him in the House of Representatives next year.

—He is about to become a parliamentary candidate. The other official was the present Secretary of the ACTU, Mr Bill Kelty, ably aided and abetted by other stalwarts of the trade union movement such as Mr Laurie Carmichael, then of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union; Mr John Halfpenny of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union and still of that union--
—No, you are wrong.
—If I am wrong the Minister will correct me.
—The Trades Hall Council Secretary.
—Indeed, he is that, but I thought he was still a member of that union.
—He is not a leader of the union.

—I accept the point that he is now the Secretary of the Victorian Trades Hall Council. We all know that. Nevertheless, he is still formally a member of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union, I think. Another person involved was Mr George Campbell, the Secretary of the New South Wales branch of the union. As a result of this we had a massive wage breakout, carefully orchestrated by the trade union movement in this country. In the aftermath of that we had the major recession to which Dr Higgins refers. Let me continue quoting Dr Higgins's address. He goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: These wage explosions set inflation alight, eroded business profitability and competitiveness and greatly weakened private sector confidence. `Hard landings' were the inevitable result.
A sentence or two later he goes on to raise a point to which Government Ministers invariably fail to advert when they reflect upon that episode in our economic history. He says:
Furthermore, the disturbances in the world economy that occurred in the mid-1970s and the early 1980s-which exacerbated our home grown difficulties-are not a feature of the present scene.

That leads him into another line of discourse. It is very valuable to have the new Secretary to the Treasury put so clearly on the public record a total refutation of everything this Government has ever said about the origins of the 1982-83 recession. It is very valuable and I acknowledge the truth of what Dr Higgins has said. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray), by way of his earlier interjection, tried to suggest that some of that wage explosion in 1982-83 was due to the fact that we did not have a centralised wage system operating at that time. I take his interjection to be directed to the view that if only the accord, or something like it, had been operating at that time, things would have been different. It cannot be denied that things would have been different, but it can certainly be denied that things would have been better in any continuing sense. As more and more people are coming to accept, the accord has failed; it has simply taken longer for people in this country to understand the nature and the extent of its failure.

The Business Council of Australia recently published a striking article on that subject in its recent Bulletin. The article is headed `The Accord-Success or Failure?'. In an extensive and very well-researched article, the Business Council of Australia finally comes down in favour of the view-which has been advanced for some time by others, including not least the Federal Opposition-that the accord has been a failure. It is true that it has produced in the past 6 1/2 years a fall of 14 per cent in real unit labour costs in this country. Of course, what is not revealed by the rather glib phrase which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and other Ministers trip off their tongues is that it has come about through continuing inflation at rates which, roughly speaking, have been double those of the average of our trading partners and much more than double those of our most significant trading partners such as Japan. The fall has been brought about also by a significant depreciation in the value of the Australian dollar.

To the extent that we have retained competitiveness at all, it has been because the real value of money wage increases has been continually depreciated by inflation running faster than those money wage increases. That is supposed to be an achievement of the accord! I am very surprised to find the Government claiming it to be an achievement. Further, because those nominal wage increases have been running so fast compared to those in the countries with which we trade, over the period of this Government we have had a significant depreciation in the value of the Australian dollar. At the moment, as we all know, the value of the Australian dollar is being held temporarily appreciably higher than it was some time back because of the effect of the very high interest rates which the Government has put in place on demand for Australian dollars.

As I say, the claim that the accord has in some way been a success in rendering Australia more competitive is a claim which, when examined, as the Business Council did in the article to which I referred, can be seen to be a fraud and a sham. The only reason we have arrived at the outcome of a fall in real unit labour costs is basically that inflation has been running harder even than the quite large rises in nominal wage rates and we have had a significant depreciation in the value of our currency vis-a-vis the rest of the world during the time in question. Of course, what the proponents or advocates of the accord always fail to point out, because this is the other side, is that the clear cost, as distinct from those unclear costs which the Government claims to be benefits and which I have just been talking about, is that the accord has resulted in putting the Australian Council of Trade Unions in the box seat of policy.

The accord has also resulted in our having during the life of the present Government-particularly if one leaves out the first couple of years when there was a rebound effect from the depressed drought-affected and recession-affected situation, but even if one includes that rebound effect from the initial point at which the Government took office-an appalling productivity performance in this country, even worse than what I would regard as the rather poor productivity performance of the Government which preceded this Government. If anybody can derive for all of that a success for the accord, I would be very surprised. It is time that the Government stopped talking about the success of the accord and began facing up to the fact that the accord has been a failure. We will have to have a totally different system of industrial relations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.
—I intervene briefly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will also need a totally different structure of the trade union movement to go with that changed industrial relations system. The strange thing is that the Government, rather surreptitiously, has begun to concede that fact. We had last week in Tokyo the extraordinary sound of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) telling Japanese businessmen and Japanese journalists in a press conference from which Australian journalists were apparently excluded that the Government is proposing-if it should be re-elected which we do not for a moment expect it will be; nevertheless I understand that the Treasurer, naturally enough, must tell those things to Japanese businessmen-to transform totally the trade union scene in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer told the Japanese businessmen that under a future Labor Administration we would have trade unions like the Japanese ones. I can understand why, in those circumstances, he has not been allowing Australian journalists to attend the press conferences. He would not like a good many of our trade unionists to hear him saying so; they might not altogether agree with that kind of formulation. Indeed, there are some signs already in New South Wales of divisions within the left wing of the ranks of our trade union movement on what is already known about developments in this area, let alone about what the Treasurer is beginning to say surreptitiously in Tokyo.

I have to ask myself why it is that Mr Keating is running around foreign parts saying things like this at press conferences from which Australian journalists are excluded. I suppose that one reason might be seen in the sorts of stories appearing on the front pages of one or two of our newspapers this morning. One such story points out that the degree of Japanese ownership in this country in the next four or five years is likely to increase astronomically. Again, that is not something which this Government wants to tell the Australian people. In saying that, I do not want to be misunderstood. I do not want to be understood to be saying that there is some specific objection to Japanese ownership as such, although if one is realistic one has to note that in many parts of the community, rightly or wrongly, that view is held. One has to note that, otherwise one is hiding one's head in the sand; but that is not my point. My point is that because of the economic policies of the Government, presided over by the Treasurer and his Department, the Treasury, whose appropriations we are discussing, we face the situation where this year, because of a balance of payments deficit, resulting from these policies, of about $20 billion, we will either have to borrow that sum or sell off Australian assets in that amount.

The Treasurer is very concerned about what will occur in the next few months. As we all know, in the next few months there will almost certainly be a Federal election campaign. The Treasurer, for purely domestic political reasons, wants our domestic interest rates to fall. After all, elections will shortly be held in South Australia and Queensland. The electors, to some extent at least, are being reminded that if they intend to vote for Labor in those States, the problems from which those States are suffering at present, in relation to, say, housing loan interest rates or small business overdraft rates of between 23 and 25 per cent, derive from the policies of Labor's Federal counterparts.

The Treasurer is quite concerned about that matter. More importantly, of course, he is concerned about being able to get interest rates down between now and the Federal election. For example, he may tell the Reserve Bank to bring interest rates down. It should be remembered that the Treasurer is the man who, six months or so ago, said, in referring to the Reserve Bank, `It does as I say'. Those were his words. Perish the thought that there should be any sense of independence on the part of the Reserve Bank Governor, Board or the institution as a whole. The Treasurer is concerned that if he tells the Reserve Bank what to do, as he is accustomed to doing, it carries out his instructions-as he would certainly expect it to do-and interest rates start to come down, under those circumstances much of the present flood, or at least a very large volume, of hot money which is presently holding up our foreign exchange markets in this country, will go away. We will see what we might almost call a speculative run against the Australian dollar.

That is why the Treasurer is in Tokyo pleading with Japanese financiers not to desert him or his Government at this moment as, after all, it has been so good to foreign investors for so long. It has allowed them to come into this country and buy assets at depreciated rates. Let us be quite clear about this point: when the value of the Australian dollar falls, the price of Australian assets to foreigners diminishes. We have seen a fair bit of that already. Of course, we will see a lot more. That is why the Treasurer is in Tokyo pleading with Japanese financiers and that is why he has now gone to London to plead with British financiers and, no doubt, with a few European financiers as well-and I do not know whether he proposes to visit the United States-not to desert the Labor Party at this time. He is saying to them, `If you just hang in there long enough, our assets will be cheaper still and you will be able to buy even more of them with your yen, pounds, deutschmarks, or whatever'.

I do not see any answers-including in the speech by Dr Higgins to which I referred in my earlier remarks-or any sign of hope being held out to the Australian people that that will stop. There is no suggestion in Dr Higgins's paper that somehow the Government, or the Treasury operating under the Government, has a recipe for dealing with the problems of the country. On the contrary, the Government in its own Budget this year estimated that our balance of payments deficit this year will be $18.5 billion. That estimate has already been blown out of the water. We have had a deficit of just over $6 billion in the first three months. Another figure will be released tomorrow, and we will know a bit more about it then. It is fairly clear that unless there is a major crash coming-and the Government says that there is not-the balance of payments deficit will be higher than $18.5 billion-perhaps between $20 billion and $22 billion this year.

The Government seems prepared to sit back and accept that that is happening and accept that the direct consequence is a continuing rise in the level of our foreign debt and/or a continuing rise in the level of foreign ownership of Australian assets. It says that basically nobody should be too concerned about that. That seems to be the Government's view-that it is all to do with the activities of a few entrepreneurs who have been borrowing overseas. I do not think that that is really good enough. I wonder whether the Minister would like to respond to the remarks that I have made.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: English as a second language (ESL) education programs are acknowledged on all sides of this chamber as important to those whose mother tongue is not English. There is a requirement for families who have recently immigrated to Australia to gain quickly a sound competence in English. We need to have in place appropriate methods for teaching English as a second language to children and adults. ESL programs were savagely cut by the Hawke Labor Government in the 1986 Budget. There was a drop from $83m to $60m in the moneys that were passed on to the States. In fact, the Budget announcement was twice as drastic as that, but the protests around Australia and in this chamber were sufficient to ensure that various moneys were found in unallocated amounts in the education area to help the States make up the shortfall. But even with that scrabbling together of moneys to save the situation a little, funding was cut from $83m in 1986 to $59m in 1987. I have asked whether the peak funding for ESL in 1986 has yet been regained. The answer that I received recently is that it has not. In 1988 funding got back to $80m, and in 1989 it was $84.5m. So in real terms there is considerably less Commonwealth assistance available for ESL programs around Australia than there was in the peak year of 1986, yet the Government and Minister Dawkins have tried to put it about that they are particularly concerned to make sure that Australia's language resources are well provided for by an enlightened languages program.

A major inquiry was carried out by the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts into Australia's national language policy. It produced a report as thorough and as sound as any that this chamber has received. The Government has considered that report-in particular through the work of an officer, Mr Joe Lo Bianco-and has, at least in principle, accepted the Senate's recommendations in all areas. That is in regard to not only English as a second language but also Aboriginal languages and all manner of community languages in the various States, and languages that are taught for business and scholarly reasons. However, the Government is unable to demonstrate that it is maintaining even the ESL program in real terms, and it is failing to give adequate financial assistance to the implementation of the national language policy. That is a serious weakness in this Government's performance.

The policy is well understood. The Government says that it gives assent to that policy. We have heard a number of outstanding speeches, even by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, about the need for the language resources of this country to be improved, with regard to familiarity and competence not only in Asian languages but in all languages that are taught at the primary, secondary and tertiary levels in this country, particularly for applied business purposes. I do not wish this Committee to overlook the fact that we have a continuing problem with this Government: its performance does not live up to its rhetoric. I am still looking for some runs on the board, some actual performance flowing from the implementation of the national language policy, from adequate provision for English as a second language programs, from the implementation of the findings of the Asian Studies Council and the Language Policy Advisory Council, and from Ministers taking note of the fact that there is not sufficient substance in the Government's financial commitment to resources to live up to the high aspirations that have been expressed.

The other matter I refer to is the effect on postgraduate students in our higher educational institutions of the higher education contribution scheme, widely known as the graduate tax. The Hawke Labor Government introduced a new requirement for Australian students to contribute $1,800 on a deferred tax liability basis for one year's study in a higher educational institution. That tuition fee falls on undergraduate and postgraduate students alike, except for some 15,000 exemptions. There are about 300,000 students, so it is a very small minority that is exempt from the graduate tax. I have before me, provided in answer to a question that I asked in Estimates Committee C, a table setting out the exemptions with regard to the graduate tax applying to various postgraduate students. The total number of postgraduate students who are exempt is only 14,299, compared to 63,086 students actually enrolled as postgraduate students. It is an expressed concern by higher education institutions, by the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and, indeed, by the students themselves that students need to be relieved of this penalty.

Up to this point, the Government has deferred any real decision on the matter by saying that the full evaluation of the graduate tax scheme will not be in the Government's hands until next February. There is a study being undertaken with regard to the experience through the 1989 year, and I understand that the thoroughness of that complete study will be sufficient for policy decisions to be made and adjustments to the scheme implemented. I want to lament on behalf of higher education institutions and students that this has been far too slow a way to respond to the actual burden that postgraduate students have felt because of the graduate tax.

I think that the solution is going to be the election of a coalition government so that the policy can be implemented whereby a quarter of all students will be exempt from any tuition fees, whether of the deferred kind or of the up-front payment kind. The Liberal and National parties have adopted a policy that the graduate tax system will be abolished completely and that in its place students-that is, only three-quarters of the students-will be required to make a payment that amounts to only two-thirds of the amount that the Labor Government is requiring of them. But the particular genius that relates to postgraduate students in the Liberal-National Party policy is that a quarter of all students will be entirely exempt and the decisions as to which particular students will be exempt will lie in the hands of the institutions themselves. So a quarter of all students in any university, institute of technology or college of advanced education will be exempt on the basis of decisions made by that institution itself. It is entirely competent for a university or college to say that all honours year and postgraduate students will be exempt from the already reduced coalition requirement for making a student contribution.

I note that there is real tension in the present system with regard to postgraduate students-and, indeed, some other groups of students-and that there does need to be relief. Certainly, if we sit next year in February, March and April, those of us on the coalition side of the Senate will be very vigilant as to what the Government will be doing to make adjustments to ensure that the burden on postgraduate students is not excessive. If there is no decision, if only the status quo continues in those months, then it will be clear that the only relief in this matter, as in a wide number of areas in education, will be the election of a coalition government and the quite comprehensively different approach which will lead to less burden on students following the election of a Liberal-National Party government.
There is one other matter that I wish to refer to, and perhaps one of my colleagues will intervene so that I can speak for a few minutes longer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intervene briefly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The final matter I wish to refer to is the amount of money in recurrent grants paid to all higher education institutions expressed in terms of the amount of money per equivalent full time student unit (EFTSU). It is well understood that our higher education institutions enrol many full time students, a lesser number of part time students and even some external students. But if the proportion of a year's work that is appropriate for each enrolment is added up in terms of what those student numbers would be were there to be equivalent full time students, we can get a genuine measure of the actual total effect of enrolments in any one institution and, when the recurrent grant of money from the Commonwealth to a particular university or college is divided into the number of equivalent full time students, we have a standard rate that can be understood in any one year or in any particular institution. So the funding per EFTSU is a well-understood standard measure.

SPEECH.PARA: My question in the Estimates Committee last month, to which I have only just received the answer, set out what that operating fund per EFTSU has been in recent years. In 1983, the figure was $9,320 per equivalent full time student unit. In the second year of the Hawke Labor Government, that amount fell in real terms to $9,180. All these figures I am discussing now are expressed in December 1988 prices, so they are expressed in real terms. Therefore, there is an ability for us to compare purchasing power, or the actual facilities or services that can be given to students with this money. So in the first year of the Hawke Labor Government the figure was at its peak of $9,320. In the second year, it fell to $9,180; in the third year, it fell to $9,160; in the fourth year, 1986, it fell to $9,000; in the fifth year, 1987, it fell to $8,850; in the sixth year, 1988, it fell again, to $8,520; and this year, it fell to $8,430. So in every year of the Hawke Labor Government the amount of money per student in higher education has fallen. It has constantly fallen; there have not been any exceptions.

This is the first time, I think, that this table has been made public. I wanted to highlight it because in many ways higher education institutions have brought to my attention the fact that they are feeling more and more squeezed because they have to do more and more with less and less money. The Government has camouflaged the fact that there has been a massive unmet demand during all of those years. Students have been turned away from our higher education institutions. Those students had the qualifications to enrol but places did not exist for them. Because of that enormous pressure, a large priority in the last six or seven years has been trying to meet that unmet demand.

I must note, favourably, that the Government has increased the number of students who can be enrolled in our higher education institutions. Let me quickly add that the coalition fully supports the increase in numbers and has made it clear that during the present triennium-1989-1990-1991-it will at least match the funding currently provided in the triennial plan. Recently the 1992 year was added and a financial commitment was given for a rolling triennium to the 1992 year. Recently the coalition, in its tax and expenditure policy statement, committed itself to at least the level of funding that the Government has indicated for the 1992 year. Students and staff involved in higher education know that, whether the present Government or, more likely, a coalition government is in power next year, the same number of funded places will be provided; so that is not a matter of contention. However, the record that is clearly before us is of falling dollars per student in every year of the Labor Government.

I need to note one more matter before I finish. The coalition's policy is not limited to providing for those funded places. As I have outlined before, one-quarter of those funded places will be completely exempt from the payment of any tuition fee. Not only will those students be exempted from the payment of the graduate tax, but also the other three-quarters of the students will face the much lower burden that the coalition will be introducing.

Another innovation which is significant with regard to unmet demand is that the coalition will allow all of our higher education institutions to enrol, beyond those funded places, any number of students on whatever basis the institutions think fit. Overseas students can come to this country to gain higher education-and there is no ceiling on numbers because it is required that the places provided for overseas students be fully funded by those students. The fees paid by overseas students under this program must cover all of the costs of their enrolment. So there is a marketplace, if you like, for anyone who lives outside Australia to go to any Australian higher education institution and say, `I have the qualifications to enrol for this course, this degree, or this postgraduate study, and I have the money to pay for it. Tell me the fee and I can enrol'. So everybody is happy. But an Australian citizen or resident cannot do that. The answer given to a student who goes to the university or college of his choice is, `Yes, we acknowledge that you have the qualifications and we acknowledge that you are prepared to pay; but, sorry, the Hawke Labor Government has said that there is a ceiling, a limit, on the number of places in higher education institutions and that limit is determined only by what the Budget can allow in terms of fully funded places'.

The coalition wants to open that door and provide an opportunity that will really test unmet demand in this country so that everyone can be told. `If you are in the first 400,000 students'-both school leavers and mature age students-`and if, on academic merit alone, you win one of the places that are fully funded by the Commonwealth, good luck to you, you have full admission and the cost will be either zero, if you are in the quarter of students who are exempt from paying fees, or an amount that is lower than the graduate tax for the other three-quarters. In addition, if you do not fall into one of those categories, you can still enrol and pay your way'. The Commonwealth Government would not be involved in determining the rules or the level of fees. Let the institutions enrol students on whatever grounds they wish and on whatever basis they wish.

The answers that are before this Committee that were given to questions put to the Department of Employment, Education and Training in these matters make it abundantly clear that there are still significant failures under the Labor Government which will be remedied only when there is a change of government next year.

I would welcome any response that the Minister wishes to give to these several matters I have raised. I would take his silence to mean that the country can continue to lament the state of higher education in these respects and others until there is a change of government.

SPEECH.PARA: I see that the Minister is now coming into the chamber and I wish publicly to thank him for the way in which he allowed the debate and the questioning on his Department's estimates in particular-and the other departments where he was involved as well-to proceed. Having said that, the comments that I want to make follow up some of the points made in the course of the Estimates Committee debate. I must say that in that latter context I was surprised that the Minister was not prepared to advise me as to the names of the members of the Multicultural Affairs Advisory Board who were not yet Australian citizens. He did admit that the question of Australian citizenship is a matter of public record. I must say that I could not quite understand-and I still do not-the Minister's sensitivity about refusing to answer that question. He may wish to comment on that later on.

Firstly, I would like to ask the Minister in relation to the regulations to accompany the new Act, which, as I understand it, are to be proclaimed by 19 December. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —On the first question, it is true that when one becomes an Australian citizen, it is on the public record, but what we do not do is publish names of people who are not Australian citizens. When a person becomes an elector, that is on the public record. I do not publish a list of names of persons who are not on the electoral roll. The Privacy Act is a lot different now because there are more constraints placed on us than two years ago when a previous question was answered along those lines. Like an umpire who is involved in an lbw decision, I erred in favour of the client on this occasion. I do not think that I have anything in particular to hide in this regard. I do not have any embarrassment that one member may not be an Australian citizen and I do not know the circumstances surrounding all that. That is the reason for it.
—You still feel that way, do you? Do you still stick with that approach? In other words, you still won't announce it.

—That is correct. The second more general question regards the regulations. I am somewhat constrained in what I can say about this because the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations is looking at it over this period, although not in an official way today, because last night the honourable senator's Party refused the Committee permission to meet today and tomorrow. The general philosophy was to have immigration criteria become law. Rather than as a policy directive from Ministers that can change from day to day with no supervision from Parliament, it was decided to transcribe all those entry criteria and other technical matters into regulations that will have the force of law. It was decided not to put them in legislation, and I think those involved in the process of reviewing the regulations now can see that that was a correct process, because it is much easier to change a regulation if it is found to be flawed than it is to change legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of discussions we agreed on a timetable to get these regulations ready. Indeed, one of the timetables placed on us was by this Senate via Senator Macklin's motion in that the latest point in which we could proclaim this new legislation was 19 December. I would have to say that this put an enormous amount of pressure on the drafting process by the time the instructions were drawn up and the first drafts done. But we managed to meet at least the timetable set, and since 31 October the Joint Select Committee has been examining the regulations in detail and, I understand, having preliminary discussions as to issues before it, looking at instructions, et cetera. The Committee has been working very hard on those regulations.

The following process is likely to occur: that Committee was obliged to report to me on 21 November, which was yesterday. It found that process too difficult and I said that it could certainly have another couple of weeks. At the latest I will receive its observations on 2 December. Between 2 December and 10 December I will be amending some regulations in accordance with the recommendations of that Committee. That is the latest I can take it to the printer. On 19 December I will also be indicating that other observations made by that Committee will see changes in the regulations probably in February, and I will also indicate what regulations I will not change.

The process then is that the Committee will report to the Parliament, and I would think at some stage we would then have to have a formal response to that Committee. However, I am making it very, very clear to everyone that there is no great proprietary interest in a particular way a regulation is drawn up and that we will be flexible in terms of responding to whatever difficulties crop up. I have to stress that this is a very major exercise. There will be flaws there; flaws that I or my Department have not picked up. Even the honoured Committee looking at it now will probably miss some. Therefore, governments have to remain flexible to change the regulations to suit.

I want to say one other thing: day by day this move has proved to be absolutely essential because of court interference in immigration areas based on an archaic and outdated Act and, if the current situation that both governments have let go over the last 30 years were to continue, there would be an unworkable immigration system; a system that is run by the courts. That has never been the intention of the Australian people or this Parliament.

That is a general summary of where we are heading with the regulations. Again I stress that the key date is when the Committee reports to me with its observations; the next key date is when I gazette the regulations; the next key date is when the Committee actually reports to this Parliament; and the next key date is when I respond to that report. I wish to put on record my absolute admiration for those members of the Committee who have gone through regulations that are four, five or even more inches thick. They are very complex. Plain English and the courts unfortunately still do not mix and we have to nail down absolutely everything. The members of the Committee have shown dedication over and above the normal dedication that is expected of them to plough through those regulations. They are under enormous time constraints to get their remarks to me so that we can react accordingly. Overall it has not been a bad process, considering where we may have been last May with a total stand-off.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for those responses and endorse his comments on the work of the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations, of which my colleague Senator Teague is an important member. I notice he is rushing off with his bundle of regulations to go and do battle on the next draft.
—Nothing official is happening at the moment, otherwise we are in breach of Senate Standing Orders.

—I note in passing the Minister's comments on the importance and the value of the procedures that are being followed, and I note for the record that it was as a result of the concerns that we on this side of the chamber had about the process by which these regulations and the introduction of the new policy proposals was being pursued that led to the establishment of the Select Committee. I am glad that we have a bipartisan view on the success of that Committee.
—I suspect that if either of us had 39 votes we may have taken a different view.
—I think I will let that one go over my shoulder. As I understand it, the regulations will be proclaimed on 19 December and apply from 15 December.
—No, they will apply from one minute past midnight on the nineteenth.

—That difference does not affect the question I intended to ask, which was that, given the fundamental change in the procedures that will be adopted-I know we had some discussion on this in the Estimates Committee but the Minister may have made further progress since then-it obviously will be essential that there be as much widespread dissemination of the new procedures, rules and regulations as possible. How is the Minister progressing in terms of the development of a program to implement that dissemination of information? Where does that stand? Has a timetable been programmed for it? What sort of costs are involved?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —What has to be distinguished between are procedures and policy. The policy was announced last December and it has been fairly widely disseminated. It is that which I am more anxious to get out to the general clientele, although these days immigration tends to be something that one does not have to go out and sell; it is something that people make intensive inquiries about. The $5 package available at our embassies and consulates throughout the world contains all the necessary information on entry criteria.

SPEECH.PARA: We will also be producing two major manuals for the use of our own officers, and no doubt they will be widely used by a lot of other people in the community. I do not plan a specific publicity campaign-that is, a paid publicity campaign-surrounding these matters. For a start, some of them are too complex but also I have found, at least in immigration matters, that word of mouth gets the message as to what is contained in the rules and regulations around very quickly. However, I think it is also true to state that, given the complexity of those rules and regulations, some of the advisory groups around the country will find increased pressure applied to them. I am talking about grant-in-aid workers, migrant resource centres, migrant workers rights offices and the other community organisations which will be expected to provide a lot of advice, as will our regional offices in Melbourne and Sydney and our central offices in the other States. However, I do not see a role for a sort of classic government advertising campaign in this regard, because the actual policy has been on the record for almost 12 months, and I think it is reasonably well understood by the community.

The specific manuals to assist officers and others have been developed in a fairly competent way. One is called the care aggregate module and the other is the standard aggregate module. I think it will be necessary to make sure that early in the new year we conduct major seminars for electorate staff to bring them all into gear on the new changes. We need those sorts of things, but I do not think we need television or newspaper advertising at this stage. Over the next few weeks I think it will be necessary for a couple of press announcements by me. It would be unfair to any illegal immigrants to this country-even though they do not have any rights-to not tell them of these changes; it would be far better to tell them to try to regularise their status now, or before the nineteenth, than to leave it until after that date, because after the nineteenth mandatory deportation will apply. So, if people have strong reasons for believing that they could be allowed to stay here, for goodness sake, they should try to regularise their status now.

I hope those sorts of announcements will convey to the public as much as possible about those sorts of details. Of course, such things do not always get coverage; but I am sure honourable senators would have already seen the appearance in newspapers of advertisements by immigration solicitors pointing out this very fact. All right, I suppose they are after a buck, but they are also letting people know that the rules for illegal immigrants following 19 December will be much, much tougher, much less discretionary and much more likely to cause someone to have to leave this country than the laws of the previous Immigration Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation involving illegal immigrants and those who have overstayed their visas changes fundamentally on 19 December. The Minister mentioned that immigration lawyers have been placing advertisements in the press. What is the Minister's Department doing to publicise that issue as well? I ask that because it involves 70,000 or 80,000 people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot tell the honourable senator how many people are involved at the moment, because the last time an analysis on illegal immigrants was done there was a big dive in the figures. Before I proclaim that to the world as a marvellous achievement by me or something else, I will have the computer print-out and a few other things checked. I will also have some analysis done on whether or not the number of illegal immigrants in the country is seasonal. So I will not jump into that.

SPEECH.PARA: My Department would prefer to do it by way of ministerial statements here, there and everywhere and to gain publicity in that way. By the way, we are not bound to advertise that fact, but we are also not trying to cover it up. I will not be surprised if next week I am asked a question on this subject during Question Time, which will help to get the message out to illegal immigrants that, if they want to regularise their status, they would be much better to do it now by lodging an application under the current law than waiting until post-19 December. But I do not see any need for a special advertising campaign to that effect. Again, it is surprising how quickly all these things get around by word of mouth in the immigration area.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to follow up a subject that was discussed in the Estimates Committee about the entry of foreign pilots. I draw attention to the fact that the Committee met quite a few weeks ago and the matter has probably progressed since then. At that stage-I think it was on 28 September-Estimates Committee E was told that the foreign pilots who were coming to Australia under temporary permits were to use the Victorian State director as the contact point for facilitating rapid entry under those permits. In view of the considerable expressions of concern that have been voiced in the weeks since this issue was discussed in the Estimates Committee hearing, including of course the establishment by the Senate of a select committee on air safety, have any changes been made in terms of the processing and handling of foreign pilot entry permits? In other words, has any account been taken of the concerns that have been expressed about the safety issue? I refer in particular to the allegations that have been made that at least some of the foreign pilots have little proficiency in English and are having difficulty understanding the navigational and air traffic instructions and directions, et cetera. I would like to know what has been done about, or what account, if any, has been taken of the concerns and developments since 28 September.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not accept the premise on which the honourable senator asked the question, even though he qualified it by saying, `it is being said'. I do not think it necessarily follows that it is the job of immigration officers to determine the competency of pilots. I do not mean that that is not our job, but a variety of Civil Aviation Authority criteria determine that matter. As the honourable senator says, a parliamentary committee is now inquiring into those matters. From an immigration point of view, we have to be satisfied as to the general qualifications of a pilot. I do not think the honourable senator would suggest that we should decide whether or not pilots are competent to fly in Australia. The point is that if anyone is to receive a temporary entry permit to work in Australia but cannot obtain work, I suggest that he will not stay here for very long.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard allegations from both sides of the quality of overseas pilots who have come here to work. I will be interested to hear what the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations says. From my point of view, I cannot make a judgment on the matter. I have not seen any evidence produced at Estimates Committee B or anywhere else in this chamber to suggest that any of these pilots are incompetent. I have not heard one shred of evidence to cause me concern in this regard. I cannot say without reservation that every pilot coming here is perfect, just as I cannot say that every doctor we bring into the country is perfect. I do not expect my overseas officers to evaluate the competency of pilots, just as they do not undertake such an evaluation in relation to doctors or any other profession. Obviously, before those professionals come to this country, they must be qualified. I am not aware of any changes having been made since 28 September. I cannot assure the honourable senator that none has been made, but at this stage none has been brought to my attention. My departmental officers will be happy to assist the Senate Select Committee at any time in relation to any of these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to a situation where a pilot flew from Cocos Island to Christmas Island to Singapore and then returned the other way. The pilot concerned crashed a Skybus, I think it was, at the Paris Air Show. At the time the pilot was flying particularly low and the computer interpreted this to mean that the plane wanted to land. By the time the pilot disengaged the computer, it was too late and I believe that 90 lives were lost. That person is now flying an Australian registered plane. Does the Minister's Department investigate issues of pilots who have lost their licences in other nations and who come to Australia?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that that job would be impossible. One cannot really turn overseas immigration officers, who are the initial contact point, into aviation experts. That is why we have the Civil Aviation Authority. That person could not fly in Australia unless the Civil Aviation Authority deemed him to be a competent pilot. I am familiar with the air crash to which the honourable senator refers; it occurred at the Paris Air Show, I think it was two years ago, and the accident was televised. I am not aware of the full circumstances or for how long the licence was suspended, but the pilot's competency to fly in Australia in not an immigration matter. If such people enter Australia under temporary permits and are not permitted to fly here, then they would go somewhere else in the world. Our job has been-and we are entitled to do this-to bring pilots into this country because there is an occupational shortage in that area. Job vacancies must be filled.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation might have been different if the pilots had gone on strike rather than resigning. We might have had a different approach. However, they did resign and 1,200 airline jobs had to be filled, some of them from overseas. It is not unusual to fill skill gaps from overseas; we do that all the time. This situation is no different from any other case. The matters the honourable senator raises really relate to the Civil Aviation Authority; they are not immigration matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —To a point.

—Not even to a point. We do not conduct the tests. When a doctor enters Australia, we do not sit down and test him. Procedures exist in this country whereby doctors are tested to establish whether they can be registered. My Department is not involved in that process. Obviously, if there is a surplus of professionals in that area, my Department does not encourage them to migrate to Australia. For example, at the moment we do not encourage doctors to migrate to Australia; we do not put any great premium on them. I think the matter raised by the honourable senator is a Civil Aviation Authority matter rather than an immigration matter.

SPEECH.PARA: We will always have this propaganda from the Australian Federation of Air Pilots that the scum of the earth is coming to Australia to fly aeroplanes. It must do more than just make the allegation. It must present some sort of proof and evidence, but in general it has not been able to do that. I am not suggesting that everyone on all sides of the argument is blameless: many assertions have been made in this dispute but not much evidence has been produced. I suspect that many bogus statements have been made by both the airlines and the pilots. It is now a rhetorical or a polemical war, it is no longer a reasoned debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not totally clear as to the relationship between the Minister's Department and the Civil Aviation Authority in terms of handling temporary pilot applications. Is it the situation that the Minister rubber stamps what the Civil Aviation Authority may decree in terms of the suitability or otherwise of an applicant, or does his Department have a decision-making role to play in the exercise? How does the process work?

SPEECH.PARA: For example, if the Civil Aviation Authority deems that a pilot is suitable, does the Department test his competency in English, which I suppose would be the most obvious criterion? Obviously his Department is competent to judge that aspect whereas it would not be competent to judge some of the other technical aspects in relation to a pilot's competency. What is the relationship and what determining role does the Minister's Department play?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Civil Aviation Authority is not really involved in the process at that stage; rather, it becomes involved at a later stage. It really involves the employer, who comes to us and says that it has recruited a certain pilot who is suitable and properly qualified to come to Australia. That pilot is then given a temporary entry permit and comes to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it, before the pilot flies he must be certified as to his competency to fly. It is not really a matter of our relationship with the Civil Aviation Authority. We would have a concern only if the employers approached us and obtained temporary entry permits for people who were not able to fly in this country. Obviously, that would breach the spirit of our immigration laws, because those people who were brought into this country on the basis of their supposed ability and competency to fly could not do so. That would be our interest in the matter, but again it is up to the employer.

I do not think that an employer would try to employ someone to fly in Australia if he could not speak English and, if it did, the Civil Aviation Authority would not certify the pilot as being competent to fly. It is really a matter of the employer's relationship with my Department. The same situation would occur if a hospital wanted to employ a certain doctor in the western suburbs because of a shortage of doctors. The hospital would come to us and say, `There is a shortage. We have advertised the position but cannot fill it, so on either a temporary entry or migrant basis we want to bring in Dr X'. We would then allow Dr X to enter the country, but his competency within Australia would be determined by a fairly complex procedure involving the Australian Medical Association and other organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: —What the Minister is saying is that a foreign pilot can come into Australia and get a temporary entry permit which presumably lasts for up to 12 months before the civil aviation regulatory and testing authorities in this country have even looked at that pilot. If there is pressure on the airlines to find pilots, obviously there is a likelihood that they will try to find them as best they can. I do not find the Minister's doctor analogy a real one. I find it strange that we are letting foreign pilots into this country on a temporary entry permit which lets them stay here for a given period before the authorities have certified-using the Minister's word-that they are competent. Surely it ought to be the other way around.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know how Senator Short expects them to arrive in Australia to be tested unless I give them a temporary entry permit. I will not give them a visitor's permit where they sign that the only reason they are coming here as a visitor is for a holiday or something else and have them breach it. It must be done by way of a temporary entry permit. Senator Short's argument would have a lot more force if he could produce a list of the pilots who have come here from overseas who have been rejected by the Civil Aviation Authority.
—It is a matter of principle though.

—I do not quite understand why it is a matter of principle. How do those people get tested in this country? How do they get into the country to be tested? The reality is that, if they fail their test, inevitably they leave the country. We do not have an overstay problem with the temporary entry permits for those people. It is not as though it is a backdoor way into Australia. Senator Short would have to acknowledge that the airlines are not likely to bring too many pilots who cannot qualify out here. That would waste their own time and an enormous amount of money. The standards are set by the Civil Aviation Authority, not the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Senator Short talks about a hypothetical matter of principle. I worry whether any practical problems are associated with this at the moment. I have not seen any.

—When I used the word `principle' I meant the principle of the pattern of procedures to be followed. It seems to me that, as a matter of principle, it would make more sense to know before a person is given a permit to stay in Australia for a period of between six and 12 months that the regulatory authorities in this country certify him to be competent for the purposes for which he is coming into the country. I guess that is a point on which we might have to agree to disagree. Does the Minister have details on the number of foreign pilots who have been granted temporary permits?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
