SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I do not, but I have no reason not to take that question on notice and write to the honourable senator as soon as the figures can be established. The figures will probably have to be in two categories: those who have been authorised for temporary entry permits (TEPs) and those who have actually arrived. Taking up Senator Short's other point, there is a difference between principles in migration and temporary entry in as much as I can cancel a temporary entry permit at any time. Therefore if someone who has come here does not qualify, it does not mean that that person can have a 10-month holiday on the beach on a TEP. I can cancel the permit at any time. I have not seen the figures as to how many pilots have been given TEPs. I assume they exist somewhere in my Department. I will ask the officers to get them to Senator Short as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ray may have given a partial answer to my question in the hearing of the Estimates committee. It concerns the proposed revision of the Australian Citizenship Act. The Minister at least will be aware that I have made representations to him and to his predecessors over some years concerning an anomaly whereby the daughters and sons of certain Australian women who were married in a brief period before 1948 do not have Australian citizenship, whereas the children of Australian men who were married in the same period do have Australian citizenship. That is the essence of the problem. It arose because an attempt was made to correct a situation with some amending legislation recently which still excluded this small group of people against whom there has been discrimination on the grounds of their gender.

SPEECH.PARA: I have raised with the Minister the particular problem of Dr Geraldine Room who finds herself in this situation. Those of us who went through the University of Sydney will know that Professor Room, who was a professor of mathematics, fought in the Australian Imperial Force and married an Australian woman but was a British citizen. Geraldine was born during a brief period while they were out of Australia on sabbatical leave. Her birth was registered at an Australian consulate but, because she had not been born in Australia and because her mother was Australian but her father was not, she has now been informed that she is not an Australian citizen. Apparently this arises because of an anomaly in the Act. I suggested to the Minister that a small number of people must be caught by the anomaly. The Minister has indicated, I thought quite graciously, that he will try to have it included in a revision of the Citizenship Act.

The problem becomes more urgent because Dr Room is having a child and is keen to establish her Australian citizenship. At present she lives in England. I ask the Minister for some assessment of when this amendment will come to pass because I keep telling my constituents, in response to their representations, that we hope it will be soon. I understand the Minister says that he wants to get a comprehensive review of the Act under way and that this might be only one of a number of matters to be covered, but the question of timing does concern me. What information can the Minister give to the Committee that might assist me in giving further information to my constituents?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter has been raised by Senator Baume on a few occasions. I indicated to him last time that I thought that a more extensive review of the Australian Citizenship Act should be undertaken and it has been undertaken. I do not think that instructions have yet been given to the draftsman, but that is not unusual. We have until 10 February to do that. I expect that the legislation will come up in the autumn session. However, I cannot give Senator Baume any guarantees of passage because I do not know how many Bills will pass this chamber and I do not know when the election will be, which will obviously impact on any autumn sittings. So it may not come up until the spring session.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I signed a letter to Senator Baume's colleague, Mr Ruddock, which is not in any sense a private letter. I was asked what we contemplated doing in this area. The first item listed happened to be Senator Baume's item. Maybe his colleague would like to share that letter with him when it arrives in a day or two. We indicate in that letter what we intend to do with regard to that and other matters relating to the Citizenship Act. It may be dealt with in the autumn session. That does not necessarily help the person involved. I am sure that if the Bill, when it comes up, does not cover it, I will be able to rely on Senator Baume for an ingenious amendment that will do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for some elaboration as to what may have happened since we considered these matters on 28 September regarding the changes that are being made to the special humanitarian program particularly in relation to the Lebanese. I understand that the changes that have been announced are about an extension of three months to six months under the relevant part of the process, that claims will be able to be processed in Australia and that there will be a slightly more relaxed attitude towards Lebanese changing status in Australia if they come from Beirut or fighting areas. That is the essence of the changes, as I understand them.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), as I understand it, stated just in advance of the decisions on the special humanitarian program changes being announced that another 1,000 places would be made available for Lebanese migrants. That is something that we would greatly welcome. We have all been very moved by the representations we have all had on both sides of the Parliament from Chouf Coast refugees. They are a slightly different kettle of fish from refugees from Beirut itself; nevertheless they are Lebanese with a very important cause.

The Prime Minister, as I understand it, stated that he thought that another 1,000 places would be made available. When we debated this in the Estimates committee the Minister said that he was not confident that the changes would deliver 1,000 places and that the Government was never committed to doing so, but it was just to investigate the possibility. Can the Minister say anything further on this matter? Have there been any further developments since the end of September? I know that this is a matter of considerable concern and interest to the Lebanese community and it would be appreciated if the Minister could add anything. In particular, I am concerned that there may be confusion, particularly in the minds of those in the Lebanese community, as to whether there will really be 1,000 additional places.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly Senator Short has added to the confusion today. Let me put the record straight so that he can never again inadvertently misrepresent the position of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The Prime Minister was asked a question in the House of Representatives. He very carefully replied that he had asked me to examine whether methods were available to us to increase the intake by up to 1,000 places. No-one ever said that there would be an extra 1,000 places. In all fairness to the Prime Minister and anyone else, no-one has ever said that. The Prime Minister asked whether we could look at ways of loosening the criteria to make up another 1,000 places. It is very unfair to the Prime Minister to claim that he said that there would be an extra 1,000 places. I have checked Hansard on previous occasions just to make sure that the point I have now made is accurate, and it is.

SPEECH.PARA: Ironically, my biggest problem is that I do not think that this year 1,000 people will apply under the special humanitarian program, let alone qualify. I have serious doubts as to whether 1,000 people from Lebanon will even apply. Lebanon is really three zones at the moment: the north, which is very stable; the area around Beirut, which has been absolutely dreadful; and the south, which is very stable. Many of the representations Senator Short and I get are from people in the north and south who want to come to Australia even though there is no fighting at all in those zones. Of course, the fighting in Beirut has eased. One of the other things we have to take into account is that the population in Beirut has declined massively. I think it is 250,000. It will surprise Senator Short that some 12,000 Australian citizens live in Lebanon at the moment, mostly in Beirut. That figure of 12,000 has surprised me. I found it staggering but apparently it is correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are they doing there?

—They are running businesses. Coming back to Senator Short's point, a new chief migration officer has gone to Damascus. He has not been there long, but he also is looking at the interpretation of the new guidelines. I think he will come back with some suggestions, based on his experience on the ground of how we can broaden this program. I would also like to stress that Lebanon is virtually the only country that has a special humanitarian program. Many other Australian citizens would like a similar program for their own home country, but I do not think it is possible to have a special humanitarian program for every potential country. There is no question that, given the 15 years of internecine warfare in Lebanon, this is a deserved program for Lebanon.

SPEECH.PARA: I have alluded to the major problem that worries me, and that is, in trying to help the extra people involved, whether enough will apply. It is still difficult to get to Damascus from Nicosia for interview. There are enormous communication difficulties within Lebanon for people here trying to get in touch with relatives there. We also have an enormous problem with forgeries in this area. Even though the special humanitarian program has tended to decline over the years in terms of numbers delivered, we should also look at the figures which show that Lebanon still remains in the top 10 source countries for Australian immigrants, especially in the preferential family area. Up to about 3,000 Lebanese a year come to Australia.

Senator Short has asked me what changes have occurred since September. The program will at least treble over last year's figure, and that is at a minimum. Nevertheless, I would like to see it further expanded. I will be very interested to hear from, if you like, `my man in Damascus' as to how he thinks the program is operating, whether it needs to be modified further and whether the criteria need to be loosened. I can assure Senator Short that I will keep a weather eye on this matter on a daily basis, rather than reviewing it every couple of months, to make sure that it is working adequately.

Senator Short has referred to the sorts of representations made to him. I think we have all experienced those representations. It would be inhuman not to respond to them and not to feel an enormous tug when some of those stories are told. Many people are put through immense hardship. I hope that we can deliver 1,000 extra places this year in the program, but I cannot guarantee it. If people do not apply, they cannot come here. Honourable senators know of the Italian syndrome in regard to migration. The Italians complain that no-one comes, but no-one applies. When they do, their success rate is enormously high. We will just have to see how the situation develops. I will keep in contact with various Lebanese communities around Australia and hear their views. Later this afternoon some Lebanese will be involved in a tree planting at Parliament House. Many of their representatives will probably make points to Senator Short and me and others. Senator Short is looking blank; perhaps he has not been invited. I invite him to come out at 3.30 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his response and for the invitation, which I hope to take up. Will the relaxation of the special humanitarian program apply only to people in Beirut and the war area?
—Essentially.

—It is true that large parts of the Lebanon, as Senator Robert Ray has said, are not in a war situation, but I think a reasonable case can be made that many people living in areas which are not at the moment classified as a war zone are suffering very difficult conditions occasioned by the events of the last 15 years and the war itself. Will the Minister's man in Damascus be looking in his review at the possibility of extending the net of potential applicants to outside the Beirut war zone area?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is nothing to prevent people in those areas applying under the special humanitarian program if they can substantiate their case, but the specific reference to the destruction of one's home is only going to happen in the war areas, I think we would agree. I hope I have not conveyed the impression that the senior migration officer in Damascus is holding an official inquiry into this. Just through the cable traffic I have noted that he will have some further suggestions to make. He is not doing an official inquiry into how it is going, so I would not like the Senate to be misled in any way. People living in either the north or the south are not disqualified under the criteria, but in one sense it is helpful to them if their residence has been destroyed. That is less likely to occur in places other than Beirut at the moment. That is the almost automatic accepter. People can still qualify under the special humanitarian program whether they are from the north or the south, depending on the circumstances.

—If people from the north or the south zone can apply, I am surprised to hear the Minister say that he doubts that there will be the number of applicants to fill the places we have available for this year. Why does the Minister think there will be a paucity of applicants?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I base it on applications from 1 July through to the current period. Off the top of my head, I cannot tell Senator Short what those numbers are. I think only a couple of hundred are involved, but I do not have the figures immediately available.
—From the whole of Lebanon?

—That is the number under the special humanitarian program. I also look at the backlog of cases to see how many there are because I often hear accusations about backlogs. Sometimes they are the smallest in the world. I will try to get the figures from 1 July to 1 November and supply them to Senator Short for him to look at. I will take that part on notice and write to him about it.

—The question of the location of the migration office in Lebanon has been one of ongoing discussions for a long time. The move from Beirut to Damascus has been discussed. Some members of the Lebanese community have pushed for the Beirut office to be reopened. Obviously, at this stage there are good reasons why that would be difficult, but has the Minister or his Department looked at the possibility of having the migration office located somewhere in Lebanon, but outside Beirut? The reason I ask that question is obvious. The road to Damascus is a very difficult one physically; it is also very difficult for many Lebanese to bring themselves to travel to Damascus for a variety of reasons. I understand that the office was moved from Beirut purely for safety and security reasons. Has any thought been given to the possibility of locating it in another part of Lebanon so that it could be more accessible to many applicants?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I might surprise Senator Short when I say that I have not been put under much pressure to reopen a migration office in Beirut. Most representatives of the Lebanese community would like a symbolic representation by Foreign Affairs in Beirut. They no longer suggest a migration office there because it represents queues and danger. The real problem with moving the migration office anywhere else in Lebanon is whether it would be under Syrian or Israeli control. What is the justice in that? That is the difficulty. Many Lebanese say that they do not want the office under Syrian or Israeli control because to put it outside Beirut reflects on their sovereignty. To put it where foreign forces are involved would be an insult to Lebanon itself. I know that Senator Short did not mean that. He is just looking for a practical solution to the travel problems. He will find that many Lebanese in Australia are vehemently opposed to the migration office being set up in Tripoli or Sidon. I have not looked at it, but I would be happy to do so. However, those sorts of problems are insurmountable. We have made the Nicosia option as available as possible which helps at least those in certain parts of Beirut when the ferries are running. I would love a quick and simple solution, but there are complications everywhere one turns.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce been drawn to the numerous television, radio and press comments by Mr Bosch, Chairman of the National Companies and Securities Commission, particularly those relevant to the operations and financial situation of a Mr Skase and his companies? Does the Minister consider the judgmental comments made by Mr Bosch to be appropriate off-the-cuff decisions? Has any caution been given to Mr Bosch either to not comment at all or to do so in a more temperate manner, or at least in a manner that could not prejudice Mr Skase's personal position and further business dealings?

—I have seen a number of comments about the Qintex situation in the paper, and in the course of reading those comments I have seen some observations by Mr Bosch. The honourable senator describes them as judgmental comments, and in answering the question I do not wish to be judgmental about Mr Bosch. After all, he has a statutory independent status. At this stage I certainly would not make any comments about that. However, I will inquire of the Attorney-General as to whether he has seen those statements and whether he has had any discussions or otherwise with Mr Bosch about them.

—My question to the Minister for Resources concerns Government support for more efficient supply and use of water around Australia. Can the Minister inform honourable senators whether recent progress has been achieved to assist research into water use under the national water research program? Can he tell us particularly what the Government proposes to spend on this program this financial year? Can he inform the Senate also what developments have taken place recently that assist activities under the country water supply improvement program, known as COWSIP, which plays such a vitally helpful role in many rural communities around Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I can answer the questions that I have been asked concerning water research. In fact today I announced the allocation of $2.8m in water research grants under the Commonwealth's national water research program. That brings the Commonwealth's allocation in 1989-90 to $6.8m and expenditure in total since 1985-86 to $24m on water research in Australia. There have been a number of applications for these funds, which indicates a considerable interest in the research community for this type of activity. The quality of the applications has been very high and the funds have been allocated with a mind to providing for the most strategic projects.

ANSWER.PARA: The projects that I have approved cover a range of research areas including salinity and integrated catchment management, the treatment of waste water and changes in water allocation, and the social and regional implications of water allocation. One of the more novel projects approved involves an allocation of funds to the Department of Conservation and Land Management in Western Australia and the Royal Australian Ornithologists Union to investigate the suitability of wetland areas for waterbirds. The type of collaboration between that organisation and the Western Australian department is the sort of thing we are looking for in encouraging these sorts of allocations.

Senator Childs also asked me about the COWSIP program, the country water supply improvement program. Earlier this month I announced grants to New South Wales and Western Australia under the COWSIP program totalling $7.2m. The New South Wales projects include provision of a reticulated supply at Tambar Springs, improved security of water at Mogo and White Cliffs, improved quality and security of supply at Binnaway and Werris Creek and improved supply at Morundah, Delungra and Bundarra. COWSIP projects for New South Wales this financial year in value amount to $1.54m, and eight projects under the COWSIP scheme have been funded this time out of the money I have allocated. A range of projects have been funded in Western Australia, including a new reticulation supply at Condingup and Yallingup, upgrading an existing scheme at Badgingarra, and improving the quality and quantity of supply at New Norcia. Western Australia has had 15 schemes funded under this project, the details of which I will release later today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Local Government. The Minister is most likely aware that the Municipal Association of Victoria (MAV) has lodged with the Federal Industrial Relations Commission an appeal against the decision to grant family day care providers award coverage. Given that the Minister has previously expressed the Government's concern over the likely cost ramifications of the decision and advised in the Senate on 6 October that the Commonwealth's position was that the carers were considered to be self-employed, can the Minister provide an assurance to councils in Victoria and Tasmania that the Federal Government will be represented at that appeal in order to assure that the Government's previously stated position is again made known? If fears of a union backlash prevent the Government from putting forward its views, is the Minister aware that the Government's absence is likely to be interpreted by the Industrial Relations Commission as support for the award decision and to place the Government, as sponsor of the family day care scheme, in a position where it is morally obliged to provide councils with the extra funding which they will require to meet wages costs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am certainly aware that this is a matter of some considerable concern to the Municipal Association of Victoria, to those who work in the family day care industry, to the Government and to the Australian Council of Trade Unions. I have said before in this place that late last year the Federated Municipal and Shire Employees Union of Australia notified a dispute with those local councils in Victoria and Tasmania which sponsor family day care schemes with a view to negotiating an award for carers. The Municipal Association of Victoria, acting on behalf of the councils of Victoria and Tasmania, has submitted an appeal against the decision based on the supposition that family day carers are self-employed as the contract for payment of child-care is between the parents and the care giver. Should the appeal by the MAV fail, the procedure by the union will be to negotiate the terms of an award, the likely content of which is as yet unknown. Until the determination of the award is known, the actual increase in the cost of providing family day care cannot be accurately assessed.

ANSWER.PARA: As the dispute at this stage is confined to local government in Victoria and Tasmania, the decision of the Industrial Relations Commission does not immediately apply to non-government sponsoring organisations and local governments in other States.

The Commonwealth Government has a strong commitment, as honourable senators know, to family day care. We will be closely monitoring the situation. I have had contact with my two ministerial colleagues for whom this is a relevant issue, Mr Peter Morris and Dr Blewett. I will be continuing to monitor the situation and I will be happy to advise Senator Calvert and the chamber in due course.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for her answer. I ask again: will the Government be represented at the hearing? If not, and if the decision comes down as it looks like it might, will the Government be providing extra funds, which it is morally obliged to do, to meet the increased wage cost?

—I thought I made it clear that this is a matter that crosses portfolio responsibilities. It crosses the portfolio responsibility of Dr Blewett in relation to child care and the portfolio responsibility of Mr Peter Morris. I am closely monitoring the situation with my ministerial colleagues and we will be in a position to provide a response in due course.

—Did the Leader of the Government in the Senate see an article in the Australian Financial Review of 17 November 1989 on the sale by Mr Alan Bond of a French impressionist painting on which he realised a capital gain of $14m? How are capital gains on French impressionist paintings currently treated for tax purposes in Australia? How would they be treated under a speculative gains tax phasing out the tax liability over five years? Is it true that the replacement of the existing capital gains tax by a speculative gains tax would stimulate investment in Australia? If so, will the Government amend the tax regime accordingly?
—Gee, you have to be desperate. You really are getting desperate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell interjects that the Government is getting desperate. I cannot think of anybody more desperate in this Parliament at present than members of the Queensland National Party. Any questions about gains of any kind, but particularly capital or speculative gains touch a raw nerve with Senator Boswell. After all, he has been up there with the paper bag merchants for years now, and they are about to get their comeuppance in the Queensland election. So, Senator Boswell would know all about governments being desperate.

ANSWER.PARA: I did see the article in the Australian Financial Review regarding the sale of Mr Bond's painting, which he acquired at Christie's in New York in 1983 for $5.07m and sold at Sotheby's in New York earlier this month for $19.05m, making a capital gain of $14m in six years. I suppose nobody begrudges Mr Bond his capital gain. Where a painting was owned by a taxpayer before the introduction of the capital gains tax, as is the case with this picture, La Promenade, the capital gain is not subject to capital gains tax because when the Government introduced the present capital gains tax it was introduced on a strictly non-retrospective basis. However, where a painting was acquired after 19 September 1985-that is the date for all intents and purposes of the introduction of the capital gains tax-at a consideration in excess of $100, that painting is listed as a personal use asset and subject to capital gains tax. The tax is levied on the gain, adjusted for inflation. If Mr Bond, or any other art collector, were to sell tomorrow a painting bought after that date and make $14m on it, such a French impressionist painting acquired in that period would be subject to capital gains tax. If the Opposition's proposed watering down of the capital gains tax were ever implemented, things would be a little different.

TALK.START.PARA: —Speculative gains.

—As Senator Panizza interjects, a so-called speculative gains tax would apply. For example, if Mr Bond held his Manet for six years, which does not seem a very long time-in this present case he held it for six hours-under the Opposition proposal he would have to hold it for only five years before capital gains tax was nullified. So, a $14m capital gain on a work of art acquired in that period would be tax-free.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Maguire asked the appropriate question as to whether the speculative gains tax and the abolition of the capital gains tax would affect investment decisions. Of course it would; it would provide an enormous incentive for wealthy people, the less than 2 per cent of Australians who pay capital gains tax, to invest in assets which yield no income whatsoever but which hold out the promise of good capital gains-that is, works of art, antiques, rare stamps and coins, real estate, and so on would not be subject to a capital gains tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Empire clocks?

—Yes, empire clocks, of course, and penthouses on the Gold Coast. That was the greatest growth industry under the Fraser Government that this country ever saw-and it will come home to roost in the Queensland election in a couple of weeks time. That is a fact. It was the biggest growth industry, and that would happen with all sorts of other things of the kind I have indicated. What that would mean is that funds would be taken away from investment in productive business assets which would improve our balance of payments.
—Rubbish!

—`Rubbish', says Senator Lewis. Look at the levels of investment in productive capacity throughout the 1970s when the Opposition was in government-an abysmal level of investment in productive capacity. It increased by no more than 2 per cent a year.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Chaney interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney now talks about resource boom investment. That was the great Liberal Party stunt of the late 1970s-Doug Anthony, Phil Lynch and other people talking up resource boom investment. Senator Chaney should remember these things. How many people got their fingers burnt in that little exercise in the late 1970s? What happened to all of that?

ANSWER.PARA: I return to the point I was making in respect of paintings and other such objects. Funds would be bitten away from investment in productive business assets. The business community knows this full well. Sensible business leaders are not too happy about this little suggestion which emanated from the bowels of the Liberal Party. That would mean less contribution to the supply of goods and services from either export or import replacement. The flow of income provided by those productive assets is taxed, and the assets depreciate ultimately to scrap value. Investors would prefer to forgo the income stream from a productive asset, under the proposal of the Liberal and National parties, for the untaxed capital gain on an unproductive asset. The Government does not intend to reintroduce that kind of distortion into the tax system. It would obviously be counterproductive to Australia's real investment needs.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Is it the case that individual employees require ministerial approval to apply to the Industrial Commission of New South Wales for a hearing on grievances or that they must do so under the auspices of a trade union, and is this not contrary to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, to which Australia is committed? Does the Minister consider this aberration to be in contravention of Australia's claim in the second report on the Covenant to the United Nations Human Rights Committee that `in all Australian jurisdictions, all persons are equal before courts and tribunals'? If the Minister does consider this to be a contradiction in the provision of basic human rights to all Australians, what steps will he take to rectify the situation? Finally, what steps will the Minister take to deal with the request for help in a similar matter brought to him two years ago by Mr John Ellenbogen of Glenbrook, New South Wales, to which Mr Ellenbogen has not yet received a reply from the Attorney-General?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McLean gave notice of this question, and I have received a response from the Attorney-General. The answers to the four parts of the question are as follows: First, I understand that section 74 of the New South Wales Industrial Arbitration Act 1940 does impose limitation on those who may commence proceedings before the New South Wales Industrial Commission. For example, in relation to most personal grievance matters, individuals require the support of a trade union or an employer or, alternatively, the matter may be referred by either the relevant New South Wales Minister or the Commission itself. However, I also understand that there are matters that can be taken directly to the Commission by an individual.

ANSWER.PARA: Second, article 14 of the International Covenant of Civil and Political Rights states that all persons shall be equal before the courts and tribunals. However, this does not mean that there cannot be preliminary procedural matters dealt with before a person comes before a court or tribunal. Third, I understand that the New South Wales Council for Civil Liberties has raised this matter with the relevant New South Wales authorities and the Attorney awaits, with interest, the views of the New South Wales Government. Fourth, in relation to Mr Ellenbogen's correspondence, I understand that the Attorney-General's office wrote to Mr Ellenbogen on 30 October 1989.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the fact that, under the provisions of section 77 of the 1940 Act in New South Wales, preliminary proceedings may preclude an individual from access to the court, does this not in fact constitute contradiction and contravention under the Covenant on Civil and Political Rights?

—I have already indicated, in the second part of my answer, the understanding of the Attorney's advisers as to the relationship between preliminary procedural matters and the rights conferred under article 14 of the International Covenant and I cannot add anything further to that.

—I ask the Minister for Resources whether he is aware of recommendations by the Victorian Department of Conservation, Forests and Lands and the Department of Agriculture and Rural Affairs in favour of growing trees on farmland. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the Commonwealth Government's attitude to this issue? Can he report any new developments regarding the tree plantation studies which are part of the south-east forests agreement between the Commonwealth Government and the New South Wales Government? Finally, can he inform the Senate of any recent developments regarding the establishment of plantations under the national afforestation program (NAP)?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like most people concerned with forestry these days, I place a high value on encouraging the growth of commercial plantations in Australia to take pressure off native forests. The Victorian Department of Conservation, Forests and Lands has announced the findings of a report entitled The Economics of Diversifying from Grazing to Pine. The thrust of that report is to recommend to the Government that it market commercially to farmers the prospect of growing pine trees on farmland as an alternative to grazing cattle and other agricultural uses of that land and thus propose to farmers a possibility of diversifying their agricultural cultivation and agricultural use of their land.

ANSWER.PARA: The recommendation, at which I have had a chance to look, is similar in type to the trees on farmland program organised in Western Australia by the Department of Conservation and Land Management in that State, which promotes hardwoods for farmers to grow on their land at a guaranteed buy-back rate from industry. It is also similar to a program announced recently by the South Australian Government, the trees for life program, which also proposes that farmers should investigate the commercial uses of this type of forestry and that there are financial benefits in it for them if they do so because of the resource needs of industry. My attitude to the Victorian proposal is to commend it and to recommend that other States look at the report and follow suit where possible.

The other part of the question Senator Zakharov asked me is about afforestation as well. On 10 November I announced grants totalling $6.5m under the national afforestation program, which is a program of the Hawke Government. It is provided to lend assistance to demonstrate the viability of plantations and to stimulate commercial investment in them. I am speaking here not about trees on farmland but about broad acre plantations and, of course, the more of that we can encourage the greater the easing of pressure on existing native forests.

My announcement on 10 November funded 28 existing projects and 22 new projects. It means that an additional 1,500 hectares of hardwood plantation is to be added to the existing 12,250 hectares already established. Since the introduction of the national afforestation program we have seen a more than doubling of the hardwood plantation establishment rate that existed prior to the NAP. Indeed, as a direct result of this Government's initiative through the NAP, the overall area of hardwood plantations has been increased by 20 per cent. One of the interesting projects that were funded under this allocation was a study of the establishment of rainforest species in agroforestry plantation systems by the Institute of Tropical Rainforest Studies in Cairns. The $6.5m that I announced is additional to the $3.9m announced by the Prime Minister in his environment statement.

I come to the final point of Senator Zakharov's question about plantation development generally. I can announce that I have set up a task force comprising Professor Lindsay Pryor, the world's foremost expert on eucalypts and who has had extensive experience in plantation development, and Dr Joe Landsberg, who was formerly chief of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Division of Forestry Research and who is an expert on both forestry and ecological management. That task force will work in the south-east forests of New South Wales with a view to testing the viability of a plantation strategy for that region. Its task is two-fold. The first phase is to look at the prospects for trees on farmland in that area to supplement the--

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on, Cookie! Watch the time.

—This is an important question. The first phase is to look at the prospects for trees on farmland in that area to supplement the forest resource for industry there, to provide an alternative stream of income for farmers, and to look at the longer term trialling of different species and types, given the soil composition, rainfall and commercial needs for that area-again, to take pressure off native forests.

ANSWER.PARA: This is the fourth study on the south-east forests of New South Wales that I have commissioned. The first was into the floral and faunal properties of the area. The second was into the establishment of a flitch mill and the prospects for better utilisation of the resource because of that. The third was into the better utilisation of small and round wood, that is, the scrap materials that are left, for forestry industry purposes. This plantation study comes on the heels of those studies. It means that we can position ourselves, when these studies are concluded and the results are implemented, to see whether we can add greater value to the forest products in that area and to ease the pressure on native forests in that region.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Attorney-General to the decision of the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly last night to reject the Australian Capital Territory Government's Bill to tax the X-rated video industry based in the ACT. In view of this decision, will the Government convene a meeting of its working party on X- and R-rated videos to determine its position on banning the sale, distribution and hire of X-rated videos? Who are the members of the working party, when will it meet and when can we expect its decision on this matter to be made public?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not aware of the decision of the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly in relation to the manner in which it intended to raise revenue from the distribution of what are described as X-rated videos. I am therefore not entirely sure of the way in which that might relate in any way to a resumption of Federal responsibility in this matter, which is quite properly left for the decision of the newly elected Legislative Assembly in the Australian Capital Territory. I would be surprised if, merely because of the vote taken last night which Senator Reid has described, there would be any referral back of responsibility in this matter to this Parliament or the Government.

ANSWER.PARA: Nevertheless, I will look more closely at the decision taken last night and see whether it has any implications which would warrant the convening of the working party of the Caucus which of course was designed to look at another matter altogether, that is, the way in which the Australian people appreciated the true significance of classifications and the difference between violent and non-violent videos was pre-eminent in the minds of the members of that working party as something about which parents in the community are concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I am a little surprised that the Minister does not know that matters under the Attorney-General's Department and police matters have still not been handed to the Australian Capital Territory Government. But the last part of my question was: Who are the members of the working party? The Minister has answered that he does not know when it will meet and when can we expect the decision, but I ask: Who are the members of the working party?
—I am not sure that I can give information concerning Caucus committees, even if I knew off the top of my head, but I will have a further look at that matter.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Local Government and refer to an article in today's Age newspaper suggesting that local government is concerned about an alleged freeze on home and community care funds in Victoria. I ask the Minister whether she has seen these claims and whether, in fact, there is a freeze on funds limiting the provision of services by local government to the elderly and to people with disabilities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a little surprised to read this particular report which was brought to my attention this morning, because on Monday evening in Adelaide I had the opportunity to address a number of workers in community services and local government at a biannual conference. This issue was not raised at that conference, but nevertheless it is of concern to me and I have sought some information from my colleague Mr Peter Staples. The Government's commitment to the home and community care program is clearly demonstrated by the growth in funding for home and community care at a time of considerable budgetary restraint. In this year's Budget the Government has provided for 15 per cent growth in total Commonwealth home and community care funding. In addition, it has contributed a further $20m of Commonwealth only money, which has had the effect of increasing the total level of home and community care Commonwealth funds by almost 20 per cent over last year.

ANSWER.PARA: In Victoria, the State Government, which is responsible for the actual administration of the program, made a decision to index the program by 12.3 per cent. Therefore, this reflects an increase in total Commonwealth-State funding of around about $12.7m. I understand from the Victorian Minister that this amount provides sufficient funds to meet the full year effect of decisions taken last year, as well as pre-existing commitments, including a level of cost supplementation to existing services. In relation to the specific area of local government participation in the home and community care program-and, of course, the Federal and State governments do rely a great deal on local government's involvement in a program of this kind-this financial year, there was a 25 per cent increase and the total expenditure is estimated at $53.8m.

In answer to Senator Colston's question, obviously it is a matter of concern to me, as it is a matter of concern to local government, but I really feel confident that there has been some misunderstanding in the interpretation of the figures.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I draw the Minister's attention to a Taiwanese fishing vessel, the Mao Hua, licence No. PNG 60, trawling just outside the protected zone that is jointly administered by the Australian and Papua New Guinea governments. The trawler is fishing just outside the Nautilus Reef and Bramble Cay area, which is a turtle rookery and mackerel spawning ground. Is the Minister aware that under Papua New Guinea legislation trawling is not permitted west of longitude 144 degrees, 30 minutes. However, this boat is 35 miles west of that position? As these fishing grounds provide the Torres Strait Islanders with fish, turtle and dugong-their traditional food supply-will the Minister make representation to the Papua New Guinea Government to have trawling cease in this restricted area as a matter of extreme urgency?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had some advance knowledge of this question, so I have had an opportunity to check out the answer. I am advised that the Australian patrol boat Wauri has investigated two incidents in which the Papua New Guinea licensed Taiwanese vessel Mao Hua was operating in waters adjacent to Bramble Cay. I understand that the vessel was operating in Papua New Guinea waters outside the Torres Strait protected zone, apparently in contravention of relevant Papua New Guinea legislation. Of course, this is a matter for the Papua New Guinea authorities. The Australian vessel Wauri has collected evidence which indicated that the vessel was operating in contravention of its Papua New Guinea licence, and this has now been passed on to the relevant authorities in Papua New Guinea. In addition, fisheries patrol officials have discussed the incidents with Papua New Guinea with a view to assisting in any future prosecution.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware that the area in the vicinity of Bramble Cay is a sensitive turtle rookery and a base for Australian licensed mackerel fishermen. However, the highest density of dugong is in the western part of the protected zone. Bramble Cay is in the north-east where the density of dugong is lower.

As I have said, the matter is one for the Papua New Guinea authorities. However, if the incidents were to occur to such an extent that the traditional fishing activities of Torres Strait Islanders were being detrimentally affected, there are mechanisms under the Torres Strait Treaty by which Australia and Papua New Guinea can jointly address such issues.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. I ask: In view of the virtual guarantee given on 6 October 1989 by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, in response to a question by Senator Beahan, that the Orionia community of Albany will receive a grant of permanent residence in two years time, what is the Minister doing to restore the access of those people to special benefit, which was interrupted on 23 September 1989 and re-applied for in the following month? Can the Minister also clarify whether they will have access to Medicare? On 6 October 1989 in this chamber Senator Robert Ray admitted:

QUESTION.PARA: It was probably actions by the Israeli Government and the Australian Government that detained them in the country.

In view of that I ask: Does the Minister share Senator Ray's expressed view that sympathetic Western Australian taxpayers should continue to provide private charity to the Orionia people until they can support themselves under recently issued work permits?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that Senator Jenkins ranges on a number of aspects dealing with the long-running Orionia case. In respect of the comments made by Senator Ray in answering the question about the migration and settlement aspects of this particular case, he made it very clear that temporary entry has been given to the people involved. That is all I want to say about that aspect of the question.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of the eligibility for special benefit by members of the Orionia community, it should be noted that two sets of cases are running before us. One is running in relation to applications for special benefit for some closed periods in the past, and those cases are being considered by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. In view of the fact that these matters are being properly heard by independent statutory administrative review bodies, it would not be appropriate either to comment on the issues involved or to make any estimation of what the people involved can expect from these two bodies.

As Senator Jenkins mentioned, there are some new claims for special benefit and those claims have been received from members of the Orionia community. I gather that they have been lodged with the Albany regional office of the Department of Social Security and I am informed that those applications are being processed in the normal way in accordance with the national guidelines issued for the administration of special benefit. The honourable senator also raised the question of access to medical benefits. The people involved here may in fact be eligible for health care cards which, broadly speaking, would give them access to health care benefits which are available to people on low incomes. They may be eligible and that has to be assessed.

The problem I have in giving the honourable senator a more definite answer about what may or may not happen in terms of the applications before the Government and the Department of Social Security by members of this community is that there are, as the honourable senator would understand, some quite stringent confidentiality provisions in the law which in fact safeguard the privacy of applicants. The assurance that I can give in the context of that is that these applications will be processed in the normal way according to the normal, nationally applicable guidelines and no discrimination will be offered one way or the other.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer and relates to the activities of the Child Support Agency. What is the length of time between employers making deductions of maintenance payable by non-defaulting persons and the actual receipt of these moneys by a dependant? Is the initial delay two months, whereas non-defaulters usually pay instantaneously on the due date? Does this mean that the dependant is permanently out of pocket for two months? What happens to that money in the interval? If this money is left lying about in government bank accounts, who receives the benefit of the interest earned thereon? What action will the Minister take to correct this crass stupidity in non-defaulting cases, since the dependant is far worse off under this system than under previous maintenance collection arrangements?

—The honourable senator has asked several questions on this matter, some of which go to matters of considerable detail. I am not familiar with the matter, but I will obtain an early answer from the Treasurer and provide it as soon as possible.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DRAFT CONVENTION ON THE RIGHTS OF THE CHILD

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I ask: Has the Government signed, or is it about to sign, the United Nations draft Convention on the Rights of the Child? Has the Government examined State child welfare laws in relation to many of the matters covered by this convention and made any judgment about their adequacy to protect the rights of Australian children? If not, will it do so, in consultation with the States, before it considers the ratification of this convention? Does the Government intend to use this convention in due course to justify Federal legislation on this important subject?

—The Australian Government welcomes the adoption, which occurred a couple of days ago at the United Nations General Assembly, of the Convention on the Rights of the Child. It was opened for signature and ratification on 20 November, which was the thirtieth anniversary of the 1959 United Nations Declaration on the Rights of the Child. It is the result of 10 years of preparation by a UN working group in which Australia played an active role. The actual internal process of ratification is a matter for the Attorney-General's Department, and my colleague Senator Tate might wish to comment further on this.
—Come on, Michael, give him the paper.

—Both he and I have already given quite substantial answers in this place on some of the lunatic misapprehensions which seem to be current in certain quarters of the community about the impact of the convention. Senator Tate's answer was given on 2 November, and I can give it to him to read again if he wants it. I gave an earlier answer on 26 October, which again I see no particular point in repeating because that would only give currency to the crazed loons around the place who have congenital misapprehensions of things, who jump at shadows and spooks, and who generally behave in a fashion which does not bear any resemblance to the kind of rationality which I would expect to prevail in this place.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Clearly Senator Evans would be much happier to handball the question to Senator Tate or, for that matter, to anybody else. The subject is not about lunatic ideas that may be current or not current on this matter. I asked specific questions about whether the Government had studied the existing child welfare laws and what its view was about their adequacy. Does it intend to legislate federally, with or without consultation with the States?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, it is a matter for Senator Tate, but at the moment the Government's judgment is that no Australian law is in contravention of the provisions of this particular convention. The utility of the convention is not in order to give the Government any additional legislative authority it may have lacked at the Federal level to do things which are not being done at the State level. Rather, the utility of it is as an international instrument reflecting an unequivocal international endorsement of some really quite fundamental and basic principles about respect for the position of children as individuals, which is manifestly not the case in a number of other cultures and countries. That is the reason for it, not in order to acquire authority to do all sorts of exotic things which, again, some lunatic fringe people seem to think are the Government's preoccupation and intention.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not my belief that there is any intent at all within the Government to legislate federally on child welfare issues based on the authority that a treaty of this kind would give it, in which case I doubt that it is necessary to go through any extensive consultative process with the States. However, as a matter of course, there is such a process of consultation before treaties are formally ratified and I have no doubt that that process will be followed again in this instance.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. I ask: Has Mr James Savage, an Aboriginal convicted of murder in the United States, made any application for legal aid? If he has, what is the Australian Government's view on that application?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —At various stages the legal advisers of Mr James Savage have applied for legal aid in relation to his trial in the State of Florida in the United States. In the first instance I decided that the Australian taxpayer should not support his application for legal aid in relation to the trial which, as to the verdict, concluded yesterday, 21 November, when he was convicted of first degree murder, robbery with a deadly weapon and sexual battery with great force with a deadly weapon. I decided that legal aid should not be made available at that stage because the Constitution of the United States provided for legal aid to be available to Mr Savage. Indeed, it was provided and I have been informed by consular officials and the Aboriginal Legal Aid representative, who is also in Florida, that the legal representation afforded to Mr Savage was very adequate indeed. They have no complaints about the adequacy of that legal representation.

ANSWER.PARA: However, the sentencing process commences on 11 December 1989. Requests have been made for legal aid to assist expert witnesses to travel to the United States to give evidence in mitigation of sentence, evidence which no doubt would go to the question of the effect of the adoption procedures and the removal from family which faced many Aboriginal women and their children. Thank goodness, that happened at a time in our past, but it was recent enough to have the sorts of consequences that it is alleged have resulted in Mr Savage facing the most severe capital penalty, that is, the death sentence.
Senator Stone interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I said `alleged'. Nevertheless, the fact is that when an Australian abroad is facing the death penalty, different considerations apply from those that apply to the actual proceedings by way of a trial of the facts. If there is a near analogy, it is the case of Barlow and Chambers in Malaysia, when some moneys were made available by way of financial assistance to those who were involved in the appeal process in regard to sentence. So at this stage I am looking at the matter sympathetically, and when Mr Savage's legal representatives make clear whom they wish to travel to the United States and precisely for what purpose and indicate clearly what expectations they might have of the part those persons could play in pleas for mitigation of sentence, I will give very sympathetic consideration to their request.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ACQUIRED IMMUNE DEFICIENCY SYNDROME: TRUST FUND

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. It concerns the trust fund established for people who have contracted acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) as a result of blood transfusions. I advise the Minister that an advocacy group that has made contact with me still has no detailed information on the administration or the details of the operation of the trust fund. I imagine that they do not know how to apply, who is eligible, et cetera. I therefore ask: When will the administrative details be available in relation to the trust fund that has been established? What information has been passed around to date to organisations representing these people? In view of the urgency of the matter, because people are dying and are in dire financial need now, can he urge the Minister to expedite all administrative processes that may be holding up the immediate use of this trust fund?

—With respect to the trust fund, I can confirm that the Government recently announced that it allocated $13.2m for a fund to assist people with medically acquired HIV. I cannot answer all the questions asked by the honourable senator, but the Minister for Community Services and Health is anxious that the matter proceed as quickly as possible and that money be made available as soon as possible to those in need. I understand that he has instructed his Department to move quickly on the matter. He has had discussions with the Haemophilia Foundation of Australia and I understand he is involved in discussions with relevant departments about the setting up of the fund, that is, the Department of Social Security, the Department of Finance, the Attorney-General's Department and the Treasury. I understand also that he has arranged for officers of the Department of Community Services and Health to provide next week a detailed progress report through the parliamentary liaison group on AIDS. If that is not a comprehensive answer to the honourable senator's question, I would be pleased to pick up any element of it and to ensure that it is properly answered.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I thank the Minister. `As soon as possible' is still not very precise for those who are trying to solve these problems. Can the Minister again approach his colleague and seek some indication as to the date on which the money from this fund will be made available?
—Yes.

—My question is directed to Senator Button, representing the Prime Minister and also representing Senator Walsh, who represents the Treasurer. The Government-the Prime Minister and the Treasurer in particular-has claimed regularly that our high interest rates, which are the highest in the Western world and the highest in Australia's history, have been necessary to dampen demand. The Minister will be aware that in order to offset unacceptably high mortgage interest rates, following the lead of the Labor Premier in South Australia, which will hold its election this Saturday, the Leader of the Labor Party in Queensland has offered $35m cash to mortgagors to compensate home buyers for the Federal Government's monetary policy. I ask the Minister: Does the Government support these schemes offered by State Labor leaders? Will the Government cut back the Federal Government funding to Queensland by $35m to bring the failed Hawke-Keating monetary strategy back on track?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question has a certain glib appeal, but that is as far as it goes. As I understand it, all political parties contesting elections in Queensland and South Australia have made offers of various kinds in relation to housing mortgage loan relief.
—That should tell you something.

—Senator Vanstone, thank you for your help. I understand that in both States the election results are likely to be fairly close, so in those political circumstances this sort of offer will be made by State political parties. In so far as the Commonwealth Government is concerned, our position on this matter is quite clear. As Senator Parer pointed out at the beginning of his question, monetary policy has been kept tight in order to reduce demand in the Australian economy and in order to have a consequent effect on the level of imports. Those statements have been made consistently by numerous Ministers and that is the position adopted by the Federal Government. As distinct from the contestants in the State political arena, no elector in the Commonwealth of Australia can hold out much hope for an early change to that policy, even if there were a change of government. Indeed, on the Opposition's policies as announced to date, if such a situation arose, there would be a further reliance on monetary policy and an increase in interest rates-there is no doubt about that.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator asked a question about $35m being promised by the Labor Party in Queensland for mortgage interest rate relief. I do not know what figure was offered by the National Party of Australia, but I assume it is larger. However, I suppose it is preferable that that sort of money be offered by way of relief to the general community purchasing homes rather than to tuck millions and millions of dollars into the pockets of corrupt businessmen in Queensland as has happened under the present National Party Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for his reply. Does he support these proposals made by Labor leaders, which appear to be a major slap in the face for the Federal Labor Government's economic policy?

—It is not my business to comment on what particular political parties in particular State election campaigns are doing in terms of this issue. If the honourable senator derives some political comfort from the fact that Australia has high interest rates, so be it. There will be no change in Federal Government policy on this issue until the problems which the policy is designed to address are resolved.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Has the Federal Government decided to transfer certain airport security functions from the Australian Federal Police? If so, which organisation will assume responsibility for these functions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator has asked a good question, as has been noted by the Opposition, because the question of airport security is of great concern to domestic and overseas passengers. That is why the Federal Government has moved to upgrade security arrangements at some 23 Australian airports and from January onwards the responsibility for that first anti-terrorist incident control will move progressively from the Australian Federal Police to the Australian Protective Service (APS). Indeed, the counter-terrorist presence will be enhanced at these airports and will be provided for the first time at some 13 other airports, including, as Senator Brian Archer will be interested to know, Launceston and Devonport, which, as a result of this decision, will receive the benefit of this enhanced security service.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result, the Australian Federal Police will be able to focus on its primary role, which of course is to be the pre-eminent national criminal investigative body throughout the Commonwealth. I believe that we are now at the last stage of the major restructuring of the Australian Federal Police so as to enable it to concentrate, outside of its community policing responsibilities in Canberra, on that nation-wide role.

I am very confident that the Australian Protective Service will be able to provide that required security at airports. As honourable senators would know, there is no doubt that the security provided by the APS at Parliament House, selected embassies, consulates and defence establishments has proved to be excellent and I am sure that it is well within its charter, training and capacity to provide the same sort of security at our Australian airports. Some legislation will be required to give members of the Australian Protective Service certain limited powers in relation to their responsibilities, but I do not believe there is any question whatsoever of members of that service being vested with general police powers. I do not think that anyone would wish that to be the case.

Community policing functions at airports will continue to be the responsibility of the State and Territory police forces. Apart from the great majority of lost and found requests for assistance, very few such incidents occur. I believe that State and Territory police forces will be able to handle, as I say, the very few incidents relating to community policing functions without any great diversion of resources.

We have now reached the final stage in the restructuring of the Australian Federal Police, which this chamber has supported. I have been very grateful for that support. I believe that from 1 January we will have a very clear role for the Australian Federal Police as Australia's pre-eminent investigative agency into criminal matters Australia-wide.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Button as the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is the Minister aware that the International Labour Organisation (ILO), the body so strongly supported by the Prime Minister and the organisation which is likely to be his employer after the next election, is about to seek a response from the Government to a complaint that the Government's actions in the pilots dispute have contravened ILO conventions 87 and 98 concerning the right of freedom of association and the right to bargain collectively? Does the Minister agree that the Prime Minister's refusal to countenance any role for the Australian Federation of Air Pilots (AFAP) in the resolution of the dispute, when that body clearly retains the support of the vast majority of pilots, puts the Government in breach of the ILO conventions which Australia has ratified? Will the Government reply to the ILO's request for an explanation of its actions or will it continue to treat the principle of freedom of association with the same contempt that it has shown throughout this dispute, or non-dispute?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that the International Federation of Airline Pilots Associations has complained to the International Labour Organisation, presumably through its member body the Australian Federation of Air Pilots which has complained to everybody it can think of that its members are having their rights to freedom of association infringed in the current industrial situation. It might be better for the Australian Federation of Air Pilots to go back to work rather than cause the disruption which it has caused in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: I am sure that the ILO will deal with this matter in line with its usual procedures. The Australian Government is preparing a response to these complaints. I would not want to respond prematurely or through unofficial channels to the specific complaint. I simply reiterate that the Government strongly supports freedom of association. We reiterated this point in our submissions to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission during the hearing on this dispute on 28 September 1989.

There has been no change to the status of the AFAP as a federally registered union, as there was to the Builders Labourers Federation, for example, or to the availability of the rights, privileges and protection of the Federal system. It is the Federation of Air Pilots which has consistently refused to follow the processes or meet the obligations of that system. It has been given several opportunities to proceed with its claim within the system and has refused to do so. Its members voluntarily resigned en masse from their employment with the major domestic airlines and, through its own actions, it is now not in a position to negotiate on behalf of any of its members who are employed in this industry. It is very difficult to see that there could be any breach of the principle of freedom of association in these circumstances and I guess the Commonwealth will be re- plying in that light.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday when the Committee was considering the Estimates, Senator Newman asked me for a general update on the situation in relation to the Iran-Iraq border. Because of the general interest in this matter I seek leave to have an answer to her question incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
SITUATION ALONG THE IRAN/IRAQ BORDER
Ceasefire Line Incidents
There have been frequent violations of the ceasefire along the Iran/Iraq ceasefire line since the formal cessation of hostilities between the two countries in August 1988.
Some violations, such as that referred to by Senator Newman and which had been reported in the press, have resulted in exchanges of artillery fire.

Many incidents appear to have resulted from attempts to improve defensive positions along the ceasefire line including the reinforcement of existing positions with additional troops and equipment. On the Iranian side of the line, for instance, a massive defence wall with associated tank ditches and embankments is being developed along a part of this line, together with canals which would enable flooding of the southern border sector if flood gates were opened.

In spite of these violations and the likelihood that incidents will continue to occur, we are confident that both Iran and Iraq are committed to the ceasefire and that a resumption of full-scale hostilities is unlikely.

I am encouraged by the fact that both sides are engaging in civilian reconstructions in areas adjacent to their border. Iran for instance is rebuilding the oil refinery at Abadan, and Iraq in engaged in the reconstruction of the City of Basra. I interpret these developments as evidence that neither side is intending to resume hostilities.
Unsponsored Peace Talks.

Peace talks between Iran and Iraq under UN auspices have continued in stalemate. Iran is demanding a withdrawal of all Iraqi forces from Iranian territory as a first step in the peace negotiations. For its part Iraq has claimed sovereignty over the Shatt Al-Arab waterway which runs between the two countries (a position which is at odds with a 1975 international agreement between the two countries defining the border as the thalweg of the waterway).

With regard to the exchange of prisoners of war, there has been no progress to date on this issue and we understand that the Secretary-General's special envoy is attempting to convene ministerial-level talks between the two sides in New York in December to address these issues. In the meantime, I was encouraged to note that Iran's Foreign Minister, Dr Velayati, announced on 16 November that Iran was prepared for an immediate and simultaneous repatriation of prisoners of war and troop withdrawal to international recognised borders.
Australian Involvement in UNIIMOG.

With no progress in the negotiations between Iran and Iraq, pressures on UNIIMOG will continue. We expect that localised tension will remain at its present level and that there will be occasions when serious breaches of the ceasefire will be recorded. Inevitably this will involve some degree of threat to Australian forces serving in UNIIMOG.

In the circumstances I have described, it is expected that UNIIMOG will remain in place for some time to come and that Australia will continue to support the force, which we consider to be performing a very worthwhile function.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I refer to an article on pages 1 and 10 in the Italian language newspaper Il Globo of 13 November written by Mr Nino Randazzo.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. The honourable senator sought leave to make a statement because she had been misrepresented. If she wished to clarify some misrepresentation of her, we would normally grant leave. We are not prepared to grant leave for her to make a statement. In the past the honourable senator has ranged fairly widely on these matters and we do not wish that to continue. Will she clarify whether she is seeking to make a personal explanation?
—Senator Jenkins approached me and said that she wished to make a personal explanation, but she did not say that to the chamber. Senator Jenkins, can you ask for leave again?
—I seek leave to make a personal explanation in the form of a statement. It is a personal explanation, Mr President.
—Is leave granted?
—Can the honourable senator clarify that all she is seeking to do is make a personal explanation?
—I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Is leave granted?
—Yes.

—I refer to an article on pages 1 and 10 in the Italian language newspaper Il Globo of 13 November written by Nino Randazzo. In the article, in which he discusses whether prospective migrants should climb on board the Australian ship or seek to disembark, Mr Randazzo referred specifically to the Australian Democrats' immigration policy no fewer than three times. His comments on the policy are inaccu- rate--
—Mr President, on a point of order--
—Order! Senator Jenkins, can you show the Senate where this is a personal explanation? You are not entitled to make a personal explanation about a party's policies.
—I have spoken to Mr Randazzo on a number of occasions with regard to policy. When asked where he obtained these statements he said, `from Senator Robert Ray'.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. The Opposition would wish to preserve at all times the right of honourable senators to make a personal explanation. I think that there is a genuine misunderstanding on the part of Senator Jenkins who believes that she can use a personal explanation to clarify a point of policy which may have been misrepresented. In raising the point of order, I point out that if this procedure is permitted the Opposition will be permitted on a daily basis to stand up and clarify the misrepresentations of its policies which are made in Question Time time and again by everybody from the Leader of the Government down. The only reason that Senator Burns, who is seeking to interject, does not do so is that he does not get to answer any questions. Mr President, I think you can see that this would be wide open for further using up a great amount of time of the Senate. If necessary, you should explain to the honourable senator what a personal explanation entails and keep her to that limit.
—Senator Jenkins, you have to refer to where in the article you personally have been misrepresented-not the party.
—As spokesperson for the Australian Democrats on immigration, I claim that, Mr President.
—Order! Unless you are personally named it will be out of order.
—I will raise the matter in the adjournment debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN HERITAGE COMMISSION (NATIONAL ESTATE PROTECTION) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to my contingent notice of motion I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Dunn moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to provide that the Order of the Day for the resumption of the debate on the Australian Heritage Commission (National Estate Protection) Amendment Bill 1989 be called on forthwith and have precedence over all other business determined.

I move the motion partly because Independents are given so little time on General Business and it is too late for me to use any of my General Business time this year. More importantly, the question of the loss of our National Estate in Australia must be debated immediately.
