TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Senator Dunn is entitled to move a motion explaining why the Standing Orders should be suspended or business should be rearranged. However, I put it to you, Mr President, that she is not entitled to canvass the substance of the Bill which she seeks to bring on for debate. What she is now doing is canvassing the detail of the Bill and I believe that that is not in accordance with the Standing Orders.
—Senator Dunn, in your remarks you have to show why the Bill should be dealt with urgently and why you seek the suspension of Standing Orders. You must not go into the details of the Bill.

—I beg your pardon, Mr President: I did not go into any details of the Bill. I was talking about our National Estate, which is admittedly in the title of the Bill and the subject and content of the Bill. I have not referred to the content of the Bill. I was saying why it is so important to debate the question of our National Estate before the end of the year and before we lose more of our precious National Estate properties around the country.
—That is the Bill.
—Of course it is the Bill but I am not referring to the content, so let me continue.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. It is not a matter of Senator Dunn continuing but of her adhering to the ruling which you have given, which, as I understand it, is that the substance of either the Bill or the cause which the Bill relates to is not proper to be canvassed when the motion before the chamber relates to the suspension of Standing Orders or the rearrangement of business. Senator Dunn is obliged to adhere to your ruling not to debate the substance of matters relating to the Heritage Commission, the National Estate or the Bill itself.

—Order! The issue of suspension of Standing Orders is one on which a number of points of order are taken every time it is raised. I think Senator Dunn is entitled to tell the Senate why she considers the Bill is urgent and I will listen to her when she continues.

—Thank you, Mr President. The Government, and particularly the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, have acknowledged the effectiveness of some legislation which is based on the corporations power of the Constitution. Indeed, on several occasions they have threatened to use that corporations power specifically in relation to logging in the south-east forests of New South Wales. On 26 July this year, when Senator Richardson spoke at the National Press Club in Canberra, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: If the Commonwealth is unsatisfied with the result of negotiations with NSW after this, then the option for the Commonwealth to use the corporations power will still be there and will be used.
That was specifically in relation to the south-east forests. In a newspaper on the same day the following report appeared:

At the same time, Senator Richardson issued his strongest declaration on the ultimate necessity for greater Commonwealth environmental power and depicted the Federal Coalition as `spooked' by State rights . . .

The Minister declared that he would use the corporations power against the Greiner Government to protect the National Estate forests around Eden in NSW if federal-State negotiations failed to reach a satisfactory result.

We know that this particular debate has been going on with great conflict since the beginning of this year. The reason I raise it now is that if we go into recess and then an election is called, such legislation could be put off for a very long time. I would like to put forward a number of reasons to satisfy Senator Puplick and others in the chamber as to why it is necessary to bring on this debate immediately.

Senator Richardson has also signalled that the Federal Government would resort to the external affairs power against Queensland to protect the rainforests there. This threat to use constitutional powers is very necessary if we are to protect our National Estate around the country. It is clear that State governments have not had the ability to deal with the problem or, as in the case of the New South Wales Government, have been intransigent and will not deal with the problem. It does not call itself `New South Wales Incorporated' for nothing, and it is not for nothing that its favourite phrase is `fast tracking development'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Now that you have heard Senator Dunn give the explanation to which you said you would listen, bearing in mind that she has now made her point on a day on which the proceedings are being broadcast, which was the object of the exercise, I ask you to rule whether she is any longer in conformity with the Standing Orders or whether she is quite clearly debating the substance of the matter, which you have asked her not to do, and whether she should be called to order and to conformity with the Standing Orders.

—I think Senator Dunn was giving reasons why the debate should come on but she is beginning to stray outside those guidelines. I ask her to return to the reasons or I will have to rule her out of order.
—Thank you, Mr President. I go back to Mr Hawke's statement in a speech that he made on 22 August at an Australian Labor Party dinner. Amongst other things he said:

SPEECH.PARA: If the State Government doesn't co-operate fully in the biological studies and in a full examination of alternatives to logging the South East National Estate Forests, my Government will bring down the full weight of its constitutional powers-including the corporations power-to achieve a solution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I have sat here patiently and listened to the interchange between you, Senator Dunn and Senator Puplick. As I understand it, Senator Dunn is arguing that this matter should be brought on for debate immediately instead of somewhat later in the current session. She must explain to the Senate why there is that degree of urgency in the matter. I do not think she has even begun to do that and, on the basis of the argument she has so far developed, she has not the slightest likelihood of being able to do so. Nobody could persuade me that having the Bill debated now rather than in the next three or four weeks would make the slightest bit of difference.
—The point of order is correct. I am listening to Senator Dunn.

—The reason I raise the matter now is that public concern over the loss of national assets, especially the natural assets of our country, is mounting. People around the country-not just those who would call themselves greenies but ordinary citizens-are very concerned. They have lost confidence in the ability of their governments, both State and Federal, to protect those assets and accept responsibility for that protection. To answer Senator Stone's objection, in the south-east of New South Wales we know that a critical situation has been developing all year. There is practically a state of civil war down there, as honourable senators might have seen from the recent Couchman program. Communities have been torn apart by the conflict and particularly by the uncertainty of both State and Federal government intentions on the matter. Hundreds of people have been arrested. The cost involved to the people of New South Wales has been phenomenal and there has been violence in the south-east. Shots have been fired; people have been hurt.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The question before the chamber relates to why it is urgent for the business of the Senate to be rearranged. You have now warned Senator Dunn on a large number of occasions about debating the substance. What she is now discussing clearly has a great deal to do with the substance of this legislation and nothing to do with the motion which is before the chamber at the moment. Once again I ask you to direct her and, if she will not obey your direction, to deal with her accordingly if she continues to breach Standing Orders.

—Senator Dunn, I have tried to be as lenient as possible because there have been many instances when people have spoken to the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders for quite some time. The point of order taken by Senator Puplick is, however, correct. You must confine your remarks to why this matter is urgent and not debate the issue. I realise that there are difficulties in doing that. I ask you only to give the reasons why this matter is urgent and why Standing Orders should be suspended.

—Thank you, Mr President. I fear that if this matter is not brought on, and brought on immediately, we could have further violence in the south-east and conflict within the community. Many people around the country are concerned about this and wish to see a resolution of the problem. If I do not force the debate in the Senate to be proceeded with at a time like this the matter will not be debated but will be ignored by the Opposition and the Government, despite the Government's threats to use the corporations power. Therefore it is up to an independent such as myself to raise the issue in the Senate and to give it the urgency that it deserves.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear from the media and from concerns expressed by citizens right across this country that environmental issues are almost paramount, second to economic concerns, and that we must address these issues now. The concern of local citizens relates to aspects of the National Estate which I think Senator Puplick may not have considered. People on the Couchman program expressed concern for the Tantawangalo water catchment area, for example, which presently is being logged in a trial logging program by the Forestry Commission. Do we really have to cut off an arm to find out what it is like not to have one? We know from metropolitan water board studies that logging in a water catchment area will affect the catchment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Dunn, I think you are debating the matter again. You have spoken for 10 minutes. I think it would be better if you wound up your remarks by stating why Standing Orders should be suspended.

—Mr President, perhaps I might take a slightly different tack. For a very long time conservation groups have been trying to engage the Government and timber workers over this conflict in the south-east. That is why I believe it is imperative for us to be able to discuss this legislation as the only solution to the problems that have arisen, particularly in the south-east but which will arise right across the country. Conservationists have prepared a document called The Wood or the Trees, which is a very substantial 300-page document which attempts to provide the industry and conservationists with a solution that is economically sustainable and realistic and which does not provide any unemployment in the timber industry. This is a serious effort on the part of the under-resourced Australian Conservation Foundation. It has been largely ignored by the Government and particularly by the relevant Ministers. Just last Sunday there was a--
—Order! Senator Dunn, you are clearly debating the issue.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. Let us assume that we were to accept Senator Dunn's urgency motion and agree to debate the Bill today, conclude debate upon it today, and pass it. Senator Dunn has yet to demonstrate by a single word she has uttered that that would make the slightest difference or have even the slightest relevance to the questions to which she has directed her remarks for the past 10 minutes. In other words, the Bill in question is irrelevant to the matters to which she is referring. She knows it and the Senate should be told of it. She should be sat down and we should be allowed to get on with the business.
—Unless Senator Dunn can relate her remarks to the suspension of Standing Orders I will have to sit her down. I call Senator Dunn.

—Thank you, Mr President. I am doing my best. I am at a loss to understand some of the complaints about what I am saying, since I have not addressed the substance of the Bill; but I will press on. I am talking about the necessity for the Federal Government to have control over the major environmental problems in this country. That goes really to the matter in hand.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. My point of order is that Senator Dunn appears to be reading a speech. She takes each point of order as it comes and then carries on down the track. She is treating the Chair and its rulings with contempt and she ought to be sat down if she cannot relate her remarks to the suspension of Standing Orders.
—I accept the point of order. I will give Senator Dunn one more chance.
—Thank you, Mr President. This is really interesting. I turn to the letter that the Director of the Australian Conservation Foundation wrote to Bob Hawke on 29 May this year.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Dunn is clearly out of order and I ask her to resume her seat. Before I put the vote, I point out to all honourable senators that the Procedure Committee came up with a recommendation to get over this type of situation. I hope that at some time in the future the Senate will look at it seriously. It was to give five minutes to any honourable senator who wanted to move the suspension of Standing Orders.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the President has received the following letter, dated 22 November, from Senator Chaney:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Government to accelerate the pace of reform to achieve a genuine workplace-based industrial relations system which will allow Australians to work together more productively to reduce our foreign debt and to stop the slide in living standards.'
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Government to accelerate the pace of reform to achieve a genuine workplace based industrial relations system which will allow Australians to work together more productively to reduce our foreign debt and to stop the slide in living standards.

I think it is probably true that most of Australia is concerned about both the slide in living standards and the extraordinary rise in our foreign debt over recent years and that most of Australia now has come to associate those two negative features of the Australian economy together. The Opposition brings this item forward as a matter of urgency today because of the apparent lack of any sense of urgency within the Government to deal with an issue which really lies at the heart of solving those fundamental problems of Australia.

There seem to be two versions of Australia's present position. Over the last couple of days I think that all members of parliament have received a letter from the Business Council of Australia which represents what one might call the worried view about Australia's position. It is by no means a lone voice crying in the wilderness. In recent days in the Senate we have heard references to the Macquarie Bank Ltd, the Industries Assistance Commission, Citibank Ltd and all sorts of bodies which have been drawing attention to what is seriously wrong with the Australian economy.

The Business Council has announced to the people of Australia that it will hold a national business summit on debt in March next year. It has talked about the fact that whilst there have been significant reforms and new approaches in the 1980s, the pace of adjustment has not kept up with what is required in a fierce international competitive environment. In the letter sent to all members of parliament the Business Council points out that one of the difficulties in finding solutions is in convincing the community-including the business community-that our rising debt and lack of competitiveness are real problems which, if not corrected, will undermine our economic future.

At the same time as we are getting from that very cautious body a clarion call to direct our attention to significant problems, we find the contrary view being advanced, not surprisingly, by the two groups in Australia that seem to be basically satisfied with things as they are. For example, we find that Mr Hawke is reported in the press as having told the Caucus this week that there really is not a debt crisis in Australia, that things are pretty much on track and that the Caucus can be reassured about where we are economically. Just as consolingly, Mr Kelty, who seems to have a fairly close working relationship with Mr Hawke, is reported in today's Australian Financial Review as saying:
This country is not heading downhill. This country is moving forward at a rapid rate.

I want to address the fact that we think that this is a matter of urgency because the country is not moving ahead. We think that a serious crisis is facing Australia and we think that the Government could be doing practical things about it now. But the fact is that the Government is choosing to do nothing. It is choosing not to take the actions that it could take, that so many people are suggesting it should take, to accelerate the pace of reform. Instead we have this sense of calm and complacency about a deteriorating situation. We think that this motion of urgency is important and is required because we think that the Government knows what is required but lacks either the guts or the gumption to take the necessary action in the face of the vested interests of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), in particular, which is against the changes which could make a difference for the people of Australia, in both an overall sense in tackling our foreign debt and also, more significantly to the men and women of Australia, doing something about their declining real incomes.

Let us just focus for a moment in this debate on why it is that the people of Australia think that there is a problem. The simple truth is that the accord which Mr Kelty entered into with the Hawke-Keating Government is an accord which over nearly seven years has delivered to the people of Australia declining real incomes. It is not just the high interest rates that are currently pressing on so many people. The fact is that, if we look at what Australians earn today compared to what they earned five, six and seven years ago, those incomes are less. They are less because this Government has not been able to manage the economy in a way which ensures that inflation is less than wage rises. Instead year by year wages go up, prices go up even higher and the men and women of Australia are worse off.

If that were happening as part of a process of economic adjustment which was getting Australia into a good economic condition, we might say it was worth it. But when those declining real wages over a seven-year period are accompanied by a massive upsurge in foreign debt, then clearly the formula is not working. In recent weeks in Australia we have had a succession of reports and comments which make the point that we have an urgent problem that requires focused attention from this Government-not the sort of attention that we have seen given to Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), who is at the table; not the sort of attention that we saw given to interest rates with a temporary $200m deal with a few banks which momentarily halted the rise in interest rates for a small number of borrowers; not that sort of special dealing that we have seen given to the airlines; not that sort of thing at all. We need a focus on the fundamentals that will make this country prosperous, productive and growing again.

That is what this motion is about. The Opposition is saying that simple practical things could be done to make Australia work better. Those things would accelerate the pace of change, give us some real growth, give us a chance to increase productivity and give us a chance to tackle these problems. We have had a number of debates in these terms. On the day on which the Budget was brought down I proposed a matter of public importance in similar terms to this one. The Minister sitting at the table responded to that debate. Sadly, little has changed since that time. The Government has shown no desire to give attention to these urgent issues. Instead we have a government which is fumbling around desperately looking for a way to cope until it can try to steal an election. We have not got the attention to these vital issues which is required. On 15 August I said that people in Australia are concerned about the spectre of foreign debt, the general sense of declining living standards and the general sense of national decline in a comparative sense. Those sentiments are still true today. There is still not that sense of urgency within the Government.

This debate focuses on what we say is the core problem, which is doing something about the way we work in Australia, doing something about the labour market, doing something about industrial relations-use whichever words you will. We believe that there are practical and simple measures that can be taken in these areas which are not being taken currently by the Government to improve things. We do not-and I make this point because the Leader of the Government indulges in cheap debating points in these debates-say that reform of the labour market is the only thing that is required to be done. The Economic Action Plan deals with a great range of areas of change, such as the waterfront, coastal shipping, privatisation, contracting out, tax and expenditure, which we think are relevant to making Australia perform better. At the core of the changes which are required are changes to the way we work and to the way we regulate our workplaces.

I simply want in the debate to avoid the Leader of the Government saying that we are overlooking major areas of change and to direct his attention to the close coincidence between the details set out in our Economic Action Plan of about a month ago and in the details set out in the Industries Assistance Commission annual report 1988-89 which carefully catalogues the same areas of change as being vital to lift Australia's wealth, to give us the capacity to pay our debts and to lift living standards. I, in no sense, wish to reduce the emphasis that the Opposition would place on those vital areas of change. According to the Industries Assistance Commission, which is a non-political body which is administered under the Public Service which is in the hands of this Government, not in the hands of the Opposition, we have the capacity to have a long term increase in our gross domestic product (GDP) of about $16 billion just by reforming our transport sector, postal and telecommunications services and electricity sectors, and by reductions in rural and manufacturing assistance.

There is a massive capacity to make changes for the better in this economy. The Government is getting plenty of non-political advice on how to do it as well as political advice from the Opposition. The Government should be alert to the fact that what the Opposition is saying, what the Business Council of Australia is saying, what the Macquarie Bank is saying, all have a very strong common thread of there being a series of changes that can be made in Australia to make the Australian economy more efficient and to move to a solution of our problems.

I have already referred to the Business Council and its deep concern about the lack of attention given to the problem of foreign debt. I will refer a little later in the debate to some of the Business Council's suggestions as to what can be done about the labour market to produce some of the improvements which are required. Again, there is a startling coincidence between what it is advocating, after its own independent research and examination of these problems, and what is being advocated by the Opposition. This Government is presiding over successive downgradings of Australia's credit rating. This Government is presiding over successive reductions in living standards in this country. This Government is presiding over monthly increases in our foreign debt, and there is a major ongoing threat to our living standards.

I refer briefly to the report of the Macquarie Bank which has been referred to in Question Time in the Senate over recent days. In that report the Macquarie Bank puts down a very stark and, as the Minister who is at the table would say, pessimistic assessment that Australians face the likelihood of foreign debt doubling over the next five years, getting to 44 per cent of our GDP, and reaching nearly 60 per cent of GDP by the year 2000. This is putting us beyond the banana republic category; it is putting us into the category of a bankrupt nation. I make that point because it underlines the urgency of this matter and the need for change in the areas to which this motion refers, in particular, the area of the labour market.

Again, there is this extraordinary commonality in the comments of observers, whether we look at comments by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development or by a business leader like John Spalvins who, I think the Minister at the table would concede, is one of those people in business who, in the process of reorganising and restructuring a number of businesses around Australia, have managed to lift their efficiency very considerably. He would not be classified as one of those takeover merchants who have reduced the efficiency of the Australian economy. Quite the contrary, he is someone who has made significant contributions to increasing its efficiency. What John Spalvins said in a recent speech to the Institute of Corporate Managers, Secretaries and Administrators brings out the point again. He said:
In particular, we have to be concerned about industrial relations in this country . . . concerned about where labour costs are heading.
This, more than any other single factor, I suggest, will dictate the level of inflation, the growth or decline in productivity, and whether we are really capable of competing internationally.

I regard over-regulation of labour as a very significant barrier to achieving higher productivity, because whenever wage increases are decided it's done nationally, right across the board, regardless of whether a business can afford it or not.

He explained further the disadvantages of that system, but I do not have time to quote him further. I simply say to the Minister at the table that he should stop rejecting the idea that more rapid change is possible and in fact is absolutely essential, as some sort of political reflex action because he does not want to admit that the Government is not doing an adequate job. Instead, he should start to embrace some of the changes which are being put forward.

What are the practical things which can be done? We say that it is important to continue some of the top down reforms which this Government has tried to promote and which we have always supported where we have seen them as contributing to greater flexibility and greater productivity. The Opposition supported, for example, the second tier wage negotiations as an improvement on the old system, as a focus on productivity increase. It has had very little practical impact on the gross figures in Australia, but we agree that it has focused attention in a new and more positive way. We have supported award restructuring in the same way.

This top down approach, this bureaucratic approach to change and to greater efficiency, cannot and will not work quickly enough. The results are slow, the results are painful and sometimes the results are nil. I invite the Minister at the table to examine the award restructuring decision in the building industry and to give us his honest opinion on whether there are real productivity gains in that process. I suggest that his answer will be no. What we are saying is that if the system is changed so that there is a greater opportunity for a workplace focus in industrial relations, it is possible to make substantial quantum improvements to productivity. The Minister in his response to the last debate on this subject referred to the fact that the Government has put a provision for certified agreements into the Act. He cited a number of examples which he cited again in Question Time yesterday. He mentioned ICI Australia Ltd and some other company.

TALK.START.PARA: —About two.

—Yes, two examples, as Senator Stone says, where productivity improvements have been achieved. Of course we welcome them and are pleased about that, but I can point to the Castle Bacon Pty Ltd case; I can point to the Sanctuary Cove case where agreements of a similar kind were delayed for between one and two years by the obstructive use of the centralised system to prevent employers and employees-including trade unions-working together cooperatively.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The decision in the Castle Bacon case was appealed. I have talked about both cases. In each case the situation was the same. Attempts by employers and employees to work together were sabotaged by small outside elements. They were held up for a very long period when both the employers and the employees had been seeking to do the right thing for themselves and Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: In the limited time left to me I say to the Minister that we believe that there are some simple, practical things which must and should be done. The first is that attention needs to be given to freeing up the capacity of parties to make agreements where they wish. When parties in a genuinely voluntary way wish to agree, there should not be the capacity to obstruct that agreement that we saw in both those cases which I have mentioned. I point out to the Minister that the quite independent research work of the Business Council of Australia suggests that there are 20 to 25 per cent productivity improvements which can be achieved following that route. I point out that its careful researchers put forward exactly the same proposition as the Opposition has put forward since 1986-for there being a freedom to agree in lieu of operating under awards.

In a debate on an urgency motion there is not the time to go into all the detail one would wish on that proposition. Suffice it to say that I think there are proper answers to the fear of a wages breakout which are contained, first, in the requirement that the agreements be genuinely voluntary; secondly, in the requirement that maximum competitive pressure be put on people who are in the industry so that they have little room for sweetheart deals; thirdly, our proposal for effective compliance procedures to back up the authority of the Commission where rogue unions or rogue employers might be involved; and, finally, we say that the centralised system-which traditionally has been the source of a wages breakout because small wage settlements in one sector of the economy are spread throughout the economy using the centralised system-has learnt something from the impact of both 1974 and 1981.

I turn then to the second area which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) addressed during his visit to Japan and which the Opposition has been saying for some time is vital if we are to get a more efficient operation in our workplaces and solve Australia's problems of both debt and declining living standards. The trade union structure in Australia is an absolute barrier to reform. Senator Burns is sitting over there; he is someone who has worked hard in the trade union movement and is devoted to it, but we find that even his Treasurer is making the point that the increasing enterprise focus which is required if we are to solve Australia's problems is obstructed by our trade union structure.

I put to the Minister that the suggestions the Opposition has been putting forward since last year, which we put in legislative form during the debate on the Industrial Relations (Directions to Stop Industrial Action) Amendment Bill and which the Business Council has now independently come to the conclusion are required, simply involve giving people at the workplace greater authority to determine how they will be represented at the workplace. They may choose to be represented by a union; they may not. But what we say is that the system of trade union amalgamations promoted by this Government in concert with the ACTU will do nothing to solve the problem of having many unions within workplaces. We have put forward the specific suggestion that there should be a greater capacity on the part of employees to produce a single enterprise bargaining unit-that is the word of our policy and the words of the Business Council-to produce no more than one trade union within an enterprise.

If the Government fails to embrace these positive proposals to accelerate change, it will carry the sole blame for Australia's continuing predicament, for the continuing hardship which is being suffered in the Australian community, and for the continued high risk this country faces in its overall economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney has given his speech before on numerous occasions; I am going to give mine.
—His is convincing.

—Senator Newman interjects and says that his is convincing. It is not convincing too many people out in the community, as I will tell the Senate in a minute. Senator Chaney, of course, begins-he uses the expression in the motion he moves-by talking about living standards. Like his present Leader in the lower House, in measuring living standards he is in fact talking about the use of average weekly earnings as an appropriate measure of living standards. That is the measure Mr Peacock uses. It is a measure Senator Chaney uses. What is meant by average weekly earnings? It is only an average of adult male full time wage and salary earnings. What the use of that measure reflects in talking about average weekly earnings is the Liberal Party view, from which it cannot escape, locked as it is into a society of the 1960s, when that was an appropriate measure. What that measure ignores is the self-employed, retired persons and almost three million women in the work force, a change which has taken place since that was an appropriate measure.
—Because they have to go into the work force.

—Come on! Senator Parer should go back to about 1965 and enjoy his heyday with the rest of the Queenslanders up there in the National Party. Do not come at me with all that sort of stuff. Look at the growth in female employment during the Opposition's period of government and in this period of government. Does the Opposition make the same claim in respect of it? A more appropriate measure of living standards is not average weekly male earnings but the household disposable income per head of population in Australia, and that includes total wages.
—Out there they are not very convinced by that argument either.

—It includes total wages and salaries received by Australian households. Maybe some of them are not convinced because Senator Chaney keeps going on with this average weekly earnings comparison. Maybe Senator Chaney has had some success there. Employment growth is taken into account in the household disposable income. After all, this Government has created 1.5 million jobs. That is vitally relevant to many Australians because it creates options and choices for them which would not have been there and were not there when the Opposition went out of government.
—And $85 billion of foreign debt to go with them-$60,000 of debt per job.

—Senator Stone can recycle the debate whichever way he wants, but he should just face up to that point. Senator Stone was the architect of the recession which brought about all that unemployment in 1981-82 and the man who then told us that we had a big deficit inherited from the previous government, the biggest deficit in Australian history, which has been reduced by this Government and turned into a surplus. That was Senator Stone's role. Now he is up there backing his mates in the National Party in Queensland, where they have different views of cash flow problems from anybody else in Australia. It is all done in brown paper bags up there. That is where Senator Stone's allegiance now lies.

SPEECH.PARA: The measure of household disposable per capita income is the correct measure because employment growth is taken into account. This measure of living standards has increased by an average of 1.2 per cent since 1983-84. The last time the measure of disposable income in Australia fell was in the Opposition's period of government in 1982-83. That is when it crashed. If the Opposition wants to know about that, it ought to have a look at the Budget Papers for 1988-89, where it is pointed out that household income fell by 2.5 per cent and by 2.7 per cent in the subsequent year compared with 1984-85 onwards, when there has been continuous growth except for 1986-87.

These speeches Senator Chaney makes begin with this stuff about living standards and then move on to `productivity now', and I will come to that in a minute. Senator Chaney has a happy conjunction of events at the present time.
Senator Stone interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Stone had a go this morning. I listened to him very respectfully in my room. I thought it was a very interesting speech, if I might say so. Senator Stone might do me the same courtesy. Senator Chaney thinks he has a happy conjunction of events at the present time with the comments by the Business Council of Australia about the level of national debt, some comments by the Macquarie Bank and so on. First of all, in response to what I think are the appropriate and thoughtful views put forward by members of the Business Council about the level of external debt in this country, let me say that we by no means retreat from the comments that have been made on that question of the external debt. There is an interesting comment on that issue in today's Australian Financial Review. It says this:

SPEECH.PARA: In the past couple of weeks the Business Council of Australia and Macquarie Bank have used some expert public relations to focus attention on private debt levels-in particular, debt to foreign lenders.
It used to be Government debt that everyone worried about, but the Hawke Government has turned that around and is now reducing debt levels.
But while high levels of private debt are also a worry, they are part of a much more complex set of issues.
The Business Council of Australia's 47 publicly listed members have a total of $49.8 billion in debt on their 1989 balance sheets, a rise of 15 per cent on the 1988 level . . .
The article goes on to say:

If the debt debate in Australia concentrates on the absolute levels of debt, whether foreign or local, it will get nowhere and achieve nothing. But if it arrives at a proper discussion of business management and the basic plumbing of capital flows, then the next six months could lead to some most important consequences.
Without wishing to tar all managers with the same brush, what happened during the 1980s was a significant increase in the level of management greed.

That is a comment which I think the Business Council people will face up to. I really think that they are prepared to face up to it. I do not condemn them for that; it is another observation about some of the things they have said.

Senator Chaney, in pursuit of this conjunction of support for making a new speech as distinct from the last one, refers to the Business Council of Australia, the Macquarie Bank and the report of the Industries Assistance Commission which was published recently. The IAC report states that this country has to get on with issues of micro-economic reform. I thought that the IAC report on human resources development and the issues that are currently referred to by most international economists as infrastructure development was a bit weak, but on the issue of micro-economic reform it stated that this country had to get on with some of those issues. I remind Senator Chaney that there is nothing new about the IAC saying that. It said it right through the 1970s when the present Opposition was in government. What did the Liberals do about waterfront issues, transport issues and tariffs? In 1987 the Liberal Government had a report from the IAC recommending a general reduction in tariffs. What did the Fraser Government say? It said, `Oh, no way'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, 1987. I am sorry; John Howard, the born-again--
—I apologise; 1977. I am sorry. Perhaps that could be corrected for me. That was said in 1977--
—I was trying to be helpful.
—Yes, I understand. Senator Chaney was trying to be helpful. Put that in Hansard. It is a record; it is the first time.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1977, the Fraser Government had a report from the IAC recommending a general reduction in tariffs and the Fraser Government walked right away from it. The Opposition lectures us about structural adjustment issues. What did the Fraser Government do about any of these things?

TALK.START.PARA: —What about tomorrow?

—This goes to the honourable senator's credibility. As one commentator said the other day in analysing the Foster's family package-the so-called economic statement-it has the usual characteristic of spinelessness. `Spinelessness' was the word used. An economics commentator for the Sydney Morning Herald said that about this so-called economic package.
—Is that the economics commentator that Keating said was hopeless?

—Probably; yes, he might have been. People say a lot of strange things up here. My simple point is that Senator Chaney gave a little talk about tariff reductions. He made a point about structural adjustment and reform and how we should get on with all of these issues. Throughout the 1970s the Liberals did nothing about these things.
—We are at the end of the 1980s. What are you going to do about it?

—I understand that. These judgments that I am making go to the character of the Liberal Party which allows it, as a political party, to bring forward a tax policy that will abolish the capital gains tax and introduce a speculative gains tax which will serve its master down at Fosters but will do nothing for the Australian community except distort investment decisions.
—What about your airline policy?
—I listened to Senator Chaney in silence.
—Order! The Leader of the Government should be heard in silence.

—That is what that policy will do. If Senator Vanstone wants to talk about the 1980s and 1990s, let us do that. My point is that there has been a 65 per cent reduction in tariffs since 1972 and not one percentage point of that was accomplished by a conservative government; not one percentage point in all that time. If the Liberals had displayed just a little courage and tackled some of these issues in the 1970s, we would not be talking today about the present levels of external debt. We would not be talking about current account deficits of the size we have today. We would not be talking about them to the same extent.
—Because you wouldn't be in government. That is true.
—Is that a bit of nostalgic thinking back to the days when Senator Chaney was a Minister?
—Well, you would not be in government.

—That may be so. I am talking about the country, not about the political fortunes of the collection of wimps over there. This country would not be confronted with the same sized problems that it has today. The present Opposition ran away from those things. So Opposition senators should not come in here talking about the Business Council, the Macquarie Bank, the IAC and all of the other things, because many of those issues involve their credibility as much as anything else. Senator Chaney sought to draw from the Macquarie Bank report the conclusion that this country was almost a bankrupt nation. That is gilding the lily a bit, because the bankrupt nations of the world are countries that have enormous government debts as well as private sector debts. I am not in any sense trying to belittle the problems of Australia's external debt, but let me make that very clear distinction.

SPEECH.PARA: Then Senator Chaney got onto the industrial relations system and so on. I want to make a couple of points on that matter. The Macquarie Bank makes them and all sorts of people make them; but, whatever the Opposition says about the accord or what other people want to say about it, it has brought about an enormous change in attitudes in this country. It is the umbrella under which industry can be restructured in a sensible and intelligent way; it is the umbrella under which attitudinal change is taking place in this country very rapidly; and it has been the umbrella for the containment of real unit labour costs, which have fallen by more than 14 per cent. I do not want to get into the argument today, because we had it yesterday, about nominal and real unit labour costs. What that has meant is that the profit share for Australian business has been its highest for 20 years, leading to a major investment surge-a 65 per cent increase over the last six years and now at a level of 13.5 per cent of gross domestic product. We used to be told in the past that business profitability was a good thing, and I believe it. I think it is, because it leads to investment. But that is one of the consequences in respect of which the accord has been a responsible and sensible contributor.

Professor Gruen and others at the Australian National University, in a recently conducted study into the accord, made the point-though they are not uncritical-that the great benefits in terms of employment growth and attitudinal change in Australian industry and their effect on corporate profitability have been quite significant and enormous. I understand Senator Chaney's argument and even he, when he is being frank, does not throw the baby out with the bath water. He says that there will still be a centralised wage fixation system for a few years after the Liberals get into office, if they ever do. I do not think there will be a centralised wage fixing system at all by the time they get into office, but hope springs eternal in Opposition hearts and Senator Chaney thinks that that will happen next year and that he will maintain the centralised wage fixation system for a while because that is a good thing for the country in terms of aggregate wages and some of these other things about which I have been talking and which are benefits of the accord.

Further reform of the workplace is under way and has to be under way and is continually on the Government's agenda of building on successes to date. Of course I am an advocate of the view that that reform should be as rapid as possible. I believe that enterprise flexibility can be achieved through plant level implementation of new awards, certified agreements and relaxation of demarcation rules. Senator Chaney says that I gave him only two examples last week. I will give him three or four today. I opened the new Nestle's plant at Blayney in New South Wales during the week. It is a one-union shop. It is a brilliant factory. They have, applying to that factory only, a Federal award which has been negotiated with the employees. These sorts of things are happening all over the place in addition to the certified agreements to which I have referred previously in this chamber.

Greater emphasis must be placed on skills and productivity in wage rounds. Award restructuring involves the most far-reaching labour market reform ever attempted in this country. Senator Chaney may say that it has not achieved much in the building industry and so on. There will always be places where it achieves better results than in others. One of the most important things for the manufacturing sector is that it will provide opportunities for career paths for workers in manufacturing plants. That is one of the biggest problems in this country at the present time which I face as Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. There is an up to 50 per cent turnover in manufacturing plants.

TALK.START.PARA: —Try absenteeism.

—Yes, all of those things. There are unique opportunities available to tackle the barriers to improved workplace efficiency and productivity and, provided that people take up those opportunities, there will be more satisfying career structures for Australian workers. Award restructuring processes can also be used for reforming award and union coverage, and it does require a little vision from management and a little activity and initiative from management as well. In most cases where it has been a success it has been management-initiated.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the Opposition's industrial relations vision, I am not here to condemn out of hand a lot of the things that Senator Chaney says. I think there is a lot of sense in some of them. A lot of people out there are not convinced. Bert Evans of the Metal Trades Industry Association was not convinced and Senator Chaney said that Bert Evans did not understand it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Set up a straw man.

—And a lot of other people out there do not understand it either, Senator Chaney. Ian Spicer of the Confederation of Australian Industry said that, although his organisation was attracted to a number of aspects of the Opposition's policy, it would not be advocating dismantling of the current award system and that there should be some form of registration of industry and enterprise agreements-which is precisely what this Government has provided for. Ken Croagh of the Victorian branch of the Australian Chamber of Manufactures questioned whether employers were ready to handle wage bargaining with an enterprise union outside the centralised system. It is a good question indeed. Of course, Senator Chaney himself has done something quite different. He has ruled out the need to register enterprise agreements with the Commission. I think that is a mistake. He says that the coalition has received senior advice that enterprise agreements would have the force of awards without being registered. But he says, `If the Attorney-General advises otherwise when we get into government, we will change it'. That is a very convenient route for the coalition to escape from that aspect of its policy.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats would like to move an amendment to this urgency motion, and I believe that in order to do so we require the suspension of Standing Orders. Therefore, at the request of Senator Haines, and pursuant to her contingent notice of motion, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Haines moving an amendment to the motion.

The proposal would be: after the words `to achieve a genuine' in line 2, to leave out the words `work-place based industrial relations system', and insert `co-operative management/worker industrial relations system'. Therefore, the amended urgency motion would read:

The need for the Government to accelerate the pace of reform to achieve a genuine co-operative management/worker industrial relations system which will allow Australians to work together more productively to reduce our foreign debt and to stop the slide in living standards.

In speaking to the motion to suspend Standing Orders, I suggest that that amendment does subtly-but not pedantically change the essence of the urgency motion. It addresses the other side of the equation in industrial relations, namely, the management side, as well as the worker side, and cites the need for a new climate of cooperation between both management and worker. I understand that that amendment is not unacceptable to the Government and the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you wish to speak to the suspension motion, Senator Chaney?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. I intervene very briefly to say that, now that I have heard the explanation from Senator McLean, it confirms what I indicated to him privately: I think that the amendment would in no way change what was intended by the motion. Certainly, the Opposition's view about `work-place based industrial relations' encompasses management and employees. On that basis, we would not wish to prolong any question about the suspension of Standing Orders. I think that Senator McLean could move his amendment by leave, which I believe would also be satisfactory to the Government, and Senator Button can speak for the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I can say that this is the first time in my experience here that the Democrats have made something marginally better.
—In order to regularise the matter, I will put the question for the suspension of Standing Orders, and that will solve the problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President, and the leaders of both the Government and the Opposition. I note that one supported the proposition with more grace than the other.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason why we propose the amendment and support the urgency motion in its amended form is that the Australian Democrats question the basic traditional attitudes of both unions and management to their relationship in the workplace. In fact, by this amendment, we are underlining the fact that an improvement in industrial relations in this country requires a revised attitude of both unions and management, and it it only through that that we will achieve the necessary new spirit of cooperation-one which has not historically been present in Australian industrial relations-which will allow the resolution of the problems which are cited in the remainder of the urgency motion.

Currently there are two basic industrial relations models in vogue in Australia, and it is not unreasonable that the centralised system is being embraced by a Labor government and a decentralised system is being embraced by the alternative government, the coalition. We believe that both of these models should be reformed to include far more opportunities for cooperation between management and workers. When the Opposition comes into power again-whenever that is-Australian industrial relations will move in the direction favoured by Senator Chaney in this motion. It is the Australian Democrats' view that any change, however, must be a slow and incremental one, and must comply with several fundamental bottom line elements which protect basic workers' rights. Today what I am in fact doing is foreshadowing for Senator Chaney the position that would be taken by the Australian Democrats in relation to substantial changes in industrial relations which would eventuate should there be a change in government.

In December 1988 in the debate on the industrial relations legislation in this place we accepted that there were two genuine alternative models of industrial relations and made the point that it was not reasonable for the Opposition at that time to expect us to support a series of amendments-in fact, in excess of 100 amendments-which were born of its decentralised model in an attempt to force them into an Act which was being proposed by a Labor government and which was born of a centralised philosophy of industrial relations.

In making that point we accept the fact that we foreshadowed that, if there were to be a change of government, we would, of course, expect that the alternative model would be advanced very quickly by the Opposition. This has been the subject of quite long discussions between Senator Chaney, me, my colleagues in the New South Wales upper House and the New South Wales Minister for Industrial Relations, because the alternative model is in fact being advanced in that State fairly quickly, and quite reasonably so. During very open and constructive discussions we have previously acknowledged the fact that we see much merit in the alternative model. However, I think in those discussions we have said there are a number of bottom lines which the Democrats require of either model. Let me state some of them. There must be a guaranteed minimum income; that is, an income support scheme must be in place before any serious change is contemplated. What I am doing is foreshadowing a requirement by the Australian Democrats that the Opposition must address, in parallel and simultaneously, legislation which ensures an income support scheme-a guaranteed minimum income for Australian workers and even, in fact, non-workers. I will develop that point later.

Poverty prevention must be an absolute priority. Any potential poverty traps must be identified and nullified before a new industrial relations system is implemented. Later I will identify what I consider to be a very real threat of a poverty trap, that is, the automatic removal of unemployment benefits after a statutory period of, say, six months. I see that as being a potential poverty trap for the genuinely unemployed in this country, who would find themselves unemployed with zero income. I believe that these are serious challenges for the Opposition in considering its alternative model. The alternative model must acknowledge the fact that there is a possibility of serious erosion of conditions that have been achieved by workers. As opposed to the dollars and cents dimensions of what people want from work, there are also serious conditions. The alternative model must address seriously the whole dimension of work conditions and ensure the non-erosion of hard-won work conditions.

We must find an acceptable definition of productivity, if the productivity model is to prove workable. There are positive and negative aspects to both the definition and the measurement of productivity, and the alternative model must address those. The difficulties associated with the definition and measurement of productivity must be acknowledged and we believe that the negative ones must be modified and discounted.

The Democrats see an inherent danger in the ultimate power and responsibility for industrial relations being given to employers, and we see that as a possible outcome of the alternative model. I see that Senator Parer is shaking his head, but we see it as being a possible outcome of the alternative model. the possible use of the principle of divide and conquer would be totally unacceptable to us. Some of the frayed edges of industrial relations at present-cases such as the proposal to do away with maternity leave in defence-related industries-give an indication of this process of erosion of conditions by which individuals, in arriving at agreements with employers, can seriously negate or erode the unity of conditions in the workplace.

I will deal with the need for increased cooperation between management and unions. We must achieve greater involvement of workers and management in setting long term goals for their enterprise, such as increasing productivity and output, increasing skills of workers and management through training and retraining schemes, and increasing penetration of foreign markets. It is only by agreement and cooperation between both workers and management that this will be achieved. We should also facilitate increased sharing by workers of management decisions and encourage profit sharing.

The certified agreements provisions in the Industrial Relations Act 1988 enable enterprise bargaining after the Industrial Relations Commission has given its approval. As Senator Button has already said, we are already slowly moving towards enterprise based unions. We must see how well the current provisions work before going further in that direction. It is interesting that there is a contradiction between the principle which has been espoused by the Government of, on the one hand, fewer and larger unions and, on the other hand, the progression towards enterprise based unions, which would lead to a proliferation of unions. I simply cite that as being a contradiction in the position that seems to be newly being taken by both the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in recent days.

Attending to the just and valid needs and claims of workers leads to increased commitment on the part of the workers and increased productivity and profitability. Looking after workers is a very profitable undertaking. For instance, IBM Australia Ltd has introduced several benefits which were considered radical at the time but which have increased worker satisfaction and work force stability and productivity. These include free workplace based child-care facilities, free education in computer services for employees' children in school holidays, free overseas travel incentives, and an active equal employment opportunity policy, including an office dedicated to equal employment opportunity.

On Saturday morning those of us who read the Australian newspaper were told by Paul Kelly the `shocking news'-they were his words-that enterprise wage deals were inevitable. In his article, Paul Kelly observed:
. . . the irony this week is that while Mr Hawke was slamming the Coalition for its obsession with Labor market deregulation, Mr Keating was actually promising to pinch this Liberal policy.

And to whom was the Treasurer making such promises? He was making them to Japanese investors, who have kindly lent us 18.9 per cent of our gross debt. Japan is our biggest single creditor country. If the Japanese decide not to roll over-that is, to re-lend-our debt when it falls due, Australia immediately becomes a banana republic. This shift in Australian Labor Party policy bemuses those of us who took part in a prolonged debate in December last year to enact the current Industrial Relations Act when, over and over again Labor espoused the centralised model and, in fact, won our support for its enactment, but now we find that that very model, which was enacted just a year ago, is in recent statements by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer virtually being contradicted. The Hansard of that debate will make quite fascinating reading in retrospect.

There is considerable merit, as the Australian Democrats accept, in the alternative model. We believe it should be embraced slowly and sequentially. I have attempted to outline for the Opposition our bottom line requirements in that progression. I move:
After `to achieve a genuine' in line 2, leave out `work-place based industrial relations system', insert `co-operative management/worker industrial relations system'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the urgency motion moved by my Leader, Senator Chaney, to which Senator McLean has moved an amendment. I would also like to support what Senator Chaney said. Basically, I do not see a lot of difference between the motion and the amendment. In fact, the enterprise type agreements as spelt out in the coalition's industrial relations policy automatically assume a better industrial relations system under enterprises, with management and workers cooperating.

SPEECH.PARA: The past two years have seen the worst terms of trade out of the past 10 years. After nearly seven years of Labor government, this country is approaching an economic crisis. It is not just me standing in the Senate saying that; that is the view of almost every observer around this country. Since this Government came to power, our net foreign debt has increased from $33 billion to $110 billion. It has been estimated that our net foreign debt is increasing every 20 days at a rate equivalent to Australia's total sugar exports for a full year. That is the nature of the increase in the foreign debt of this country. Current account deficits are running at about $2 billion a month and the figure for a full year is now expected to be more than $20 billion for the coming year. That is yet another record for this Hawke-Keating Government-a disgraceful record. This country's interest rates are among the highest in the Western world and are the highest in our history. The inflation rate is locked in at around 8 per cent, which compares with 3 per cent for Japan and 5.3 per cent for the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development average.

In the face of this quite appalling situation, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who is out of touch, is wandering around trying to convince people that high interest rates are good for them, that the size of our foreign debt is not a problem, that there is no airline dispute, and that no children in Australia are living in poverty. One cannot help but remind the Prime Minister of that little poem by Hughes Mearns. I see that Senator Tate is smiling-he knows the poem:
As I was going up the stair
I met a man who wasn't there.
He wasn't there again today.
I wish, I wish he'd stay away.
Someone should remind the Prime Minister of that poem.

The Prime Minister claims that the cause of our problems is, on the one hand, that Australians spend too much on imported consumption goods and that the way to fix that is to jack up interest rates with tight monetary policy. He has done that but it has not worked. On the other hand, he claims that the reason our imports are too high is high imports of capital goods for investment which will be beneficial in the long run. They are the two statements made by the Government in relation to this matter. However, neither the Prime Minister nor the Government can have it both ways. What the Government will not admit is that the cause of our problem is that, except in the mining and primary production areas, where we are blessed by nature, we are just not competitive with the rest of the world. We are unable to make the goods that people want or need and, with a few relatively minor exceptions, we cannot compete on world markets with our manufactures.

An obvious area in which we could make a substantial increase in exports is the secondary processing of our exported commodities. This fact has been known for years; there is nothing new about it, but it seems to have been discovered only in recent times. With few exceptions, this is not being done because it is simply more economic to process overseas. That is a terrible indictment of the situation in which we find ourselves, and a major reason for it is that we persist with an antiquated centralised industrial relations system which guarantees-and has in time guaranteed-low productivity and an absolutely disgraceful reputation for industrial disputation. In that area, regrettably, our record with our trading partners throughout the world is second to none.

As pointed out by the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) and others, we must increase our exports by 6 per cent a year for the next five years just to stabilise-not to improve but just to stabilise-our existing position. Urgent and immediate reform of the system is needed. I am not talking about the workers or individual unions. The system is at fault. The thrust of the coalition's industrial relations policy to get Australia back on track is to move towards enterprise based industrial relations. When this policy was launched some years ago-I think it was 1986-not unexpectedly the Labor Government forecast disaster if it was implemented. The sole reason for opposition was that it represented a change which would have diminished entrenched power bases. Its opposition had nothing to do with what was best for Australia: it was a reaction to protect its comrades at the top of the heap under the centralised system.

It is interesting to note that, notwithstanding the earlier vilification, we now have senior Ministers such as Senator Button, and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) when he was in Tokyo recently, talking about enterprise based agreements. I quote in particular Senator Button when talking to reporter Pru Goward as recently as 20 November:
First of all, let me say there's a lot of, I think, rigidity in the Australian labour market, as the Treasurer observed nearly a year ago. Labour market reform has to be a priority.

The centralised wage-fixation system, in my view, has served this country very well in a very difficult period of structural adjustment. If we hadn't had it, we wouldn't have had the employment growth we've had: we would have been in much more difficulty than we are now as a country.
That comment was made on the basis of the system as it was, without change. Senator Button continued:
But always I have felt, and I think this view would be shared by my colleagues-
it would be interesting to ascertain whether Senator Burns agrees with this view-
that as time goes by, we have to gradually liberalise that system, round the edges.

`Round the edges'-fiddling around the edges. That is what Senator Button said. Then the Treasurer visited Japan, and I think it is worth quoting some of the remarks he made to the Japanese, bearing in mind that he was talking to one of the great post-war success stories-the Japanese. He made a speech to Nomura Securities and dealt specifically with the industrial relations system and wages policy. He said:
I fully appreciate that Australia's industrial relations record has been a bone of contention with some of the people and companies in this nation with whom we deal.

That is one of the greatest understatements I have heard. I dealt with the Japanese in the period between 1970 and 1983. It was more than a bone of contention. It cost this country billions of dollars in lost export income. At least the Treasurer recognised this because he stated:
. . . I fully accept that Australia's industrial relations record fell well short of what was desirable.
That statement from the Treasurer was absolutely correct. The recognition was there, but he then talked about moving to an enterprise-based system and attempted to define it. He stated:

. . . an exciting and fundamental process of labour market reform . . . The challenge now is to further develop the process whereby enterprises can deal directly with their workforce, as occurs in Japan.
Did he really mean that such a process occurs in Japan? He went on further to state:
And it is the Accord processes, along with the Industrial Relations Commission, that is bringing this about.
He further stated:

. . . while there is a widespread recognition that wage negotiations must have an increasing enterprise focus, there is also an acceptance that this process must be underpinned by the continuing role for Australia's Industrial Relations Commission and the Accord to ensure effective aggregate wage constraint.

The Japanese would have laughed themselves silly because, through their trading companies, they know as much about industrial relations as most people in this country, perhaps even more. To say in one breath that we will have the same system as that in Japan and then go on and qualify it by referring to a centralised system which does not exist over there would make them wonder what was happening. In fact, what the Japanese understand to be an enterprise-based wages system is similar, if not almost identical, to the proposals contained in the Opposition's policy. The tentative proposals of Senator Button and Mr Keating are totally different and will not get Australia back on track. I think it is important that we define the difference.

Under the Liberal-National Party proposals as outlined in detail in our industrial relations policy, we want to see agreements reached within an enterprise by employees of that enterprise and its own management. Let us make that clear. This will guarantee productivity increases which will be to the benefit of the employees, the enterprise and the nation. It must be made clear that our approach does not involve squeezing anyone down or knocking anyone over; rather, it involves improving the position of this country and of individuals. Our approach would ensure that the situation is better than it was before and would get us off the downhill path towards a banana republic which is happening as a result of the foreign debt and other matters about which I spoke.

When Labor talks about enterprise agreements, it is analogous with the Prime Minister saying that there is no airline dispute. Based on the Swedish system, the Labor Government wants fewer and more powerful unions, with a single monopoly union under the auspices of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) negotiating with a number of enterprises. It would involve a single union and a number of enterprises. This is doomed to fail because it will involve a number of agreements each basically the same. It gives meaning to the words used by Senator Button which I quoted earlier: `We have to gradually liberalise that system, round the edges'. That does not involve any real micro-economic reform. There is a lot of talk about it, but nothing serious is done.

The Labor Party approach is exemplified by the in-principle waterfront agreement. Time does not permit my canvassing that matter but, once we decide to have an enterprise agreement with one union-and a recognised militant union, the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia, dealing with half a dozen stevedores on the basis of what they call enterprise agreements-we can back it in that each one of those agreements will contain almost identical work practices, hours of work, et cetera. How on earth can they be called enterprise agreements? I see that Senator Burns is laughing. He knows that it is a joke. In today's Australian Financial Review Mr Kelty is reported as saying:
. . . no objections to paying negotiations at the enterprise level provided they were carried out within the centralised wage-fixing system.

We cannot have it both ways. We either have an enterprise-type agreement or we do not. Let me give an example of one of the few genuine enterprise agreements in Australia and how it came to pass. I refer briefly to Power Brewing. To start off with, it did not want an enterprise agreement. It wanted a separate industrial agreement which is the normal way that breweries operate. However, when it came to settling the terms of that agreement, the officials of the liquor Trades Union turned up at Power Brewing. The union delegates on site had asked whether they could be present and when the union officials arrived they asked who those people were. When told that they were the union delegates on site they said, `We're not going to discuss the agreement in front of them'. There was a row and the union leaders left in a huff. The delegates called a mass meeting of their men and said, `Guess what happened to us? We do not want anything to do with this union'. In fact, I am led to believe that the language was much more colourful than that, but the result was that they ended up with an enterprise agreement or, as it is in Queensland, a voluntary employment agreement.

I will not have time to cover all the points that I wished to cover. No-one would deny that there is a role for unions in the future, but it has to be a changed role. It cannot be the role that has existed for the past 40 or 50 years, although it may have served us well. It is sheer lunacy for a peak body to agree with a government to share productivity across the board, irrespective of who has contributed to that productivity. It is interesting to compare such an approach with the attitudes of the real success stories of Japan, Korea and Taiwan. Senator Burns, who is to follow me in this debate, had the experience last year of seeing that different approach. Over there the attitude is that if someone can afford to pay because he happens to be successful, that is good but, if he cannot do so, companies are built up and not destroyed so that the nation can get into manufacturing and import replacement, so it can be responsible for reducing its current account deficit and so it can create jobs--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no disagreement with what the motion says, particularly as amended by the Australian Democrats, because any sane person in this country would want to see better living standards. They must be based on better productivity and greater wealth in the community. If that is to occur it has to be as a result of recognition of the importance of workers and their right to dignity and equity in discussion and in the outcomes. I would like to answer, quickly, a few of Senator Parer's comments. He talked about Japan. A lot of what he said is true, but Japan's culture is completely different from ours. A stark way to illustrate this, although I do not want to go back to the war, would be to say that it had Kamikaze pilots. I would not imagine Australia being able to get anyone to do what they did. I just point out that the Japanese had and have a different culture. One cannot take a little bit out of a culture, say that it is good and forget about its background.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Parer knows better than to say that all enterprise agreements are the same. Of the many enterprise agreements existing under the old system of 29a agreements under the old industrial relations legislation, there are many differences depending on the approach to management by various companies and the response of employees. Prime Minister Hawke never said that we do not have a foreign debt problem. He said that we do and that we must take it into consideration and work at it.

Senator Chaney mentioned the need to do something about reduced living standards. I agree with that. When people talk about prosperity and the economy being balanced and in a proper condition, they talk about the balance of payments being right, there being a surplus in the Budget, the credit rating being strong and the dollar being strong so that the country can trade competitively. However, at the same time, a large number of people in the community could be very poor, unemployed and without hope. But some people would say, `That is good. The economy is going all right. Why worry about it?'.

Senator Chaney also talked about the top down approach as though unions have such an approach: they do not. All the trade unions I know of that are worth their salt are very keen on the pyramid approach where the power and the authority come from the bottom up. The authority is among the rank and file. Obviously they get input from those at the top level who may be better educated and have more experience in how to operate. Certainly, people at the rank and file level are given authority.

Senator Chaney mentioned the Sanctuary Cove agreement as though it was a catastrophe. The Trades and Labour Council in Queensland negotiated that agreement collectively. One union refused to sign it, but it made no difference. Other unions would have accepted it and, to all intents and purposes, the agreement would have operated. That union had a right to contest it in law in terms of the arbitration legislation and it did so.
