When we look at the record of coalition governments, as opposed to what this Government stands for and has achieved, we find that since 1949 the coalition has opposed all wage increases. Ultimately in 1982 it brought in a wage freeze. How anybody who was part of a coalition government which brought in a wage freeze can talk about having concern for reduced living standards is beyond me. Fred appears to be quite sincere in what he says. Maybe he does not understand what reduced living standards are because his living standards have never been reduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! When Senator Burns refers to a senator he should use his proper title.

—I accept your advice, Mr Acting Deputy President. The coalition has also used penalties in every circumstance where there has been an industrial dispute. It has encouraged employers not to go to the bargaining table and not to fix up what may be a festering problem by saying, `You can use penalties. We will not look at the merit of the case. We will just fine people #500 a day'. It was #500 in those days-it is now $1,000 per day-as each day was considered a new dispute. It encouraged Mudginberri and Dollar Sweets and so on to use sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act. In Queensland there is the Essential Services Act, the Industrial (Commercial Practices) Act 1984 and the Electricity (Continuity of Supply) Act 1985. When an electricity strike causes a fundamental breach of contract, the contract is cancelled immediately and people can be dismissed immediately. People can be dismissed without notice from employment and suspended from employment without pay for such periods as an employer thinks fit. No-one has the right to question that. It is written into legislation and is very clear.

SPEECH.PARA: Is that what the Liberal Party stands for? Does it stand for the type of thing that has occurred in Queensland, which reinforces the right of the employer not to renegotiate? It does not talk about issues such as safety and life threatening problems that it will not apply to. Are companies right to refuse to negotiate and to deny the rights of people on the job to take industrial action? That is something which I reject. The people of this country have rejected it time and again and they will continue to do so. The Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Peter Morris, put out a press release on the New South Wales Government's new industrial relations discord stating:

The proposals also attempt to ban industrial action for the duration of an award or an agreement (1-3 years). This will lead to bigger, longer and more bitter industrial disputes when awards/agreements come up for renewal.
The introduction of harsh penalties will do nothing to stem disruption, but will only make it worse.

I concur absolutely with that. We cannot bludgeon people into accepting positions. We cannot legislate to force people to accept an unfair and inequitable position. What is the coalition's position? I refer to a paper presented by Mr Justice W. K. Fisher at the University of New South Wales. He quoted Senator Chaney, when being interviewed by the Australian, as saying:

The mistaken belief about the Opposition's industrial relations policy is that under a Coalition government, wages would be set by enterprise-based bargaining. They wouldn't. At least not for a long time.
According to Opposition Industrial relations spokesman Senator Fred Chaney, during the first few years of a Peacock government, the centralised wage system would rule.
Apparently Senator Chaney thinks it is a great idea. The article goes on:
The Industrial Relations Commission (IRC) would set wages for the majority of Australia's workers and-after being given new teeth to enforce compliance-would be stronger under a Coalition government.

Again, Senator Chaney is going to use the system we use, the centralised system, but he is not going to talk to the trade unions about it. He will not get any agreement; he will bludgeon them with penalties. He wants greater penalties, more teeth. In a speech at the Sydney Hilton Hotel Mr Peter Morris said:
For the first time in years Australians have a clear policy choice between the Government and the aspirants in the opposition.
The choice is between hard fact and fairytales, real experience and armchair theory.
The conservative alternative has not shown that it can restrain overall wage growth; indeed it has shown the opposite.
And what is more, the architects of the 1981-82 wages blow-out have not changed . . .

I do not deny that the trade unions had a role in that, but they have learned by it. The 1972-1975 Labor Government went through periods of inflation and high wage increases. We have learned from that; but it does not seem that the old recycled team of Peacock, Howard, Hewson and Senator Stone have learned from it. They are hardly the people I would look to for guidance on the future of this country. Further, Senator Chaney said in a press release:
Higher productivity is essential if this country is to tackle its balance of payments and foreign debt problems . . .
That is true. One could not argue with that. I agree absolutely. Senator Chaney continued:
The present Federal Labor Government appears incapable of taking the measures necessary to boost productivity.

I will get to that in a moment. Before I do, let us look at an example of the people in the grain industry who are represented by the National Party of Australia and the Liberal Party of Australia. The Australian Wheat Board indicated that it would load a ship in Brisbane. It was told that if a union worker was used to supervise loading, a first-aid officer would be required on the wharf. I believe that someone should be there to ensure maximum safety for people who work in those sorts of industries and are subject to serious injury. As a result of the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority (WIRA) reaching agreement with the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia and stevedoring companies, there will be a 72 per cent cut in manning levels on ships loaded at the Brisbane Fisherman's Island grain terminal. The number of waterside workers was cut from six to 1.6 per shift.

If somebody had told Senator Parer and Senator Chaney 10 years ago that that was going to happen they would have laughed, and so would I. That is a pretty fair gain, and I do not think the Opposition should be too greedy. It should allow further discussion to take place on achieving another system which would ensure the safety of the waterside workers but would also look at maximising productivity capacity.

In relation to the enterprise agreements, I mentioned a while ago that the provision existed under section 29a of the old industrial relations legislation. But we talk here about certified agreements. Section 115 (1) of the Industrial Relations Act 1988 states:
If the parties to an industrial dispute or any of them agree on terms for the settlement of all or any of the matters in dispute, they may make a memorandum of the terms agreed on.
Section 115 (2) states:
The memorandum of agreement shall specify the period for which the agreement is to continue in force.

The section goes on to talk about how this will occur. This is an agreement that can be negotiated between the workers and the management in an enterprise. One thing is certain: that should not occur without the right of union members to be represented. Certainly the employers would be represented. It is worth citing again the answer given by Laurie Carmichael in evidence in the inquiry leading up to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology entitled Manufacturing Industry Revitalisation: Making it together. Laurie Carmichael said:

The trade unions represent [that] professional advice to the work force and to deny the work force the right to that trade union representation is to deny equity and to confirm the inequality of power in the work place.

We can have enterprise agreements under the framework of the Industrial Relations Act. Such agreements will be freely entered into and should be honoured. They would not be thrust upon people from above but would be agreed within the framework of understanding the economic needs of this country in terms of wage restraint, and the way in which the saving in wages has been directed to profits among certain employers and companies, some of which have wisely reinvested in better machinery, better training for management, better management approaches. We understand that. The trade unions are mindful of that.

Senator Chaney, and probably Senator Parer, said that the union structure was obstructive. I agree that no organisation such as a trade union that has been in existence for 70 or 80 years should retain the same structure. One must move with the times. One must look to the future, be creative and put forward ideas which will contribute to the whole and are in the interests of the community. It was mentioned that industry unions would not eliminate one union in the workplace, but that is not true. They would. There would be one union in the enterprise and one in the industry; there would not be one union in each enterprise. Of course, unionists in those enterprises should have the right to have the framework of support and advice from a properly and democratically structured trade union movement.

Another thing this Government has done in practical terms is to offer workplace resource centres. They will be used to set objectives and goals, to redesign individual or group jobs and to further understanding of motivation and morale strategies and develop and administer in-house training programs. This can work only if there is trust and belief between the parties. But the Government as a third party is doing its job, accepting its responsibility to provide some support in setting up those things. In the final analysis, the difference between somebody who has the right to strike and somebody who does not is that between a free man and a slave. There is no doubt about it. As I said, it eliminates the need for any employer to negotiate genuinely. But the question of the use of that right to strike is another matter. We should develop the concept of cooperation in the interests of the community, as the motion says; but it has to be done in a way whereby, as I said, people's rights and their dignity in the community are recognised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the urgency motion moved by Senator Chaney and amended by the Australian Democrats to read:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to accelerate the pace of reform to achieve a genuine cooperative management/worker industrial relations system which will allow Australians to work together more productively to reduce our foreign debt and to stop the slide in living standards.

I take it from remarks made by those on the other side of the chamber and by a number of interested parties through the media that the Government would support this motion but would prefer to have after it, in brackets, (but only if the unions are involved). I think that therein lies the difference.

There is no need for me to spell out what sort of trouble the Australian economy is in. Suffice it to say that we are in trouble-big trouble. We have escalating foreign debt, declining living standards and phenomenally high interest rates. One does not need to go on. The Government's solution, as offered today, seems to be a bit more of the same. It says that things are a bit better than last year and will probably be a bit better next year. We say that that is not enough. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) likens the economy to a glass of champagne that is simply too effervescent and bubbling over. Meanwhile, people with mortgages or with loans for business in South Australia-where they will have the opportunity to send a message to Canberra in the next week or so-and in every other State and Territory are drowning in a sea of interest rate increases. For years the coalition has repeatedly said, as Senator Chaney pointed out, that one of the fundamental problems we have at present is our rigid labour market system, our centralised wage-fixing system. Not everybody agreed with us when we first canvassed this issue. It might be instructive to consider what our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said in 1985. He said:

How can one possibly talk about applying an economic policy if one has abandoned a whole incomes policy situation and said that wages and salaries in this country will be determined not within a centralised system but by allowing negotiation and the exercising of bargaining strength to take place in industry after industry and in enterprise after enterprise?

Although the Prime Minister said that in 1985, he seems to have had a change of heart. Headlines in the newspapers in the last couple of days have the Prime Minister urging business to move towards enterprise-based negotiations. The Prime Minister, the Treasurer and many others are now finally acknowledging the urgent need to deregulate our labour market. Recently in Japan the Treasurer gave an extraordinary speech to Nomura Securities. On the one hand he attempted to endorse some of the better elements of the coalition's industrial relations policy, saying to the Japanese that we need to operate more like the Japanese management; but, on the other hand, as Senator Parer pointed out, tacking on conditions saying that we want to act like Japan, but not really like Japan. In other words, we want to have our cake and eat it too. We just cannot have it that way.

In the last couple of days much mention has been made of enterprise-based agreements. On the surface it might appear to the casual observer that the coalition had won this debate and that there was now unanimous agreement that we have to work towards enterprise-based agreements. That would be a good thing. It gives power to the people who need it, the people on the shop floor, to negotiate directly with their employers should they so choose. I am loath to understand why some people do not seem to agree with this. But when we scratch the surface of that apparent agreement we see a very different picture. We see the Australian Labor Party very strongly still in the vice-like grip of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, acknowledging that there is a need to go towards enterprise-based agreements but knowing that its legs would be cut off by the ACTU if any attempt were made to move that way without involving the unions and keeping the union hand in there.

I make it quite clear that the coalition is not suggesting that unions have no place in industrial relations negotiations; quite the opposite. Our policy spells out that, where employers and employees choose to make a voluntary agreement between themselves, employees specifically retain the right to nominate a union to negotiate on their behalf. There is no question of coalition policy trying to muscle out unions or to legislate against their capacity to represent workers. The policy very much protects the right of workers to nominate a union to do that for them. That is the difference. We protect the right of the workers to seek the union's assistance should they so choose, whereas the Labor Party wants to protect the right of the unions to negotiate on behalf of workers whether the workers want them or not. That is probably a key difference.

The Labor Party says that it wants enterprise-based agreements; but it says that union restructuring, award restructuring, must come first. I am at a loss to see why, albeit I can see that some restructuring of the union movement and, in some cases, award restructuring might make a contribution. However, this is certainly not a complete barrier to moving towards deregulating the labour market now. The Government says that in any event these agreements must be approved by the Industrial Relations Commission. In other words, the employees and employers can discuss what they will and come to what agreement they will; but, if the Industrial Relations Commission does not like it, bad luck. In order for these agreements to get certification from the Industrial Relations Commission, they will have to look very much the same as each other, as Senator Parer pointed out in his earlier remarks.

I would like to draw the Senate's attention to some of the reasons why it is so important that we give power back to the workplace to negotiate the wages and conditions that suit the workers in that industry and in that enterprise rather than trying to come to some sort of lowest common denominator that suits that industry across the nation. When one considers that two-thirds of the Australian work force is not unionised, one can see that not everybody in the work force is that impressed with what unions have been doing with them. Australian unions have less support than one might imagine. Two-thirds of Australian workers have made their views clear by not being unionised. One might therefore ask how unions survive. They survive in the current form because of the ludicrous situation whereby about 85 per cent of the work force is covered by awards even though they are not in the relevant unions. In fact, this non-union labour is roped in, irrespective of its will, to be covered by these awards.

The Government will not encourage for one minute the development of enterprise-based agreements until it can be sure that the unions will retain this protected position. The coalition says that there is no need to wait. We can immediately give Australian workers the right to negotiate on their own behalf-give them the right, not badger them into it as the previous speaker, Senator Burns, seemed to believe we were attempting to do. We would give them the right to choose to negotiate on their own behalf or to have a union do so if they would prefer that. The Government seems to believe that the Australian work force is simply incapable of doing this; but we say that workers should have the right to negotiate on their own behalf with their employees. We can offer this choice, and that is what it is-a choice.

Those who are happy in the central system, who like the protection it offers, who are comfortable in it and are reluctant to enter a deregulated market-I speak in the sense of employees and employers, because not everybody has the strength of ICI Australia Ltd and Comalco Ltd to hop out into the big, wide world immediately-can stay in the central system. But those who choose to opt out, who have confidence in themselves and their capacity, who believe that employers and employees together can come to a better deal for both, are welcome to do that under our system. They are not going out into a completely unprotected area; workers would be protected by a minimum hourly rate and, as I say, should they choose would have the right to nominate a union to act on their behalf. In that respect, I make some remarks to Senator McLean who earlier said that he was very concerned about the rate of progress the Opposition, when in government, would choose to make.

Under the system that I have outlined, the rate of progress is left up to the employers and employees and they can go as quickly or as slowly as they feel capable of doing. This is not a change driven by a government standing behind them with some sort of lash; it is a change that gives people the opportunity to have a greater control over their own lives as employers and employees, should they so choose. The Labor Party does not put much faith in the capacity of its work force to act without the big brother unions and the Industrial Relations Commission. In other words, it is not letting the workers out of the club.

Labor makes much of its interest in status of women matters. I remember, as might Senator Knowles, and you, Madam Acting Deputy President, attending a ceremony to look at a tapestry that we gave to the United Kingdom. The tapestry said: `Trust the women, Mother, as I have done'. It was created to encourage the United Kingdom to give women the vote as we had done in Australia. I say that, if we can trust women to vote, we can trust them to negotiate their own working conditions. It seems eminently obvious. The Government, in its affirmative action legislation, made it a required step for employers to consult their female employees. The Government in the legislation effectively told employers that they must listen to the women. But when it comes to wages and conditions, the Government says no. Women still have to listen to the unions and to the Industrial Relations Commission. Why not trust the women to negotiate if they choose to do so?

I concentrate, albeit briefly, on the position of women not only because the Government chooses to make much of its, at the moment, somewhat limited contribution to advancing the status of women but also because what women are doing in relation to unions is very interesting. They are voting with their feet to show the unions what they think unions can do and have done for them. In other words, women do not think much of unions. They know that they have been distanced from decision making in the workplace. The decisions are made by union bosses, in other States in all probability. Women are not adequately consulted and they know that. Women are effectively locked out of the union hierarchy. A few women hold positions of status in unions, some of whom have done a very good job. But there are very few of them.

It might be worth while to consider just a few of the statistics to see what Australian women, who will be playing such an important part in dismissing this Government at the earliest opportunity, have to say. Let me quote from an article by Sue Neales, a journalist with the Australian Financial Review, in her Corporate Women column very appropriately headlined `Shrinking unions jump on the female bandwagon'. She points out:
But statistics show that it is the female workers who are turning away from unions in droves. In 1976, when only 1.8 million women worked, 43 per cent belonged to their relevant unions.
But last year, the number of women with jobs had climbed by 800,000 to 2.6 million.

The interesting thing is that now only 35 per cent of them are choosing to join a union, a drop from 43 per cent to 35 per cent. The unions can see the writing on the wall because they are not doing the job. They are not doing a good enough job in representing women. That is why women are giving them the boot. The article continues:
Since 1976, the number of women joining the work-force was up by 38 per cent, but the increase in female union members was only 16 per cent.
Of the 1.5 million new jobs created by the Hawke Government-
allegedly created, as the Government says it created the good things and discarded the bad-
only 100,000 are now filled by union members.

The Opposition says to the Government: move now to give women the right to choose whether to stay in the central system or to negotiate their own wages and conditions with their employers; give all workers, irrespective of their sex, this choice; give industry a chance to show some innovation in the wages and conditions that it offers; get the employer and the employee together and the outcome will be a happier work force, a more productive work force and more profitable companies. That has to be a good thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing a matter of urgency, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to accelerate the pace of reform to achieve a genuine workplace-based industrial relations system which will allow Australians to work together more productively to reduce our foreign debt and to stop the slide in living standards.

Senator McLean has added to the original motion the expression, `a genuine cooperative management/worker industrial relations system', which I think improves the original motion. The reality is that this is exactly what this Government is doing. I take up the very last point that was mentioned by Senator Vanstone, namely, the position of women. At the beginning of its term the Government, with the accord, set in place a measure to make sure that the unemployment that we inherited from the Fraser Government would be eliminated. The particular beneficiaries of that action have been women in this country. Thousands of women have entered the work force for the first time. The greatest increase in women entering the work force has occurred during the period of this Government. So, that accord not only laid the general basis for an improvement in the real standard of living, as Senator Button has pointed out, but also started the Hawke Government's emphasis on cooperation.

This Government then moved to the critical area of establishing the framework of award restructuring. The metal industry is a classic example of where a major change, an historic change, is taking place in industry. There has never been such a qualitative change in industry as this Government initiated. In the past things that it was said would never be done are actually being done. The examination of work practices and the beginning of the examination of management practices are changing the face of Australian industry. Industry agreements in the steel, textile, shipbuilding and heavy engineering industries, which represent micro-economic reform, are of particular credit to Senator Button. We can go through a whole litany of industries that were in difficulty but have been helped and supported by this Government which has created a genuine change both in industry and in industrial relations. All of the changes were on the basis of a tripartite system of working through the problems which consisted of issues that had stagnated for decades but that this Government grabbed hold of.

We went from the experience we had in the Fraser years when thundering statements from Ministers-I remember that Senator Chaney was one of those Ministers-were made but where neglect, distrust and disputes were the order of the day. During the period that this Government has been in office we have set about having the supportive mechanisms so that change can take place. We have been successful because a mobilising of goodwill has occurred in contrast to the situation in the previous decades. This Government has the runs on the board because it has been able to persuade unions and employers to work together more productively-as the matter of urgency says-identifying the problems and seeking solutions.

The mention of unions separates the position of the Government from that of the Opposition. Senator Chaney talks about reform of the labour market. The Opposition has a problem. It wants to weaken or eliminate unions. It wants, at least, to deny them, because it tries to say nothing about unions most of the time. Senator Burns has pointed out that Senator Chaney has said that the Opposition will allow the central wage system to last for some time while he adds some pressures for compliance by unions. That is a sort of a compromise on the basic thrust of the Opposition which on the extreme side, as you will appreciate, Madam Acting Deputy President, is enterprise unions on the Queensland model and on the other side is just a general acceptance of attacks on unions, attempting to undermine the balancing between capital and labour.

The unions are the main weapon that wage and salary earners have to establish their general standards of income and their disposable income. When the Opposition talks of enterprise agreements, it means that it wants enterprise unions. I would like to talk about this in a practical way. It is one thing to talk about labour market deregulation. The coalition means, when it says labour market deregulation, something like this. Take a classic company of 50 to 100 employees which now has a framework of national industrial negotiation. The unions have the ability in that system through awards to lay down the standards by argument before the Commission. Employers and unions appear before the Commission and a standard is laid down. This has been ignored by Senator Vanstone in the speech she just made. She forgets that, regardless of how many people actually join a union industry, the basic protection has been set by the unions.

I return to the example of the employer of 50 to 100 people. At the moment the national union would be involved. The State branch of the union would be involved as well as the employers' organisation and all the employers who are respondents to the award. The coalition's secret strategy is to say to those 50 or 100 people, `You now cannot have the use of the union's resources'. But the employers will still have the resources of the employers' organisation. They will have the lawyers, the economists and the professional advice to be able to negotiate with 50 or 100 people in a particular enterprise. This gives the lie to what Senator Vanstone said. It is not simply a case of people working things out. The employers at every stage will have the advantage of professional assistance. What chance do the 50 or 100 people have in this situation? Senator Chaney will say, `We will allow a union, a paid hand, a lawyer or somebody to represent the employees'; but the trick is that 50 or 100 people will have very limited resources as against an employer who is a member of a major employers' organisation.

That is the fundamental flaw, the fundamental bias, in the coalition's industrial relations policy. It is not fair. It means that ordinary people in an enterprise, whether they are males or females will not have the resources available to the employers. Senator Vanstone indicated a lack of knowledge of industrial relations when she suggested that women in some way-or men for that matter-can cope when such tremendous, powerful resources are ranged against them. In contrast, this Government has created the parameters for working together far more productively. At the enterprise level the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Peter Morris, last year introduced legislation which allows for an enterprise agreement.

I will outline the salient characteristics of this system that allow an enterprise agreement in such a way that people will not be exploited. A certified agreement is simply one form of award, with special characteristics. It allows for flexibility; yet avoids the undesirable outcomes of a totally decentralised system. It provides scope for the development of arrangements designed to reflect the particular requirements of an individual employer or enterprise; yet it guarantees certainty in relation to labour costs which will apply during the period of the agreement, and enables appropriate management decisions to be taken in the knowledge of such predetermined labour costs. Certification ensures that the agreements do not result in exploitation or a wages explosion. That is what the Fraser Government gave us in 1981-82. The Commission must be satisfied that it is in the interests of the parties immediately concerned. It must not be contrary to the public interest to certify the agreement. An agreement may contain provisions which are inconsistent with general Full Bench principles.

There is, therefore, every flexibility in the existing industrial relations system. That is why I can assert that our system is moving to allow companies experienced in dealing with this legislation-it is only a year old-to be able to use it. As people become more aware of it, more individual enterprises will, as Senator Button has pointed out, institute an award, which is one alternative, or a registered agreement. So, this is part of the development of the consensus style of agreement. But the Government is going further-and this is in line with Senator McLean's amendment-because we are encouraging, at the same time as award restructuring is going on, the introduction of modern management techniques in manufacturing such as total quality control, which is just in time, material resources planning, critical path planning, and similar systems of modern manufacturing. The successful economies of Sweden, Germany and Japan which have used this system have one characteristic which we aim to achieve, and that is a high degree of cohesion between management and the work force. Everything this Government is doing is in an attempt to create that characteristic.

The management-work force relationship, which under this Government is based on a non-discriminatory, participatory and consultative type of system, has a chance of success. If we examine what has happened we find that in 1987 the Australian Council of Trade Unions adopted a strategy called Australia Reconstructed-a strategy of trying to influence all of the labour movement to change direction. Indeed, the trade union movement has led the Australian work force in this direction.

Senator Chaney talked of a top down approach. The peak body of the Australian trade union movement decided to try to modernise industrial relations in this country. The Government has done everything to continue that process. One of our problems is that the Opposition in its policy-and this is clear from everything it has said and done-does not want to continue in that tripartite style. It means that we will end up with the Fraser Government style of confrontation. The Fraser Government may have been dead for some time but there are still living examples of that style of confrontation. Queensland is one example. New South Wales will quickly increase confrontation. It is already a characteristic of the Greiner Government and of other coalition governments. I do not believe that the Australian people, having seen how things can change in a positive way, will return to the ways of the past, when decisions were based on ideological conviction rather than on a commonsense approach to industrial relations.

I will answer the question that has been raised about trade unions not amalgamating. The major change that is occurring in unions is quite extensive. Unions are actually in the process of reducing their size, and changes are occurring which were never thought possible. The unions understand that, with a government such as the Hawke Government, changes can be made. The Government has created a supportive atmosphere which is necessary in order for people to make changes. They know that changes will stick, that changes can be contemplated and taken through because the Government is supportive. This Government has made real changes. This is occurring in the whole of the trade union movement, with very few exceptions. Its participation has never happened before in Australia's history.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for the various contributions that have been made to the debate on this motion. I wish to use the couple of minutes that are available to me to respond to some of the points which were raised. I express some disappointment that Senator Button spent a good part of his speech explaining in some detail why he thought the Hawke Government was superior to the Fraser Government in certain areas. I would have thought that the relevant debate was whether the Hawke Government is coming to grips with the quite drastic difficulties which Australia faces in terms of debt, living standards, interest rates, and so on. The fact that in the late 1980s things are being done differently from the way things were done in the late 1970s is scarcely surprising; but the inadequacy of what we are doing is attested to by the many reports referred to in the debate, such as the Industries Assistance Commission report, the Macquarie Bank report or the Business Council of Australia report which called for a debt summit, and so on. I do not believe that that sort of comparison is any more useful than my standing here and saying that the Fraser Government was a lot better than the Whitlam Government. Time moves on and the country has to face the problems of the day.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button also talked about some of the positive aspects of recent years. Of course, there are positive aspects. He talked about the fact that profit share is at its highest level for 20 years. I ask Senator Childs, who has just taken his seat and who has had a long history in the trade union movement: Does the Australian Labor Party really believe that higher profit share, which I, like Senator Button, support, is sustainable over the long haul if real wages continue to decline? To maintain the higher profits that are essential to promote investment in Australia, to create jobs and wealth and to pay off our debts and raise our living standards, we have to get an increase in productivity which will also support higher real wages. The Liberal and National parties do not believe that a continuing policy of low wages is right for the long haul. It might be okay for a period of economic adjustment; it is not a suitable long haul solution. We reject it and believe that changes are essential.

I do not have time to respond to Senator McLean's very interesting contribution, which went to the views of the Australian Democrats concerning supporting under the next government a new system of industrial relations. I am very glad that Senator McLean has publicly indicated the point that he and I have discussed privately on a number of occasions and perhaps debated on the Government's industrial relations legislation. The Democrats took the view that the Government was entitled to its shape of industrial relations. The next government, the coalition government, will be promoting a different shape; not a radical sort of sudden chucking out of what is in place, but a reshaping and an accelerating of the processes of change that are already occurring which will give Australian workers more interesting work, better career paths and higher real incomes in a healthier economy. This is not an anti-worker, anti-union approach; it is quite the reverse. But my concern-and I put it quickly on the public record-is that if Senator McLean is suggesting, for example, that we want a guaranteed minimum income (GMI) scheme of the sort which is sometimes talked about where, whatever we do, we have some guaranteed minimum income, I think we are going to need to talk further, because there is plenty of study to show that the idea of a guaranteed minimum income of itself could be quite destructive of living standards. Therefore I simply say that, whilst of course the Opposition will be supporting a very substantial social security system, the system that we have in this country, and whilst it will be supporting a floor under wages so that there cannot be a falling away of wage standards, it certainly would need to look very carefully at any what might be called formal GMI system.

As far as poverty prevention is concerned, the best guarantee against poverty is a growing economy. The countries which are wiping out poverty best are those countries which are growing. I think that is a very important part of the response to the point that he makes. I do not regard that as a complete response.

TALK.START.PARA: —People have to be able to participate.

—Of course. There are many such points. Education is relevant to that, and so on. These are matters on which I suspect that I will be having many further talks with Senator McLean. I do put up one caution. Senator McLean used an expression which trade unionists here would know about-non-erosion of hard won conditions. That can be a defence of some very silly work practices. I would just contrast the defence of inefficient work practices with the proper protection of conditions. I do not have time to speak any further on this matter. I commend the motion. As I indicated earlier, the Opposition accepts the Democrat amendment as not changing the substance of the motion, and I commend it to the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, agreed to.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report to the Prime Minister by the Australian Science and Technology Council

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This report from the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) deals with the future of Australian astronomy. Interestingly enough, this is the third major report which has been forthcoming from ASTEC on this subject. The previous two reports were a report in 1979 entitled The Next Generation of Australian Telescopes and a report in 1982 entitled New Telescopes for Australian Astronomy in the 1990's.

It is a matter of pride for Australian science, and indeed technology, that we have established a position of world leadership in astronomy-one of the most esoteric of fields. It is also one of the fields that are most likely to respond to major developments in high technology in terms of both the building, design and construction of terrestrial telescopes and getting into the very exciting fields of space-based telescopes and the astronomy which derives as a result of those technological innovations. As a result, one can say that Australia has an enormous intellectual base upon which to build as far as astronomy is concerned. The great shame is that a lack of commitment and a lack of investment by the Hawke Labor Government over the whole of its term of office is now starting both to waste the capital resource that we have and to put strains on the scientific community in Australia who are dedicated to making progress in this area.

The most exciting and innovative things are happening in terms of space research and astronomy. I have had the pleasure of looking at some of the American facilities at places like the jet propulsion laboratory at the Johnson Space Centre in Houston and having a look at one of the Galileo probes under construction. We have all been impressed, almost beyond belief, by the nature of pictures coming back from the deep space probes and satellites. We know that there is most extraordinary work going on at the moment: recent discoveries in the theories of cosmology and cosmic evolution; and the recent detection by astronomers of light coming from what we believe to be the edge of the universe, which might give us some indication of the actual distances in the universe, the actual age of the universe and the process by which the universe was actually created.

But all of that requires, of course, that we have in countries such as Australia astronomers who have the capacity to continue their studies in Australia, who have the resources in Australia to contribute to the interpretive work which needs to be done and, above all, who have access to facilities here in Australia at which they can continue their work and research. People such as Dr Leo Dintenfass, whose work on blood rheology has impressed the United States Administration sufficiently for some of his experiments to be included in a couple of the space shuttles, cannot now get adequate funding for his work. We have in this country astronomers of great repute who are quite legitimately complaining that delays and decisions to defer things for another five years, or whatever it happens to be, will simply destroy the resource that we have available and will encourage people to travel overseas, stay overseas, study overseas.

This is a report to be welcomed. What is not to be welcomed, however, is the Hawke Government's continuing neglect of this area, its failure to invest in basic research and its failure to give adequate support to Australian astronomers by providing them with the resources needed to keep the technology on the ground up to date and to continue to build upon one of the areas of scientific expertise in which Australia is an absolute world leader.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not repeat many of the things that I would also have liked to have said about astronomy in Australia. I am disappointed in the report that has come down from the Australian Science and Technology Council. It sounds more like the report of a government department than of an independent scientific authority. I believe that its advice at all stages needs to be bold and independent and to be seen to be so. Australia is in a pre-eminent position with a huge international importance. Because of the southern skies, the lack of pollution, the clear weather and all the other things that we enjoy, Australia is very important internationally.

SPEECH.PARA: If we had taken the same attitude towards the Australia Telescope as it appears that we are taking towards the proposed new eight-to-ten metre optical telescope, it would never have been built. In the Australia Telescope we have an item of great international importance. If we go ahead with this eight-to-ten metre optical telescope in the next six or eight years, it will present the same opportunities. Certainly the technology is improving every day and the longer we leave it the more up to date it will become; but we want to be part of that development and we want to be in there doing the things that other people will find useful as well.

There is no doubt that the country should be allocating something in the order of $10m to $20m a year at this stage with a view to creating a kitty to build this new optical telescope by the mid-1990s. We want to have all of the planning under way by then. It is absolutely the single most important item that will come up for astronomy in the decade ahead. The work should be going ahead. There should be the commitment at least. We do want to retain our position and this is the only way we can do so.

The alternative to which Senator Puplick alluded is that, unless we do that, we will go down the same track we have gone down with so many other scientific pursuits. With the aid of this Government we have seen so many things disappear or wind down, and this will be just another one unless we get out now and start kicking and screaming. We should be out there now looking for partners and not just saying that we will have another look at this deal in five years time. We should be out there stitching up deals all the way.

We are spending a total of only about $20m a year in Australia on astronomy, and that covers all the universities, Mount Stromlo, the Anglo-Australian telescope and everything else. So it is not an enormous expenditure. To stay in the field we will have to make an extra commitment. There may be problems for those Ministers who want to see a quick cash return and want to shunt this off to the State or local government and have somebody else pay. Investment in this field is most important, and nothing ranks as highly for the 1990s. I would like Australia to make a commitment. Where are we in regard to the future? This Government has come up with nothing at all to demonstrate to people what Australia is all about, where we are heading, how we get there, what the goals are and what we see as important-any of these things. Only by starting to bite off a few of these things and make commitments towards them will we get Australia some way out of the mess that seven years of Keatingism has created.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Australian Electoral Commission annual report was presented to the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) under the signatures of the three commissioners-Mr Justice Morling of the Federal Court of Australia, Dr Colin Hughes and Mr Ian Castles. The Australian Electoral Commission was established as an independent statutory authority in February 1984 and the stated mission of the Commission is to ensure a fair and equitable Commonwealth electoral system. The primary functions are noted as follows:

to conduct parliamentary elections which accurately record voting intentions and are honest, equal in their treatment of electors and universal for all entitled to the franchise; and to conduct elections and ballots required under the Industrial Relations Act . . . and to ensure they accurately reflect electors' voting intentions.

I would like to speak with particular regard to the election for the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly, which was held on 4 March this year, bearing in mind the stated objectives of the Australian Electoral Commission. It is noted in the report that the system used was the modified d'Hondt electoral system. It is stated in the report:

For the election, an extremely complicated electoral system, unlike any other in the world, was used. Modified d'Hondt combines the European party list proportional representation d'Hondt system, the Senate proportional representation system, and various mechanisms for preferential voting for candidates and parties, both within and across party lines.
The Commission stated in December 1988:
. . . an election on this system could take up to two months to count and its assessment proved correct.
In fact, it took exactly two calendar months to count because the election was held on 4 March and the result of the election was announced on 4 May.

The Australian Electoral Commission has put out a video describing the procedure using this particular electoral system. Anyone who sees the video will understand why the count took so long. Obviously it is a very complex process. During the count, the ballot papers, which were huge, had to be sorted into six groups, three of them involving the different ways the elector could vote for a party, two in which the elector could vote for an independent and, of course, the informal vote, and then the papers had to be sorted into 85 categories. Various coloured stickers were used and the count had to be done and redone at certain stages. Indeed, experienced staff had to be used because apparently the errors of one inexperienced staff member who counted for two hours cost the whole system two days to rectify.
In his speech at the declaration of the poll, the Australian Capital Territory Electoral Officer, Mr Geoff Marles, said:

If taking two months to count the votes is unacceptable to the community, there is one and only one way to solve the problem, and that is to replace the modified d'Hondt system. If such a change is not made, if the same number of candidates run at the next election, and if the voters record similar ranges of preferences to those they recorded this time, the one thing that can be guaranteed is that the next Australian Capital Territory election will take just as long to bring to a conclusion as this one did.
I commend the Australian Electoral Commission on its report. It is a full report. It describes in detail the major tasks performed on behalf of the community.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK INDUSTRY POLICY COUNCIL

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I congratulate the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Policy Council on its annual report and on its efforts to identify and investigate problems facing the industry and then to develop recommendations and guidelines to help correct those problems. As I read the report I noted particularly the work of the Council in looking at the issue of mutton marketing. The report noted:
This is considered timely . . . because . . . the continuing increase in the Australian sheep flock is creating potential for significantly increased levels of turn-off of adult sheep.
The report also noted:

It is certain that with a break in season or wool prices, or both, major problems will arise, centring around viable markets for an increased turn-off of what many customers perceive to be low-quality, low-value meat product. Conversely, with the retention of flock numbers, some processors presently are facing economic difficulties in terms of maintaining throughput.

This study is especially relevant today in light of the recent troubles with the export of live sheep to the Middle East. At a time when more sheep are available for slaughter, the lack of Government action in securing the seven million annual live sheep trade has resulted in a dramatic reduction in auction prices for that type of sheep. The lack of urgency on the part of the Government to solve this problem could cost Australia $150m in export income. The failure of senior Ministers, and especially the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), to seriously address the crisis can be described only as a gross dereliction of duty and has allowed the Saudis to treat Australia with contempt.

If Australia cannot maintain strong and viable markets, this serves only to further push Australia's farmers into the abyss of debt which is now facing many of them. Only today we read of disturbing figures which show that farmers are losing money fast, with costs increasing at twice the rate of their income. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics' September quarter index shows an average of a 1.2 per cent increase on prices received, or income, whereas this was heavily outweighed by a 2.1 per cent increase in the prices paid.

This has happened under a Labor Government which then has the effrontery to claim that farmers are pleased with the Federal Government. I do not know what criteria the Government would use for such a claim, but I can assure honourable senators that if their income was being steadily eroded at a rate where the costs to earn the income were twice the rate of the actual income, if they are thinking Australians they would know that they were going backwards and would not be too happy with that. I do not believe that any of the senators opposite would be happy to see their income eroding in that way.

I can only assume that somehow the Government is trying to fool the Australian people just as much as its bedfellows in the Queensland Labor Party are currently doing. It is important that everyone, especially the voters in Queensland at the present time, remember what havoc and devastation the Australian Labor Party can cause to industry, whether it is rural, manufacturing or tourism. When one considers the high interest rates and the problems they are causing small businesses and rural people, who play a tremendous part in Australia's balance of payment figures, I believe that they have been having a very hard trot.

These are some of the points that should be kept in mind when considering the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Policy Council annual report. There is no doubt of the importance of the policy council and its work. I commend it for the tremendous job it is doing to identify and help find the solutions with what I might add is little support from the Labor Party and its union-controlled Government to many of the problems facing the livestock industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, wish to congratulate the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Policy Council (AMLIPC) on its report and on the excellent summary of the work that it has done.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the meat industry is one of Australia's major industries and, as such, it has the capacity to make a lot of impact on Australia's balance of payments. It is one of those industries that seem to be taken for granted. Everybody simply believes that the meat industry can keep on going and solve the problems. That is not quite the case. After reading this and various other documents, it is clear that the meat industry is subject to two things: firstly, it has to provide exactly what every customer we can find really wants; and, secondly, we must see how to get a better price or more value added for the products we sell and, conversely, how to go about reducing the costs.

There must be an action plan built around these two particular factors, and I am pleased that attention has been given in the report to various aspects of these two matters. The first matter, providing what the customer wants, comes back to a matter of breeding, feeding, management, transport and processing-all those things. The second matter, how to get a better price, involves looking to Australia's markets and seeing how we can on-process, where we can establish better markets than the ones we have, and generally trying to merchandise the products in a better fashion.

In addition, as Senator Bjelke-Petersen said, we must look at how to go about reducing the costs to a reasonable level. The costs of the meat industry are astronomical. It was only recently in the Estimates debate in this section that the numbers of people who are being paid for not working and the amount of money that is shuffled backwards and forwards between the various sections were discovered. Everyone has welcomed the rationalisation of the processing industry and the improved mechanisation that has gone with it. The CALM process of marketing-computer aided livestock marketing-has provided enormous reductions in costs already and in a reduction of damage losses, but there are still further production savings that we can make and that will be made.

The AMLIPC is performing a most valuable function and I hope that its investigations will lead to further extension of the value adding nature of the products involved. It was only lunchtime today when we were having a discussion with a group of gentlemen in the meat merchandising game who have been overseas. They have come back and said that Australia certainly has to lift its game. We must make sure that we are providing what the market requires, and these gentlemen do not think that this is happening now. They also said that we need to change the grading system that we have accepted. The Ausmeat system does not help us and Australia needs to go onto a scheme that is universally accepted. The American scheme is clearly the one that the world sets its pattern by. If Australia wants to achieve ready acceptance on the international markets, it will have to be by the acceptance of the United States scheme. I would honestly recommend to the Council that it again look at this matter and make recommendations to the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation that we should change in that direction.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: RESOLUTIONS OF THE 132ND MEETING OF THE AUSTRALIAN AGRICULTURAL COUNCIL

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In talking to the resolutions of the 132nd meeting of the Australian Agricultural Council held in Darwin on 29 July this year, I wish to raise one or two matters of concern that I have. The first matter is the reference in this report to the new committee that has been set up, the National Consultative Committee on Animal Welfare, which has been set up by the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industries and Energy to advise the Minister on matters affecting animal welfare.

This comes on top of quite a few other similar committees that abound in this country. To name just a few, as we are already aware, there are the State Animal Welfare Advisory Councils. Under the auspices of the Australian Agricultural Council, there are sub-committees on animal welfare, and in this particular report they actually recommend codes of practice for the welfare of sheep and the capture and welfare of feral animals. The report makes reference to a code of practice for the farming of deer, the welfare of animals at saleyards, the welfare of goats, and the intensive husbandry of rabbits. This is the sort of work done by this advisory council sub-committee of the Standing Committee on Animal Health under the auspices of the Australian Agricultural Council. In the paper they express concern about the establishment of another welfare committee because they are of the view-and so am I-that enough committees exist already. Perhaps this particular body, which represents all States, should have been used to achieve what the Commonwealth was trying to come up with. We also have the Joint Animal Welfare Committee, which is made up of animal welfare committees around the States. We have the State Committee on Animal Welfare. We also have the Australian Council for Care and Research and Training-

TALK.START.PARA: —An excellent body--

—Yes, I know the honourable senator is a member of that organisation. There are also other animal welfare organisations that are put together on a voluntary basis, such as Australia and New Zealand Federation of Animal Societies (ANZFAS), Australia for Animals and the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (RSPCA), to name just a few. Then there is the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare, of which my colleague opposite Senator Cooney is a member. He would know, as I do, of the amount of reporting we have been doing in recent times and of the acceptance of that Committee by all those people involved in agriculture in Australia. I would like to make the point that the Australian Agricultural Council and the Standing Committee on Animal Health, which is part of that Council, raised concerns about the formation of this new advisory council. Having seen the first agenda, I can see why: that concern was caused by the amount of business they seem to have. I hope that the Minister, Mr Kerin, and this council make use of the committees that already exist to assist in giving advice on the animal welfare issue.

SPEECH.PARA: In the few seconds remaining, I would like to draw attention to another matter raised in this report, and that is the initial notice about a new rabbit virus. We have approaching us in Australia, I believe, another rabbit plague that could outclass even the terrible plague of years ago. I am interested to see that a working party has been formed to look into this virus, which has already killed some 32 million rabbits in Italy. It has spread right across Europe and is now in epidemic proportions in Mexico.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

—The Australian Agricultural Council meeting of 29 July 1989 covered a range of some 35 topics. Some of them were covered in quite considerable depth but most of them were not. Having studied the reports of the Australian Agricultural Council now for some years, I would urge an investigation of the whole process. I think it is time we reconsidered it. What is the cost of running a conference of this nature in a place such as Darwin? How long does it take to get there? How long does the conference take? How long does it take to come back--
—It is a good place for a conference.
—It is a particularly good place to have a conference on agriculture.
—It is no different from Perth-

—None at all. When one considers the nature of these conferences and the fact that they are held in New Zealand, Hobart and various other places-a few years ago one was held at Ayers Rock-we have to look at exactly what we are getting and what it is costing. At the conclusion of this speech it is my intention to put a question on notice to find out exactly that. At a time when we have learned some new traits because we do not have aeroplanes flying, even though there is not a dispute, I want to suggest that these things could be run much more efficiently and just as effectively with a telephone conferencing system. This is a wonderful scheme that has been available for some years, but it does not replace the joys of the junkets that go with these types of conferences. Much of the work that is done at these conferences is the consideration of prepared papers and the acceptance or amendment of them. Of course, there are advantages in meeting socially, but I question the value. I believe that the Agricultural Council has very largely become a cup-of-tea operation and I would accordingly suggest that changes be made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the eighteenth report of 1989 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I also lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 16 dated 1 November 1989.
