DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs entitled Company Directors-Report on Social and Fiduciary Duties and Obligations of Company Directors, together with the transcript of evidence and copies of submissions.

SPEECH.PARA: Order that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

In May 1988 the Senate referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, for inquiry and report, the social and fiduciary duties and obligations of company directors. This matter must be placed in the context of today's corporate culture. Our corporate culture is not that of a century ago, from which much of the law concerning company directors evolved. Over that period there has been an ever increasing separation between the ownership and control of companies. In 1932 Adolf Berle and Gardiner Means, in The Modern Corporation and Private Property, a classic work, analysed the widening chasm between directors, managers and shareholders. As a result, shareholders lost the ability to control the corporations in which they had invested.

The corporation has become a major social institution. It is now a structure which allows a small number of directors control over huge shareholder funds. Today, boards have great power over vast assets. They pursue more with vigour through takeovers, mergers and buy-outs. At the same time, advances in technology have transformed old industries, engendered new ones and enabled trading in securities to be world wide and rapid.

The modern corporate sector has a profound effect on our life. It is crucial to the creation of the nation's wealth. Society looks to it to produce that wealth ethically and in accordance with community values. Directors are the mind and soul of the corporate sector. They are crucial to how its great power is exercised. They can weaken and even suppress markets. They can disturb and destroy an environment. Their actions can have a profound effect on the lives of the shareholders, employees, creditors and the public generally. A legal framework has developed regulating companies' incorporation and providing a mechanism for their winding-up, laying down standards of conduct for their officers, protecting shareholders and regulating how they may merge and be taken over.

There will always be a need for a legal framework such as this, but the extent to which the law will need to intervene in the corporate sector beyond providing this framework depends on the degree to which the corporate sector can effectively regulate itself. Ideally, company directors' conduct should be informed by high ethical values. Corporate history confirms that, without ethics, self-regulation will fail. Courts and legislatures will need to step in when ethical standards are too low or when they are not met.

Laws regulating the director's role have arisen from the intrinsic nature of the company. For the most part, directors are enjoined to act in the best interests of the company. In other words, the board of directors is required, first and foremost, to have regard to the shareholders' interests. In some respects, the law also deals with directors' duties to their employees. This law has developed out of the relationship the company has with entities extrinsic to it.

Should the law, as it deals with matters intrinsic and extrinsic to the corporation, be extended? Some say it should. Some say that companies are now so dominated by directors that their owners, the shareholders, are denied an effective say in their control. Some argue that the law should move to meet the reality that the corporate sector is central not only to the economic well-being of society but also to most dimensions of community life. They advocate the imposition of wider duties on directors-that is, directors should be required to consider the interests of the community at large, or various groups within it, in administering companies. In this way, the control of the company would become a balancing of a variety of claims rather than being focused on the interests of its investors.

In examining these issues, the Committee has looked at the role of the directors as members of a board and at the division of power between the board and the shareholders. It has considered whether directors should be required to have certain qualifications or experience. It has looked at how the law is enforced, and at the remedies available to those who are wronged by directors. It has also considered the question of self-regulation by company directors. In its report the Committee has aimed to deal not with extraordinary situations that might arise but with the everyday situation in which every company director finds himself or herself. Directors should take their role as one of vital importance. As far as the Committee is concerned, the days of the status or figurehead director are over.

The Committee takes the view that, in general, it is appropriate that directors' primary duties and responsibilities lie with the company, as company law presently provides. Other interests, such as those of consumers or the environment, should be dealt with in legislation other than company law. However, given the range of legislation that already imposes obligations on directors towards their employees, it seemed only reasonable to the Committee that the companies legislation be amended to reflect this situation. It has recommended that the companies legislation make it clear that directors are entitled to take into account the interests of employees in administering the company.

It is clear from just a glance at recent newspapers and business journals that some directors are not conducting themselves properly and that, too often, shareholders are unhappy with the leadership of their companies. The law already sets out general principles to guide directors. Some are set out in legislation-such as section 229 of the Companies Code-and some exist as general principles which have been developed by the courts over the years. The Committee has considered the adequacy of the present state of the law and has asked whether any inadequacies can be met by more law. It has concluded that, to the extent that company directors themselves can develop a general code of ethics to inform their conduct, they should do so. Neither case law nor legislation can ensure moral behaviour, and it is moral behaviour that the community is entitled to expect. The Committee has recommended that company directors' professional associations take steps to develop and promote a code of ethics for company directors. Peer pressure is a powerful force and, in this way, it can be harnessed by company directors.

However, history shows that self-regulation has not been completely successful in the corporate sphere. To the extent that it fails, the legislature and the courts must step in and ensure that minimum requirements of behaviour are set out. Company directors must take their role seriously and act responsibly. They should be required to attend board meetings, the extent to which they can rely on others should be limited and the extent to which they can be exonerated from what would otherwise be breaches of their duties should also be limited. The Committee sees no place for appointments to boards as mere window-dressing and its recommendations aim to ensure that window-dressing would not occur.

The Committee also recommends that an objective duty of care for directors be set out in the legislation. Over the years, company law has required little of directors. The courts have been concerned to allow for flexibility and not to hamper entrepreneurship unduly, but the law has, to some extent, been outstripped by the pace of development of modern business. Although the diversity of corporate activity makes it difficult to lay down standards that must be met equally by all directors, if the modern company director wants professional status, then an objective standard of care should apply as in other professions. Certainly modern business practice has developed to the point where the community expects such standards. The law should reflect this.

In conjunction with an objective duty of care, the Committee has recommended that a business judgment rule be introduced. The business judgment rule would allow room for directors' informed business judgments and thus would stimulate proper innovation and risk-taking in the corporate sector. This kind of rule has been developed by American courts, although it has been little discussed in Australia.

The Committee has considered the system of internal controls within companies and the division of power between directors and shareholders. The evidence before the Committee showed that many large companies have already set up audit committees. It has recommended the introduction of audit committees as a requirement for public listing. An audit committee would be a committee of the board and would assist the board in dealing with financial information and would help ensure the existence of effective accounting and financial controls. The establishment of an audit committee will help directors take the conscious and active role in the company's affairs that the Committee thinks necessary.

The Committee received many submissions to the effect that the law was adequate but that its enforcement was not. Indeed, the efficacy of some existing provisions-for example, section 574 of the Companies Code which provides injunctive relief-remains to be tested. It is only when bodies such as the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) and the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) are funded properly and are operating to their limits that the full effect of the law as it stands will be seen. No amount of change in the law will be of any effect unless the law is enforced. The Committee has recommended that the various bodies set up to oversee corporate activity, such as the NCSC and the ASC) be adequately funded so that they will function effectively and will not be toothless tigers. These bodies must not only be capable of operating effectively but also be seen to be operating effectively. This will occur when they are able to acquire and retain staff of the highest calibre and run an adequate number of test cases and implement the law to its fullest extent.

The Committee considers it appropriate that there be a range of penalties available to meet the range of breaches that might occur, but criminal penalties are not appropriate in the absence of criminality. It has recommended that the companies legislation be amended, where necessary, so that this does not occur. It has recommended that civil penalties be provided in the companies legislation for breaches which do not involve criminality. It has recommended that a system of on-the-spot fines, such as the Victorian PERIN system, be introduced for minor offences.

Company directors may be held responsible for the wrongs of their companies. Sometimes this occurs because of specific statutory provisions which impose personal liability on directors; at other times it occurs as a matter of prosecution practice. It seems to the Committee, however, that there is a lack of policy behind decisions to impose personal liability for corporate misconduct and that often little thought is given to how future misconduct could best be prevented. A detailed study of the relevant factors is required before principles regarding the appropriate mix of corporate and individual liability can be set out. The Committee has identified some of the relevant factors but has recommended that this matter be examined in greater detail by a body such as the Law Reform Commission.

In conclusion, I would like to extend the thanks of the Committee to all who made submissions, both written and oral, to the Committee. The Committee recognises that the majority of company directors do their jobs honourably but, clearly, there is presently a need to set standards in the corporate sector. It shares the widespread concern that such standards not be unrealistic or inflexible. The recommendations made in this report are made on that basis. The recommendations on ethical conduct are made on that basis as well. Ethics is simply a mix of experience with morality. If morality is added to the experience of those in the boardroom, hopefully a set of ethics will develop.

I thank all members of the Committee. They all gave great attention to the report. I especially thank the staff, particularly, Kathleen Gibson, Geoffrey Kennett, Stephen Argument and Bronwyn McNaughton-the Secretary-for their learning, dedication, skill and patience. This report is very much a product of their outstanding work. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Traditionally it is members of the committee who are the first to speak to such a report. My colleague Senator Robert Hill wishes to speak and it is a matter of great courtesy on his part that he has allowed me to intervene extremely briefly. It is impossible not to be impressed by the report which has been brought down and impossible not to listen with great interest to Senator Cooney's statement on company directors' duties.

SPEECH.PARA: I intervene only briefly to draw the attention of the Senate to an interesting address on the same subject delivered on 8 November-that is, well after the report would have been settled-by Mr R. J. Fynmore, a senior executive of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, on the subject of regulation in Australia-a corporate view. In light of Senator Cooney's last remarks, it is interesting that Mr Fynmore spent part of his time talking under the subheading `Entrepreneurism-The Unacceptable Australian Face' in which he addressed specifically some of the issues of ethics and morality and some of the failures in this area which lead him to take a view of regulation, which is what one might call a middle of the road view, saying that we need adequate regulation and that there have been some examples where people have failed to behave ethically or morally partly because regulation has not been adequate. His paper talks about business regulation and addresses some of the problems in the public sector. I quote from one part of his paper:

The business community has an obvious interest in regulation which lays down, as clearly as possible, the framework or rules within which business can be carried on; which leaves firms free to judge how they should best conduct themselves within that framework; and which provides a fair measure of certainty or predictability as to the outcome in particular cases; the identity of the responsible regulatory authority should be clear, and that authority should be accountable for its actions . . .

It is obvious that the views he expresses are quite consonant with the views which Senator Cooney has expressed. The paper is quite relevant to the work that the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs has done. It would not have been available to the Committee as it was delivered only on 8 November. For the information of honourable senators I seek leave of the Senate to table the paper.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend Senator Cooney for his leadership of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I particularly commend the staff of the Committee-Bronwyn McNaughton and others-who have made this report possible. Senator Peter Baume's intervention was interesting because the corporate misbehaviour that was covered in Mr Fynmore's speech was very much the motivation for this inquiry in the first instance. I am conscious of that because I, more than anyone else, pressed for the inquiry in the first place. I appreciate the fact that members of the Committee, some of whom have changed in the meantime, were prepared to embrace such a reference.
—If you would reply to me I would like to acknowledge that it was your original idea.

—I do not think I need that, Senator. The inquiry came about because of some highly publicised cases which disclosed apparent abuses of responsibility by directors for which it appeared that there was no effective recourse. That motivated the Senate, through its Committee, to look again at the whole subject of company directors' duties, to look at whether the law required reform or whether the application of the law required to be changed in some way. Those who are interested in this area of the law-I trust that the Government is-will find the Committee's report useful. It is fair to say that it is couched in sensible terms and with sensible recommendations rather than the somewhat sensational contribution that we find elsewhere in this area of the law. As all Senate committees do, we took the reference seriously. I believe that there are recommendations in the report that will be found to be particularly useful over a period.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously there are areas which we decided not to cover because they had been dealt with or were being dealt with by other bodies, such as the issue of indemnification of directors and alternate and nominee directors, which have been examined recently by the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee. What we decided to concentrate on were the questions of qualifications of directors; multiplicity of directorships; the role of directors and composition of the board, including board members and especially audit committees; the nature of directors' existing duties and responsibilities and the standards required; to whom the duties and responsibilities are owed and whether they should be widened; and enforcement of the laws relating to directors. There is an extensive discussion in the report of the ways in which duties are imposed on directors by the courts and by legislation as well as through self-regulation.

The courts historically have been reluctant to intervene in the management decisions of companies or to extend the duties of care, skill and diligence which directors owe to a company, and we review the leading cases in the report. I believe that that review will be useful for students of the law. A wide range of obligations is imposed on directors by legislation. They include duties relating to areas such as tax, trade practices and industrial relations. The principal obligation is contained in section 229 of the Companies Code and its equivalent in the new corporations legislation. In this section a duty is imposed on a director to act honestly, to exercise a reasonable degree of care and diligence, and not to make improper use of his or her position. Although on its face this looks to be an objective standard of care, in fact, the courts in practice have read it down. It does not add anything to the common law subjective standard where the courts look at what would be reasonable for a particular director in the particular circumstances. There are many more duties and responsibilities in the code: for example, those relating to record keeping and auditing, amounting to what is often described-and certainly this was put to us-as a bewildering array. That becomes important because we received many submissions from directors, directors' organisations and companies stating that the obligation upon directors had become onerous and, in some ways, almost unworkable.

As the report points out, it is not easy to determine uniform minimum standards of behaviour for company directors because of the diversity of modern companies and the flexibility which is necessary to run them. The Committee, while recognising the need for that flexibility, came to the view that the present state of the law is not satisfactory and has recommended that the companies legislation provide for an objective duty of care. As something of a balance, the Committee has also recommended the introduction of what has been referred to in the American courts as a business judgment rule. Where such a rule is in operation there is special protection from liability for directors who make business judgments in good faith provided they act with a reasonable degree of care.

One of the interesting characteristics of the report, I suggest, is the commonsense nature of many of the recommendations. I refer, for example, to the recommendation that directors be required to attend board meetings-not something that is necessary under the common law. We suggest that directors should be required to attend board meetings unless there is a reasonable excuse for non-attendance. This recommendation leads to what I hope will be seen as an interesting discussion on the controversial issue of figurehead directors. We do not go as far as to recommend an end to the appointment of figurehead directors, although it might be said that some of our recommendations are leading in that direction. The practice of appointing figurehead directors does not seem to be particularly widespread in Australia. Therefore, we resisted the temptation and the suggestion of some submissions that it should be outlawed. But we do not find it unreasonable to expect that a director will actively contribute to the running of a company.

Chapter 4 of the report is a comprehensive discussion of directors' fiduciary duties. The issue of multiple directorships is relevant, as conflicts of interest may arise where a person is a director of more than one company and such conflicts may breach fiduciary law. The general tenor of submissions made to the Committee was that the ethical considerations arising from multiple directorships are more properly dealt with by directors' professional associations than by setting some arbitrary limit on the number of positions which may be held, and we accepted that advice.

Another issue arising in the context of fiduciary law is that of disclosure by fiduciaries of their activities so that a beneficiary can make an informed decision about them. The report acknowledges the difficulty of formulating a general rule about when disclosure is necessary and to whom, but it nevertheless makes the recommendation that there be a general rule in the legislation setting out requirements which must be met for exoneration of directors from what otherwise would be breaches of their fiduciary duties. The recommendation may be seen by some as somewhat controversial and it will be interesting to see what debate follows within legal circles.

Chapter 5 of the report deals with directors' wider duties, in particular, the question of duties owed to creditors. Once again we hope that students of the law will find the discussion of the case law both comprehensive and useful. Consideration of those cases seems to indicate a duty on directors of insolvent companies to act in the interests of creditors. It is not clear whether this extends to directors of solvent companies. Under the provisions of the corporations legislation, directors are personally liable for debts incurred when there are no reasonable grounds to expect that they will be paid. Although obviously on its face this is a good idea, it has been criticised because each creditor must bring an action to recover the amount that is owing to him, which means it is useful only to those creditors who have the resources to bring an action and those who get in first may clean out the assets of the debtor. Therefore, we recommend in our report that the legislation be amended to provide for all creditors to share equally in sums recovered from directors.

The report also deals with the duties which have been imposed on company directors by the courts and by legislation in relation to areas external to the company itself, such as conditions of service for employees, occupational health and safety and environmental protection-areas that were of particular interest to the Chairman, Senator Cooney. There was some discussion of the potentially competing interests of shareholders and employees-an area of the law not yet well advanced in this country. The Committee recommends that, in line with prevailing community thought, companies legislation should be amended to clarify the power of directors to take employees' interests into account in administering the company. Duties are also imposed on company directors by environmental and consumer law. The Committee came to the view that these issues are best dealt with in specific legislation rather than in companies legislation.

As was mentioned by Senator Cooney, the Committee also looked in some depth at the question of audit committees and made detailed recommendations on this issue. The presence of an audit committee has several major advantages for a company, not the least of which is enhanced quality of financial reports; at least, we hope that would occur. The Committee was of the view that all publicly listed companies should have an audit committee comprising non-executive directors. On the question of the qualifications of directors, it was common ground that it would not be feasible or practical to require any formal qualifications of skill or experience. As many witnesses pointed out to the Committee, to put a formal requirement in place would be to disqualify many present and potential competent directors. The Committee instead recommended that the Company Directors Association of Australia and the Institute of Directors in Australia compile an index of courses and programs dealing with company directors' duties and responsibilities and that they encourage participation in these courses. In order to make public companies more accountable for their choices of directors, the Committee recommended that the boards state in the annual reports the particular skills and expertise that each director brings to the company. If that recommendation is adopted, some interesting consequences might follow.

In emphasising regulation by legislation and by the courts, we should not forget that many aspects of company directors' duties and responsibilities are best dealt with by self-regulation through a code of ethics. The Committee recommended that company directors' professional associations develop and promote such a code. The Committee also makes the obvious point that all these means of regulations do not count for much if proper mechanisms for enforcement are not in place. Considerable concern was expressed at the hearings that regulatory bodies such as the National Companies and Securities Commission do not receive sufficient funding to be fully effective. For what it is worth-because it depends on the will of government and we have not seen great will from the Government in this area-we recommend that such agencies receive an adequate level of funding. The final recommendations in the report relate to sanctions against directors for breaches of their duties. Basically, we say that breaches should attract criminal penalties only where the conduct is criminal in nature. There has tended to be some extension towards criminal penalties that might be imposed upon directors who innocently breach provisions of the legislation.

Those who read and study the report will find it a cautious one. I hope they will find it a useful contribution to law reform in this area. Soon after commencing the report it became apparent to us that it is not possible to legislate for the worst case scenarios. No law will stop those who have no intention of complying with legislative requirements. We tried to make constructive and useful suggestions to reform the existing law so that at least those who wish to comply with their legal obligations might have those obligations more explicitly pointed out to them in the legislation and so that, in effect, the law might be updated to meet the needs of the modern corporate society. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just a couple of additional points I would like to raise with the Minister in the consideration of the appropriation for the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. They follow on, though are separate and different issues, from the ones we were discussing before lunch today. The first point I want to raise relates to the fact that emerged-for the first time to my knowledge-during the Estimates debate in September about who meets the cost of citizenship ceremonies which are conducted by local councils. As I understand it, most of the citizenship ceremonies are so conducted. I was interested and, I must say, surprised to learn that the Federal Department does not make any contribution at all to the cost of staging those citizenship ceremonies.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Minister, particularly in view of the Year of Citizenship that we have had and the Government's drive to increase the number of Australian citizens, whether he considers that it is a matter that we ought to have a look at. If all of the cost is being borne by local government-as I raised, on behalf of Senator Peter Baume and others during the Estimates Committee hearings, the cost to local government is increasingly onerous-I would like to know, following that discussion in the Estimates Committee, whether the Minister has had an opportunity to think any more about that matter. Also I would like to know whether the Federal Department ought to be looking at making some contribution as part of the overall effort of increasing the status and stature attached to gaining citizenship in Australia, which is a goal to which we all aspire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be wrong to say that the Commonwealth makes no contribution to citizenship ceremonies. We do not make a direct contribution but the Commonwealth makes funds available to local government per se. I would have thought that in the assessment of making those funds available, one takes into account some things that local government does on behalf of the Federal Government. Senator Short would know the sorts of financial grants that are made to local government authorities. That is the first point I would like to make. Secondly, these people who are becoming citizens are not only Australian citizens voting in Federal elections, they also have a State and a municipal role. I have had very few councils actually complain to me about the cost of running these citizenship ceremonies; some have though.

SPEECH.PARA: I think another point to make is that most councils enjoy this particular thing and do not mind paying for it. Councils enjoy playing this particular role. It has probably become onerous on a couple of councils. The Brisbane City Council, for instance, at one stage had to conduct very large ceremonies. But I think that Council has broken the areas into wards which is a much better idea as there is no need to have 700 participants at the one time. As I say, I have not had a lot of complaints from councils. The next point is that I would have thought it was part of the councils' compact with the Federal Government that they do this as their duty. In return, that is taken into account when money is allocated to local government. I agree that money is not specifically allocated for citizenship ceremonies. In the same way, the Grants Commission takes into account certain things that States do for the Commonwealth Government.

If, however, we were to look at funding local government-I do not rule it out entirely-in common with that also would be some more direction. One of the problems that Senator Short and many other politicians have raised with me is that councils from time to time take it on themselves to be very selective in their invitation list when Federal and State politicians attend. I have examples of complaints of political bias both ways on that issue. If I were asked whether I would fund all the citizenship ceremonies, in that case I think I would bypass local councils and design the citizenship ceremonies myself and run them in my own way. If it becomes a problem it should be looked at. I do not see it as a major problem at the moment. It may be that local councils have not written to complain because they regard it as inevitable. Having attended I do not know how many in the last year, I noticed that all the councils seem very enthusiastic to retain their control.

It is interesting that if I delegate someone else in an area to perform a ceremony-from time to time I delegate people from both sides of the chamber to carry out a special, one-off ceremony just for a day, it could be the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or it could be my colleague Senator Calvert on the other side of the chamber who did one in Hobart-the councils tend to write to me to complain about that. They say that it is their right to conduct the ceremonies. So I do not see this matter as a big problem. If Senator Short has received a lot of complaints I ask that he forward them on to me and I will give them due consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that answer. I have to say that I have not had a lot of complaints which surprises me but to some extent perhaps it is because I do not get any invitations.
—I am still preparing a letter to send out asking them to invite politicians.

—Good; I welcome that. I think it is a very good move. As a point of principle, if we as a Federal government place a lot of weight on Australian citizenship-I think rightly so and we do on both sides of the chamber and of politics-it raises the question of whether we ought to be looking at making some contribution towards the cost of the appropriate ceremonies. I do not push the matter. If the Minister says that local government has not raised the issue in any marked degree, perhaps the problem is not there to the extent that it might appear to be.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other matter I want to raise in relation to this Department is a specific case. It is one that concerns me because I think it has a wider implication for the whole question of the treatment of over-stayed or illegal immigrants. That relates to the case of a Mr Kandasamy, who was previously known as Mr Damieen. I raised a question on notice in the Estimates Committee hearing. I did get a response. My question was:
Has Mr R. Kandasamy . . . been deported yet? If so, when? If not, what is the status of his appeal? When is the decision expected to be made?
The reply I got was:

Mr Kandasamy has not been deported. He has applied for resident status. Enquiries relating to his claims for resident status, which have been complicated by changing circumstances, are continuing and should be completed shortly.

The reason I raise the matter and express concern about the answer-it is perhaps part of a wider question in terms of how we handle overstayed immigrants-is that this matter, as I understand it, has been going on since October 1986 when this man first applied for permanent resident status. My understanding of the background of this case is that he is Malaysian by birth. He came to Sydney about 12 years ago on a visitors visa for six months. He overstayed the visa and he became too frightened to approach the authorities to explain the situation. In Melbourne he met an Aboriginal person in an hotel in Fitzroy who gave him some documentation in the name of another Aboriginal person.

The fellow then got a job in Melbourne with the Tramways Board as a conductor, and he worked there for 13 months. Then he did some study. He had a serious accident causing him to be hospitalised for many months, and whilst in hospital he met a person whom he married. They had two children, and they are now divorced. He then went to Darwin and got a passport in the name of the Aborigine. He went back to Malaysia for a two-week holiday. He came back to Australia and worked as an inventory clerk in the Department of Defence at Laverton. I understand that whilst he was there the team from the Mike Willessee show raided his home and accused him of falsifying his identity to arrange particular ventures in Australia. He was imprisoned for five months and fined $2,000 before applying for an Australian passport without being an Australian. Therefore, he was an illegal immigrant. That is the background information that I have been given on the case.

It is extraordinary that it has taken more than three years to determine his application for permanent resident status. I would like to know more about why a case like that takes so long and what the implications are in the broader nature for the whole question of the examination of overstayed and admitted illegal immigrants in Australia. If it is going to take so long to look at applications which would appear prima facie to be clear-cut-I should not pass judgment on that-it does not surprise me in some ways that we have as many illegal immigrants in Australia as we have. We have to tighten up on that situation-and it is correct that we do so, and there is universal agreement on that. I wonder how we will go in the future unless we lift our game.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no intention of discussing the specific details of the case without the file in front of me. Senator Short has raised some very valid general points. It is interesting that the honourable senator mentioned that this man was a tram driver. One of the things he could have done was drive a tram through the Migration Act. The one we are operating under today was passed in 1958. It has been so reinterpreted by the courts-I am not necessarily saying that it is the reason in this particular case-right up to the High Court of Australia, that it can be a very slow process determining someone's status.

SPEECH.PARA: For instance, Mr X, whoever he is, could apply for a change of resident status in this country under the existing law under the employer nomination scheme. He may miss out there. He may then apply on compassionate grounds. He may miss out there. Then he may apply for refugee status. All these things take a long while to resolve. Every step has to be dealt with very carefully because if officers do not give due consideration to every aspect of the application we find the courts remitting the decision back for further decision. Under the new Act that is to be proclaimed on 19 December, when one appeals on one ground one appeals on all grounds other than the refugee status. So one is considered on all claims. That will shorten the process. More important than that, following 19 December if one is here as an illegal immigrant one is subject to a mandatory deportation order following the issue of which one has two working days in which to make any other claims, et cetera.

We are going to face a revolution on 19 December. I appreciated the support from most people in this chamber for toughening up these particular areas. It is long overdue. Senator Short can blame this Government for not doing it in the last six years and I will blame his Government for not doing it in the previous seven years. He can blame my Government for not doing it in the previous three years and we will be back into the Gorton and McMahon periods through to the Menzies reign. These problems have been building because of the treatment meted out and the length of time taken in dealing with these cases. The real thing to consider is that when we extend the length of time a person stays in Australia we are giving a great privilege to that person. Any time the time is extended overseas we are giving a penalty to someone overseas. The whole thrust of the new Migration Act this year was to reverse the situation and to have these things dealt with promptly.

I would be happy to examine the specific case and talk to Senator Short privately about it, having the full file details in front of me-which I do not have at the moment. That is not surprising with the thousands of cases going at any one time. The points he makes about the delays are valid. We need to overcome them because unless we have quick justice in this area to some extent we are giving a massive advantage to someone who has stayed here illegally while other people are queued up orderly overseas. Maybe I am being an optimist when I say that the new Act will drastically alter the situation. I guess the proof of the pudding will be in the eating next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —For my clarification and for those who might be listening to this debate or who might read it, if this particular case had arisen under the new Act, as from 19 December, how would it have been treated?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a tough one. I qualify this by saying that a mandatory deportation order would be issued after a period of time. Once a person had an illegal status there would be a mandatory deportation order against that person. I think that the person would be on apprehension-I will have to check this-and would have two days to make any further claims of changed circumstances or anything else. Other than that, that mandatory deportation order is irreversible, by me or the courts, as I understand the Act. We cannot interfere with that. We still have discretionary deportations to cover other circumstances but the mandatory deportation, as I understand it under the Bill we passed, is irreversible.
—If the illegal immigrant married while he was here would that, under the new Act, change his position? Would he still be subject to mandatory deportation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —That would constitute a changed circumstance, I think. The honourable senator is almost asking me for legal opinions. I think that would involve us-and I will have to check this-in discretionary deportation because there would have been a changed circumstance that applied, that is, a marriage. I think that is a discretionary one, but I would have to check that and the regulations as to how it applies in those cases.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Committee, having considered the Report of Estimates Committee E, recommends-That the following matters be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration for inquiry and report on or before the last sitting day in May 1990, bearing in mind the functions and purposes of the Senate Estimates Committees:
(a) the adequacy of the present format of departmental explanatory notes and monitoring by the Department of Finance to ensure that departments comply with the format set out in its memoranda;
(b) the need for any change to existing procedures of the Senate to ensure that the activities of government service providers operating through Trust Accounts do not escape adequate scrutiny; and
(c) the need for any change to existing procedures of the Senate to ensure that Special Appropriations and bodies funded through such appropriations do not escape adequate scrutiny.

Paragraph (a) of the motion is a matter of ongoing concern. Materials provided to Estimates committees should be sufficient for senators on those Estimates committees to make judgments about the proposed expenditure and how well a department is meeting its stated objectives. The move to program budgeting is welcomed in this respect and should make the task of making such assessments easier. It is probably true to say that departments have needed time to settle down to the new reporting format, but the result has been patchy, and this is identified in the report. I will not go into it here, except to say that the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs deserves particular praise for giving what the Committee thought were very clear reports throughout, whereas the reports of other departments were quite patchy. The Department of Finance is held partly responsible for this, so we thought it prudent to recommend that it look at the procedures and that they apply to departments in that reporting process.

Paragraph (b) of the motion arose out of changes occurring within the Department of Administrative Services. A number of programs providing services to other departments are currently undergoing a process of commercialisation. Instead of being directly funded by appropriations, funds are being provided to departments so that they may, in turn, pay the service providers. These payments are being placed in trust accounts under the Audit Act. Some concern was expressed by senators on the Committee that the process might diminish the scrutiny by the Estimates committee. While I guess the problem has been exacerbated by the transition period that that process is in, we are assured that financial statements will include full details, as with any business, in the annual reports of the departments. Nevertheless, it was felt prudent to refer that question to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration so that it can examine the processes necessary to achieve proper scrutiny.

Paragraph (c) of the motion arose out of consideration of estimates of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and, in particular, the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account established under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976. Amounts of money equivalent to certain royalties are paid into an account out of Consolidated Revenue and the costs of the Northern Territory land council administration are met from these funds. The question arises whether it is appropriate for questions to be asked in the Estimates Committee in relation to the account in the first place and the land councils in the second place, neither of which receive funds directly through the estimates. The question also arose about whether the Estimates Committee did have a right to call witnesses from the land councils. Again, that is a question that we felt should be referred to the Finance and Public Administration Committee in order to determine proper procedures for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of Estimates Committee E, I strongly agree with the motion moved by Senator Beahan, the Chairman of the Committee. He explained very clearly the difficulties that we see arising. My friend Senator Tambling raised initially the problems that may arise through the increasing move to use trust accounts in the operation of government agencies and perhaps parts of departments. Whilst I have not had the opportunity to read the recommendations of Estimates Committee E, having listened to Senator Beahan, it is certainly in line with the concerns that we had. I think it is an important issue. Of course, it goes well beyond the ambit of Estimates Committee E; it relates to the whole question of financial operations of government. For that reason, the motion to refer the matter to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration is, in my view, very wise. I therefore support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity that the facilities of the Senate did not enable prior notice of this motion to be given. This motion has only just been brought to my attention. Whilst I appreciate that the motion is a technical formality regarding the issues that were referred to in the Estimates Committee E report, there was no prior notice given to members of the Committee that the motion was going to be brought on at this time.

SPEECH.PARA: As we discuss the report of Estimates Committee E, naturally a number of these issues across the various portfolios will be addressed, be they from the Department of Administrative Services or the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the various statutory authorities. The issues canvassed in the motion do reflect recommendations that arise from the Committee's report and, as Senator Short has just said, enjoy the support of all members of that Committee. I only briefly heard Senator Beahan speaking to his motion while I was still in my office. He addressed some of the issues that, either later today or tomorrow, I will raise in considerable detail as we proceed through the committee stage. I refer in particular to those of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission, to which the Estimates Committee has given particular attention for quite some considerable time. In fact, going back to October 1988, there has been a continuing saga of a very strong need for scrutiny, review and reports by various committees-not only by Estimates Committee E but by other committees of this Parliament, various inquiries that were instituted by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), and various reports, including, of course, the Australian Audit Office report. All those things have highlighted for the attention of the chamber some very important deficiencies that have to be noted in this particular portfolio.

In the process of Estimates Committee E a number of activities of the Department of Administrative Services required investigating, particularly those relating to the provision and operation of trust accounts. Therefore, the moving of this motion, that these three matters be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, is timely and proper. I assure the Committee that it will enjoy my support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse what my colleagues have said and commend Senator Beahan for bringing this matter forward. I also commend him in general for the quality of the report from Estimates Committee E, which is by far the most informative and detailed of any of the reports that have come from Estimates committees.

SPEECH.PARA: I stress that the matter of trust accounts, as Senator Tambling and Senator Short have said, extends far beyond the area of Estimates Committee E and certainly far beyond the problem that Senator Tambling identified in Aboriginal Affairs. One of the responses I intended to deal with in this debate on the report of Estimates Committee E concerns the Australian Government Publishing Service, which has multi-million dollar trust account operations that, in the absence of appropriate questioning at Senate Estimates committee meetings and the provision of a reply to questions upon notice, would not have been available for public scrutiny under a system that I think certainly needs examination. So I commend Senator Beahan for bringing this about.

I hope that the question of whether or not annual reports of statutory bodies which are not at present required to be presented, where possible, to Senate Estimates committees, as departmental reports are, could be brought into the same category as departmental reports. As I mentioned the other day, the Civil Aviation Authority, I think it was, presented a one-line appropriation and, when questioned, said that all the details were in the annual report. When asked where the annual report was, the Authority said that it may be available perhaps in November. We have not seen it yet and we are now debating appropriations, and that strikes me as a particularly bad principle. I wonder whether Senator Beahan feels that that matter is covered. I must say that, had I realised that this was coming forward, I would have had a chat to him to see whether the availability of annual reports of departments could have been included in this change of procedures because they provide a great deal of explanation of the appropriations and performance as against appropriations of the previous year. Paragraph (c) of Senator Beahan's motion reads:
the need for any change to existing procedures of the Senate to ensure that Special Appropriations and bodies funded through such appropriations do not escape adequate scrutiny.

Perhaps that is a compendious enough matter to raise the question of these statutory and other bodies which do not have the same reporting requirement to Senate Estimates committees. In conclusion, I commend Senator Beahan for the motion and say that it has my strong support.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to deal with the question of citizenship, and I refer particularly to former British child migrants. Some of these people now wish to take out British citizenship. They have been without papers of any sort and have all manner of related problems. When some of them put in their applications for citizenship, they found that they had to go through exactly the same process as everybody else. They were shocked to discover this because, having been brought out here as children, not by their parents and without having any say at all in the matter and having regarded themselves as Australians-some of them even fought for this country during the Vietnam war-they really feel that they should have some automatic right to citizenship. They regard themselves as having been brought up in Australia. In the last weeks of the Year of the Citizen, I wonder whether the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) would consider again the plight and the circumstances of these people with regard to Australian citizenship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jenkins in her opening remarks said that these people were applying for British citizenship, so I was confused for a moment. Obviously she meant to say that they were applying for Australian citizenship. The current Act provides very little discretion that would allow me to say that we could foreshorten the normal processes, nor is there any provision for automatic citizenship. Early in the Estimates Committee hearings, I indicated that a review of the Citizenship Act is fairly high on our agenda and is part of our legislative program. A variety of changes will be looked at.

SPEECH.PARA: I take on board the remarks of Senator Jenkins today and I will see whether my Department has a view on whether we can accommodate these people. In general, my Department has been very helpful in assisting these people, and there has been a whole range of events during the last year since those major publications came out. We will have a look at it in terms of reviewing the Citizenship Act to see how it can apply to those individuals.

I hope that this legislation can be brought in in the Autumn session, but Senator Jenkins was not in the chamber earlier today when I said that, if it is foreshortened by an election, it will be spring next year before anything positive is done about it. There is no automatic grant of citizenship under the existing Act, and I do not think any amount of waiver would cover it either. The Act contains a number of anomalies and we hope to rectify them by way of legislation.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Department of Administrative Services
Proposed expenditure, $630,091,000

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to these votes, and I know that that would surprise my Labor colleagues opposite. There are some matters that have interested me and I am certain will interest the chamber. I again commend Senator Beahan for taking up in his report some of the matters that concerned me.

SPEECH.PARA: One is the question of the extent to which members of departments, senior members of the bureaucracy, should respond to questions asked by senators in Senate Estimates committees. The report of Senate Estimates Committee E noted that, over many years, I had been specifically asking about the extent to which property leased, rented or owned by the Commonwealth had remained unoccupied or significantly underutilised for any length of time in any financial year since 1982-83. The response from the Australian Construction Services was that there were no properties currently unoccupied or significantly underutilised.

As I pointed out at the time, the Auditor-General in his audit report No. 15 for 1989-90 drew attention to the fact that the Australian Construction Services facility in Kewdale in Western Australia was underutilised and that that had been apparent since at least 1982, which was in the period covered by my question. The response I got when I compared the Auditor-General's view with the Department's view was that there was a little confusion about the words `significantly underutilised'. It is worth quoting the report of the Committee in this respect. It reads:

When the Auditor-General's findings were raised at this Committee's hearing, the Departmental officers attempted to defend the answer they gave on the basis that they had attached a particular meaning to the adverb `significantly' which somehow excluded the underutilisation that had taken place at Kewdale. As the Minister at the Table, Senator Ray, remarked, . . . the important lessons for Departments to draw from this instance is that they should give the fullest answer possible to a Senator's question, rather than relying on a restrictive interpretation of the wording used in the question to deny the Senator the information which he or she may have been seeking.

I commend the Minister for his very reasonable response at that time, but the matter that concerns me is whether there are other instances within the Commonwealth Public Service-which is in charge of multi-millions of dollars worth of assets-where other departmental officers may have taken the view that because in their view, something may not be `significantly' underutilised, it is therefore not `significantly underutilised' in the view of a reasonable person. I suggest that clearly the Auditor-General's report does raise a few questions and makes one a little uneasy about the merit of some of the answers that we may have been getting.

At times many members of the bureaucracy may feel that senators are unfairly hectoring them in the manner in which they go about asking questions in Senate Estimates committees. There is no doubt that there are some budding Perry Masons on the Opposition benches who enjoy seeking to make some strong points. The fact is that if senators have to put up with responses which may well be either intentionally or unintentionally misleading, then it underlines in their minds the need to ask probing and what often may be seen to be harassing questions.

I would hope that the atmosphere in Senate Estimates committees would be at a much better level than that and that there would be a genuine pursuit of knowledge without the feeling that there is an adversarial situation. Theoretically, we should all be in there together. In the case of Senator Robert Ray, I can say that on all occasions when participating in Senate Estimates as Minister he participates in such a way as to assist in the discovery of information to which the Senate is entitled. Some Ministers do not do that, but this Minister acts with total propriety in these matters. However, when there is a mixture of a senator-like Senator Bolkus-using his position, in so many instances, it seems, to obstruct the Opposition in the asking of proper questions, and members of the bureaucracy appear-as in this case-to mislead members of the Senate, either intentionally or unintentionally, there will be a bad atmosphere and an atmosphere of hostile questioning in these Estimates committees.

I am underlining the recommendation from the Minister that departmental officers should take this into account and I am asking departmental officers across the whole spectrum of the Commonwealth Public Service to recognise that the great bulk of Opposition senators-to my knowledge-bear no ill will when they are asking questions of the bureaucracy. However, if we get the feeling that we are being misled and that people are hiding behind particular forms of language in order not to be frank, then it is inevitable that there will be an atmosphere of hostility and reports outlining Senate concern very strongly, as was outlined in this matter.

I hope that this matter in general, that is, the presentation of full and ready information, may well form part of the sort of inquiry before the Committee on Finance and Public Administration that Senator Beahan has just initiated. There are some matters I wish to raise in general, but I do not want to take up too much of the Senate's time right now in case other senators wish to raise issues immediately before we get up for dinner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel inclined to respond to some of the remarks made by Senator Michael Baume. I do not appreciate his putting the kiss of death on Senator Beahan and me, and I might go back to Senator Vanstone's bibliography in which I once referred to Senator Baume in certain ways and repeat them here. But I think it was a fair summation, especially the latter part of it. For one moment I was going to get up and criticise Senator Baume for being one-sided in just criticising public servants, because at some stages in Estimates committees I believe that senators have mistreated public servants in their attitude to them. It is a chicken and egg argument as to why that may occur, but these people are there to assist the Minister. The greatest abuse occurs when senators try to ask public servants for their opinions on policy. They are not there for that reason. It is the old business of bowling five leg-spinners then a wrong'un. They ask five factual questions, establish a rapport, public servants are always trying to help, and then they cop the question on policy grounds. Simply, public servants are not there for that, and the last thing senators opposite would want is them passionately defending government policy, because the moment an election turnaround occurs, they would expect public servants to implement their policies and not have a passionate approach to policy matters. At times it is a difficulty when nascent Perry Masons get loose. Also I must add that there is a responsibility by Ministers and chairmen of committees to intervene where possible and to halt that procedure. I have noticed that when we have intervened, cooperation from senators does ensue.

SPEECH.PARA: To return to the question of a full and frank answer, I have said that I believe that that should be the case. I would not like anyone to think that I am just a prissy, principled person. I do that out of self-interest because that is the safest approach. One cannot get caught out if one puts in a full and direct answer. One cannot get accused of covering up, and it is the Senate's right. I will conclude on this point: Estimates committees are one of the great institutions of this Parliament. I have often been accused, a la Mae West, of showing contempt for this chamber and, like Mae West, I have always responded by saying, `No, I have always tried to hide it.' The one overriding body that does keep the whole public administration on its toes is the Estimates committee. I agree with not having them in the House of Representatives, because they are a farce anyway, and I would always agree to having them here. I might agree to knocking out a lot of other committees in this chamber that I regard as useless, but we have to acknowledge the fact that Estimates committees are basically there for oppositions, and so it should be. I would hate to see them ever go.

I can also say in conclusion that anything that has been done to me in Estimates committees was nothing to what I did to others in cahoots with Senator Gietzelt and Senator McLaren in the period 1981 to 1983, and any trick that is currently being played in Estimates committees we certainly played when we were in opposition. I acknowledge the remarks made by Senator Baume, especially the way he balanced them; that it is up to public servants to give full and frank answers and, in turn, to be treated with respect by senators and not simply someone they can take their bad day out on.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Dr T. Bavadra: Death-State Election, Queensland-Frail Aged: Treatment-Immigration: Australian Democrats Policy-Defence Equipment

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 7.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:
