SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to say a few words about the passing of a person who I consider a close friend but, more importantly, a very significant political figure of the south and mid Pacific, that of Timoci Bavadra, in Fiji recently. As has been reported in the press, Timoci died from cancer. His passing is a great loss, not just to Fiji but to all of the peoples of the South Pacific.

SPEECH.PARA: I had the opportunity to meet Timoci on a number of occasions, both before he became Prime Minister of Fiji-but never while he was Prime Minister of Fiji-and on a number of occasions after he was deposed in a coup in April 1987. Some features about Timoci Bavadra were unique. Of all the people I have met in politics, I do not think I have met a person who was genuinely more sincere, honest and humble in the way he carried himself in his political work. Some people suggested that he was unsophisticated. If that was a criticism, I think it was a criticism that Timoci bore very gladly. From the meetings that I had with him, I certainly know that that honesty, sincerity and humbleness always came across. That was also, I believe, the reason for his extraordinary support in Fiji.

Timoci was a great democrat and a great statesman. Why I think he deserves those descriptions is that he saw that the only way that Fiji could progress was to break the stereotype of the racial divisions in that country. He was the founding leader of the Fiji Labour Party, the first multi-racial political party formed in Fiji. As I say, he believed that that was the only way Fiji could progress, that it was the only way that the many tensions in the community could be overcome. He was the first politician openly to seek the support of both communities, and he had great success in that. The first time that the Fiji Labour Party contested a general election in that country, it was successful and formed a coalition with the Federation Party. I have no doubt that the coup, which occurred after only 33 days in office, was motivated by the fact that a number of people realised that, if Timoci Bavadra had the chance to govern Fiji for any length of time, he would be successful in creating a balanced, multi-racial society and that that would threaten certain vested interests in that community.

The unique thing about Timoci Bavadra is that, after he was deposed, despite what I think is the right that he had to be extremely bitter about those circumstances, he never allowed personal feelings of hatred against those who perpetrated the coup against him. He maintained his good humour, his dignity and, above all else, his humanity towards all, although many of us in Australia who were his friends expressed a lot more anger than he did. Again, I think that was a mark of his extraordinary political statesmanship.

I got to know Timoci Bavadra particularly well when a number of us were involved in forming the Association of South Pacific Progressive Parties in early 1988. The inaugural meeting was held in Melbourne and, at the end of that meeting, Timoci was elected as the first chairman. He was elected unanimously, without any debate or division at all, because all of those representatives of something like eight or nine different countries of the South Pacific realised that he clearly had the stature and the status automatically to become the first chairman. The idea of the Association was to provide a forum for people with views against colonialism in favour of progressive policies to support ordinary people in the various countries of the South Pacific. Timoci Bavadra was an excellent first chairman. Not only will he be greatly missed in his own country of Fiji, but as a member of the Association of South Pacific Progressive Parties, he will be very sorely missed. That is an indication that the South Pacific, as a region, will miss his leadership.

Until the time of his death and the funeral, it was said that support for him and his Party was declining. I thought that was dispelled by the scenes that we saw in this country at the time of his funeral. It is estimated that, at a minimum, 20,000 people attended his memorial service. It has been estimated that in Fiji as many as 60,000 people attended his funeral-in a country without a large population. The interesting thing about the funeral was that, although it was conducted just outside of Lautoka, on the western side of the main island of Fiji, people came from all over Fiji and from other countries. Again, a mark of that funeral service was the fact that it was multiracial. Not only were there large numbers of Fijians present but also large numbers of Indians. Throughout Fiji most shops and businesses closed as a mark of respect for Timoci Bavadra. It proved that if a free and fair election had been held at any time in Fiji after 1987, even under the 1970 constitution Timoci Bavadra would have been swept back into power.

I certainly offer my condolences to his widow, Aidi Kuini, and the family. I say to Aidi that I hope she will continue to play a role. I think it is most important that she accept the role of becoming, if not the new leader of the Fiji Labour Party, one of its leaders. In her own right she has been an outstanding leader. She will be able to provide the leadership for all of those people in Fiji-and they are not a minority, they are a majority-who want a decent, democratic system. That would, of course, be the final, ultimate tribute to this remarkable man, Timoci Bavadra, who died only two weeks ago. His death is a great tragedy. As I say, I pass on my condolences not only to his immediate family but to all of the people of Fiji whom he worked for and served for so long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly on the Queensland State election campaign and on some of the less seemly things that are occurring in that State. The leader of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) in Queensland, Mr Wayne Goss, in a slick campaign, is claiming that he is the only person who can deliver clean government in Queensland. It is interesting to note that the campaign is being waged with little or no reference to the Labor Party itself. The State Party does not wish to be associated in any way with the economic disasters imposed on every Queenslander and every Australian by fellow Labor comrades in Canberra: record interest rates, high mortgage rates, continuing high inflation, a frightening debt, all of which are reducing the standards of living of every Queenslander.

SPEECH.PARA: The other tack being taken by Labor in Queensland is to keep its candidates' past buried. It is about time that this cover-up by Mr Goss was exposed. The State member for Redcliffe is Mr Terry White. It should be recalled by everyone that it was Terry White, as leader of the Liberal Party who, because of his own perceptions of lack of accountability, in 1983 took his Party out of government. This is the only time that this has ever occurred in the history of Australia. He is a man who, by his actions, has shown himself to be someone of integrity and principle. Of course, it was claimed that that move was not politically smart. Maybe it was not; however, when the chips were down, Terry White opted for principles and integrity, something which everyone in Queensland is demanding today. What about the integrity and principles of the State Labor Party and Mr Goss? Mr White has a Labor candidate, Mr Ray Hollis, standing against him. Mr Hollis has already infringed the Electoral Act by distributing material in the Redcliffe electorate and claiming that it has come from the Liberals. He produced a pamphlet, which I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. Although I do not recall the precise words, Senator Parer said that a Labor candidate had infringed the Electoral Act. I infer that to be the Queensland Electoral Act. Surely that allegation is a matter for a court to decide, and the fact that it was made on the eve of an election is inappropriate in this chamber. The remark should be withdrawn.
—Senator Parer, could you explain exactly what you meant?
—I am attempting to explain that what has been done by Mr Hollis in distributing a pamphlet, which I will describe in some detail, clearly infringes the Electoral Act.
—In your view.
—I think in anybody's view.
—Well, in your view. Whether or not it is an offence is a matter for a court to decide.
—Perhaps I could amend that to say that in my view it infringes the Electoral Act?
—That would probably cover it.
—Mr Hollis distributed a leaflet. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a copy of the leaflet.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
A CALL TO RESTORE HONOUR AND
DIGNITY TO QUEENSLAND AND OUR
PARLIAMENT
Dear Fellow Queenslanders,
Greetings.
May I please raise the issue of the Queensland elections and the urgent need to restore the honour and dignity of our Parliament.
Our traditional institutions are in jeopardy. Public morale is at a low ebb. Corruption stalks the land.
The National Party is at fault through its contempt for the Parliamentary process and our long established Westminster system.
The power of Parliament as the people's house is in danger of disappearing altogether unless principled and farsighted folk take a strong stand at the forthcoming election.
It is plain that the Liberal Party cannot win enough seats to lead the coalition.
No matter what they say now, the Liberals will do a deal with the Nationals after the election. That's their usual politics. All they can promise is more of the same.
We are in such a mess! Only you, the electors, can save our state.
Wayne Goss and Labor are the only team who can be completely committed to a strong Parliament through Mr Fitzgerald's reforms.
It is time for those of us who usually vote Liberal to use Labor to stop the rot and restore the dignity of Parliament and the honour of our state.
We are fortunate that Wayne Goss, a sensible and sincere lawyer, is on hand to lead the Labor team and do the job for us.
Do your bit for the restoration of Queensland in the electorate of Redcliffe by voting-No. 1 Ray Hollis-the Goss Labor candidate.
In the hope that together we can save Queensland,
Yours sincerely,
Vernon Christie
The Hon. Sir Vernon Christie
A.S.A.A., A.F.A.I.M. F.C.I.S., F.C.I.M.
M.P. (Liberal) 1955-73, Speaker (Parliament of Victoria) 1967-73, Resident of Queensland 1914-22, 1929-30, 1973-89

TALK.START.PARA: —I will refer to only part of the leaflet. After greetings it goes on to discuss why people should vote Labor. At the bottom of the leaflet it is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: This letter is funded by Liberal supporters who want real change. Authorised by: Frank Bradley, PO Box 217, Carina.

This leaflet has been distributed by Mr Hollis. It has nothing whatsoever to do with the Liberal Party. Frank Bradley is a well-known ALP supporter who regularly hands out how to vote cards for the ALP. He is well-known in the area.

Mr Hollis was initially a member of the Liberal Movement in South Australia. In previous elections he stood as an Independent and based his campaign on what was called `a free voice'. In a newspaper article he is quoted as being disillusioned and stating that it was hard to cast a vote for any major party with confidence. Throughout the campaign he was highly critical of the rigid control of the Labor Party by what he called the party hierarchy or the junta. He subsequently stood as a Democrat for the House of Representatives and, again, in 1986 as a Democrat in the Senate. In the previous Redcliffe City Council election he stood for the Labor Party. Having been defeated on all occasions over a number of years, he now pops up as the Labor candidate for Redcliffe. According to complaints from constituents in the Redcliffe electorate, Mr Hollis's campaign is basically being run out of the office of Mr Gary Johns, the Federal member for Petrie, with members of Mr Johns's staff, and with the use of Government paid telephones, eliciting support for Mr Hollis.

I suppose that all honourable senators could say that to some extent assistance is given to candidates at various election levels. The reason I am drawing this to the attention of the chamber is to point out the utter hypocrisy of Mr Clean Goss. Here we have Mr Goss portraying a squeaky clean image, running around the State talking about abuse of ministerial expenses and corruption, and yet we have the classic case of the Labor Party using taxpayers' money to fund a State Labor candidate. Mr Goss should come clean and tell the people of Queensland the background of other Labor candidates as well as how many other Mr Hollises there are. The people of Queensland should realise that the State Labor Party and Mr Goss in his glass house are in no position to throw stones.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I want to bring to the attention of the Senate an injustice affecting my constituents in Western Australia, and one constituent in particular. I am very pleased to note that Senator Cook is here this evening because I think he will be interested in this matter. The general problem relates to one I have raised in the Senate on a previous occasion and that is the treatment of the frail aged in certain nursing homes in my State of Western Australia. I have in my possession a document which details complaints made some time ago about the treatment of patients in a nursing home in Western Australia. I do not seek leave to table this document because the complaints were made some time ago and I understand that the major aspects have been addressed and a new director of nursing has been appointed to that particular nursing home. I understand also that ownership of the nursing home has changed.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I want to indicate the seriousness of the allegations that were formerly made because they are relevant to what I have to say later. The complaint stated that residents were oversedated and that, as a result of oversedation, some suffered falls with resultant hip and other fractures; that incontinent patients were left for long periods without being cleaned up; that patients who called for bedpans were ignored; that there were no emergency bells in some daytime areas; and that patients in a lounge had no means of attracting attention when one of their number set her rug alight while smoking, which again was the result of being oversedated.

There were also claims of residents being denied access to religious comfort and advice, of staff shouting at patients to intimidate them, of censorship of patients' mail, of inadequate medical care, of inadequate food, of financial irregularities, of other indignities, and even of active euthanasia. Eventually a staff member who had a strong conscience and who had the welfare of the patients at heart complained to a priest about the treatment of the residents. My information is that the priest then went to the director of nursing and revealed to that person the identity of the complainant, who was then summarily dismissed from the employment of that nursing home.

The matter that I want to bring to the attention of the Senate and the Government this evening is that this particular staff member has since applied for a number of positions with other nursing homes and has been unable to obtain a job in the industry. On more than one occasion this person has gained an interview and on one occasion she was told at the conclusion of the interview that she was successful and an appointment would proceed. Subsequently, she was contacted and told quite openly that the appointment could not proceed because she had been blacklisted by the industry.

Honourable senators may recall that some weeks ago I made some general statements about Western Australian nursing homes. I am happy to relate that there was a strong and positive response to my speech from the State Department of Community Services and Health. Senior officers of the nursing homes section visited my office and gave a briefing on their responsibility for the maintenance of standards of care and on the investigation procedures, as well as resources which can be applied when complaints are received. An investigation of the complaints that were channelled through my office was then undertaken. I have not yet been informed of the results of the investigation but I have been assured by the Department that, when it is complete, I will be advised of the outcome.

I mention this again because on this occasion one of the elements which disturbed me greatly was that staff at the nursing home in question were threatened with dismissal if they should make any complaints to the authorities. They were also told that, if that did happen, they would never work again in the industry. They were clearly given to understand that the private nursing home industry in Perth operates a blacklist and that anyone who blows the whistle in relation to abuses or inadequate standards of care will find himself or herself blacklisted.

On 15 November this year the West Australian published a report on the subject of death threats received in the mail by a psychiatric nurse who earlier this year had given evidence to an inquiry, commissioned by the Western Australian Government, into patient abuse at the Graylands Psychiatric Hospital. This nurse has received a number of veiled death threats, rat poison, a rat trap and two get well cards in the mail. The nurse is reported to have stated that many of the nurses at Graylands who gave evidence to the inquiry have been threatened and intimidated. If there are abuses in nursing homes and other medical institutions, the first people who are likely to become aware of them are staff members, particularly the nursing staff. I am certain that the professional ethical standards of nurses would require them to speak out if they became aware of any abuses or inadequacies in either the medical care given to residents or related areas such as nutrition, occupational therapy, et cetera.

It is, in my view, an essential safeguard of industry that staff members should feel free to complain to relevant authorities, without any fear of intimidation, sanction or dismissal. Inadequacies and abuses can easily be hidden from visitors and, in any case, many elderly patients in these nursing homes do not receive visitors. Some aged people either are unable to complain or can easily be intimidated. If nursing and other staff are intimidated by threats of instant dismissal and of being banned from ever working in the industry again, the chances are that abuses will continue unchecked.

Therefore, tonight I call on the Government to bite the bullet and to take legislative action on the recommendations of the report Residents' Rights in Nursing Homes and Hostels, which was tabled in the Senate recently. I call on the Government to ensure that, as far as is possible, measures are implemented which impose strong sanctions on any group of employers who collude to black-ban or in other ways punish employees who draw attention to serious inadequacies and abuses in the care of aged and infirm residents in nursing homes.

I would be interested to hear from Senator Cook, the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, whether there is any action that I or the person whose experience I have described can now take to obtain redress and the right not to be discriminated against in respect of future employment in the industry. I fully appreciate that this is a ticklish problem. No-one will easily admit in public that a black list exists, or confirm that any particular name is on it. Nonetheless, I suspect that such a system does operate-these people have indicated that very strongly-and that it is effective in deterring the making of complaints which, although embarrassing and highly inconvenient to management, can have a significant role in protecting elderly and vulnerable people who are not in a position to assert their own rights when they are in these nursing homes.

Earlier today I referred to misrepresentation of the Australian Democrats' policy on immigration in the Italian language newspaper Il Globo on 13 November. The newspaper's comments on the Australian Democrats' policy are inaccurate and offensive. When the editor of the newspaper was asked where he had obtained his information he stated that he had obtained it from Senator Robert Ray, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, and a Special Broadcasting Service television program.

As spokesperson for the Australian Democrats on immigration, I make it clear that the Australian Democrats have a policy which is firmly based on a preference for compassionate and humanitarian standards with an emphasis on family reunion and Australia's obligation under the international refugee conventions to which we are a signatory. That is a different policy from the illusory `economic' and `factory fodder' model shared by the Liberal Party and the Australian Labor Party. I have made that clear every time I have spoken with the editor of Il Globo, Mr Nino Randazzo. The Australian Democrats have never considered setting a ceiling on immigration in any of these areas. I also make it plain that we believe that the Government should reconsider its policy of continuing to bring in migrants on a skills basis in order to paper over the deep cracks in Australia's neglected educational and training provisions, especially when we have a relatively high level of unemployment in this country. We also have extreme reservations about the business migration scheme as we feel that it has failed to provide any substantial human or economic value to Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Next week, Canberra will be hosting the largest arms bazaar ever held in the Southern Hemisphere called AIDEX 89. The organisers describe it as the largest and most sophisticated defence high technology exhibition ever held in the Southern Hemisphere but I prefer to call a spade a spade, and, despite mutterings about defensive equipment to justify its existence, I shall refer to it for what it really is, an arms bazaar. Perhaps the Canberra Times defence columnist, Frank Cranston, was more accurate when his column on the subject on 13 October referred to it as a war show.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1986 the organisers of this arms bazaar, the Sydney-based Australia Trade Fair Co., DESIKO, was instrumental in trying to set up a similar event known as PADEX. As this was also the International Year of Peace, the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, Bill Hayden, now elevated to higher office, realised that it was somewhat untimely and, after some huffing and puffing from the nearest that Australia gets to a military-industrial complex, PADEX was called off.

Since then the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has lost out in the long struggle with the Department of Defence and the merchants of death are riding high. They started out with the Cooksey report on the Review of Australia's Defence Co-operation Programs and Policy on Export of Defence Equipment in 1986, which was never tabled or discussed in this Parliament, and which recommended that Australia double its military exports over the next three to five years. Then, starting last year, they got all the rules changed so that more companies could get into the game. Red tape was reduced and, in effect, the controls on which countries we sell to were slackened.

I realise that there are those who would argue that Australia is small fry in the global arms trade-I believe that we rank in thirty-fourth place, according to the most recent set of figures-and that what we are really selling is purely defensive equipment, not the nasty killing stuff. The point I would make in this context is that, although this may be true, modern warfare is not possible without all this other hardware to back up the killing. I have already drawn an analogy with a situation where we might be saying that we are willing to supply the syringes but not the heroin to the addict, knowing that someone else will supply the heroin, because that is precisely our position.

There are over 200 companies coming to AIDEX 89. Their wares vary from combat clothing to military journals, and from lots of high technology electronic gear to batteries and instruments. Some companies would appear to be promoting the weapons that kill. Some of the names are very familiar to those who track global arms transfers. There is Creusot-Loire from France, British Aerospace, Ferranti International, General Electric (GE) Aerospace, General Dynamics, Honeywell, Marconi Defence Systems, Raytheon, Rockwell Electronics, Siemens, Thomson-CSF, Thorn-EMI Electronics, and Westinghouse Electronic Systems. Several of these come from the United State Defense Department's top hundred military contractors list. General Dynamics brings us Trident submarines and cruise missiles, including the ones which were deployed at Greenham Common in England and which are still deployed on ships such as the USS Bunker Hill and the USS Fife which were in Fremantle harbour last week bearing Tomahawk cruise missiles.

Honeywell was the target of international protests during the Vietnam War because of its products utilised there by the United States military up to the end of the war in 1975. Rockwell is the maker of the B1 bomber and in 1987 one of its vice-presidents told Jane's Defence Weekly that Australia was to be the springboard for its maritime penetration of the Asia-Pacific region. Both Westinghouse and General Electric make nuclear reactors. General Electric also manufactures components rather than complete weapons systems and there have been problems for the United States through the sale of GE aircraft engines as a result, particularly involving Israel.

Canada will also be represented at AIDEX through its High Commission. In March 1987, the Canadian publication Ploughshares Monitor noted that for about a decade it has been Canada's declared ambition to increase its sales of military commodities to the Third World. The problem has been that this market is highly competitive and, despite a decade of effort, Canada has made no dramatic breakthrough, although it is still trying. Given the parallels between Australia and Canada, there is an obvious lesson for Australia here but one which, so far, we have not noted. Indeed, Canada's direct sales to the Third World averaged about $Can150m during the 1980s, having slipped from the peak year of 1982 when they reached $Can250m. The figures are hard to calculate, however, because some Canadian military commodities are sold to the United States and become part of total US production.

European companies coming to AIDEX are better known for their involvement in corruption scandals. Ferranti is in deep water at the moment since it bought the US company, International Signal and Control, two years ago-the company that made the cluster bombs which rained down on the Lebanon during Israel's invasion of 1982. ISC is one of the Beltway Bandits which grew to enormous size and influence during the Reagan years. It was one of at least a dozen of these companies which were raided by the FBI and Justice Department last year in what was described as the largest investigation of white collar crime in the history of the United States. It has a reputation for secrecy, characteristic of many defence contractors, and Ferranti lost #215m-the equivalent of $450m-because ISC led it to believe that it had won major contracts in the developing world which simply never existed.

Currently the Pentagon bribery trials of Operation Ill Wind are in full swing, and Ferranti's erstwhile partner, James Guerin, of ISC, is being investigated for his association with a bankrupt defence contractor whose president has been jailed for conspiracy to defraud the US Defence Department of $US12m. One of ISC's subsidiaries has been named in Italy as selling arms to Iraq, possibly against US laws, with unauthorised credits from an Italian bank, possibly against Italian laws. FFV, a Swedish company taking part in AIDEX, was named in a report in February this year as having flouted an official arms embargo for years by selling antitank guns to blacklisted states, including Australia between 1966 and 1972, the years of the Vietnam debacle. The report was commissioned by the Swedish government after media allegations in 1988 of FFV arms smuggling when the company had illegally sold anti-tank guns and ammunition, much of it via Britain, worth a total of $US65m since the mid-1960's. The commission was headed by Justice Chancellor Hans Stark, the Government's top ombudsman who scrutinises the behaviour of civil servants and officials in the public sector. It is not surprising, then, that fifteen countries will be taking part in AIDEX 89, with France having the largest display area.
An interesting article in Time magazine on 3 July, entitled `Boom into Bust' made the comment:
Governments are chopping away at budget deficits; regional conflicts have been noticeably reduced, leading to reductions in export sales. East-West arms-control talks are gaining momentum.

A disheartened Israeli executive is quoted as saying with a sigh that, `The military market just isn't what it used to be'. Further on the article says that contractors are fighting to preserve their bottom lines in several ways. Many are hustling as much business as they can in the Third World and along the Pacific Rim. Not surprisingly, many of these companies are coming to Australia's arms bazaar to drum up business in the Third World and the Pacific Rim. We are very well placed to be that springboard. The United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency in its most recent report stated that world arms international transfers had now topped $US56 billion, and that the most promising market is east and south Asia where `the size and importance of the markets are increasing'.

South Asia, particularly India and Pakistan, is the fastest growing region for weapons sales. In 1977, east and south Asia represented only 6 per cent of the world's weapons import market. They now represent 23 per cent of the market. India, of course, has become the latest potential threat to Australia since it acquired a nuclear submarine from the Soviet Union, and it aims to deploy three aircraft carriers in the Indian Ocean. The worst case scenario warriors who have picked on India as the latest threat to Australia have been noticeably silent on an Australian company's partnership with a Dutch company to design India's latest naval base in Kerala. How hypocritical! Nor do they seem to have noticed that India this year took a decision to start exporting military equipment, doubtless for the same reason as Australia-to offset their imbalance of payments caused by buying expensive military equipment from overseas. Such are the contradictions of those who have a vested interest in maintaining the threat while trying to maximise arms sales to the region.

These developments also pose another problem for Australia, not only because so many other countries are moving in on the region we have targeted for military exports, but also because in September this year, the head of the World Bank, Barber B. Conable, made a statement to the Board of Governors in Washington, and Australia is on that Board. He said:

Developing countries on one side, and their arms suppliers and creditors on the other, must adapt to a world where budgets are tight. It is important to place military spending decisions on the same footing as other fiscal decisions, to examine possible trade-offs more systematically and to explore ways to bring military spending into better balance with development priorities. In evaluating their military expenditures, Governments should be realistic, but they also should remember the human consequences of these choices.

When I referred this speech to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) representing the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) on 31 October in connection with a question about HMAS Tobruk being used as a floating arms bazaar for visiting south and south west Asia on its way back from Gallipoli next year, all I got was a meaningless re-statement of government policy on military exports. It was an evasive answer which totally avoided my concern about how we can reconcile this military export drive into Asia with what the head of the World Bank was telling us in September in Washington. It is not surprising, then, that companies like Rockwell International, faced with a downturn at home, are moving into this part of the world.

The article in Time magazine pointed out that countries like the United States, Canada, France, and the United Kingdom are pegging back their defence budgets, and defence manufacturers are having to lay off their workers. West German and Scandinavian firms have kept their order books filled with overseas transactions, and countries like Britain are marketing more aggressively abroad. Many of these countries and companies, like Rockwell International, are coming to AIDEX 89 precisely because they see south and east Asia as the best growth area for their products. For them, Australia is a suitable base. As another Rockwell vice-president put it:

We are transferring technology from the USA into Australia, bolstering its technology and capability. In turn, Rockwell is using Ship Subsystems Australia as its means of obtaining new maritime revenue for its venture into the Asia/Pacific region.

The philosophy is to establish a legal entity in Australia to execute the submarine project primarily and, secondarily, to pursue the Australian surface combatant project which has now started. The third priority is to move out from Australia to the Pacific with that capability.

Later he added that he expects other US defence contractors to mimic Rockwell's actions while European firms seek business in the USA. The list of companies taking part in AIDEX 89 shows that he is obviously correct, but it is not only US companies which are coming; the Europeans are as well. As an article in Le Monde put it last year, `Peace threatens sales in the arms bazaar'.

The winding down of the Gulf War has been quite a blow to the 60 or so countries which had been selling weapons to Iran and Iraq while more than a million people died. One of the visitors to AIDEX 89 will be Monsieur Serge Dassault, the President Director-General of Avions Marcel Dassault, who will be leading a team of fifteen of his company's top executives to Canberra. This is the company which sold arms to Iraq with between F40 billion and F60 billion during the period of the Gulf War. This is the company which sold dozens of Mirage F1 jet fighters to Iraq, some of which, according to the January 1989 edition of the Geographic Magazine, may have been used to drop the deadly poison-gas bombs on Kurdish civilians, an act which, of course, we all deplored.

The latest news is that, following a successful campaign initiated by the Campaign Against the Arms Trade, Britain has decided not to sell aircraft to Iraq and so France through this same company, Dassault, is hoping to get the latest contract. Of course, it is not only European and American companies which will be taking part in AIDEX. Over the last few years, a number of Third World countries have entered the market for precisely the same reason as Australia, to try to offset their balance of payments problems caused by importing expensive hi-tech military equipment from Europe and North America. According to the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute, the leading Third World major-weapon producing countries include Israel, India, Brazil, Taiwan, Argentina, South Africa, North and South Korea, Egypt and the ASEAN countries. At least two of the top three Third World arms producers will be taking part in AIDEX, Brazil and South Korea, while most of the others will be excluded because of their international status or their politics. AIDEX is supposed to be only for friendly nations according to the publicity brochures. In the last few years, Brazil has become a major supplier of weapons to the Middle East. Iraq and Saudi Arabia were its main customers. So was Libya with deals worth more than $US1 billion. This was made possible because the Brazilian Government views arms sales as strictly business ventures. Brazilian companies are rarely held back by political considerations. Brazil's arms exports have skyrocketed, from zero in 1974 to $US1.3 billion in 1984. It sold to both sides in the Gulf War and the state-run Brazilian War Materiel Company, IMBEL, exports over 50 types of military goods to over 70 countries in Latin America, Africa, Asia and the United States.

South Korea has been developing a major arms industry for over a decade, encouraged through special licensing deals to manufacture US weaponry that America offered when it withdrew some of its troops from Asia. In 1971, the United States licensed South Korea to produce M16 rifles and since then, other licenses have been issued to make ammunition for the US designed M14 rifle as well as F5 fighter jets. It did not get permission to produce F16s although it sought such a license. Today South Korea specialises in tanks, armoured personnel carriers, munitions, aircraft and patrol boats. Larger arsenals of US arms, left behind at the close of the Korean War, were fitted with indigenously produced components built especially for Third World clients. In 1986, two US analysts from the Centre for Strategic and International Studies identified South Korea as the fourth largest exporter of arms to the Third World. South Korea has sold primary rifles, pistols, grenade launchers, ammunition mortars and explosives to nations such as Guatemala, Ecuador, Malaysia, Burma, Bangladesh, South Yemen, Cameroon and Indonesia. Its ultimate goal is a $2 billion per annum arms business. In passing, it is also worth noting the comment of a public relations consultant for a British defence manufacturer which has done business with South Korea. The consultant stated:
It's an impossible situation for us-trying to explain to the Koreans about our share price. They are just not interested in publicising basic information about contract values and items being sold.

This is the secrecy that characterises the world of arms bazaars which Australia is now seeking to embrace. It is worth noting too that Australia, along with other countries, has been worried about the increasing number of countries making missiles and exporting them. So it is important to note that in 1978 South Korea tested a modified copy of the United States made Nike Hercules surface-to-air missile and has since displayed it at several international arms bazaars. On two occasions South Korea's expansion into high technology areas has run afoul of the US export administration Act, once after the export of the US licensed PSMM-5 patrol boats to Indonesia in 1979-80 and then after a request to sell howitzers, mortars and ammunition to Jordan in 1982.

The question remains as to how long the United States can prevent countries like South Korea from selling weapons to unstable Third World countries. The answer may depend on the future proliferation of defence technology throughout the world. This will make it harder for the United States to identify its own components in foreign military equipment. A number of the ASEAN countries will be represented as well, though not necessarily as displayers. After all, they are the principal market for the wares available. Singapore and Indonesia are the only members of ASEAN which have promoted a military export industry and Singapore has also been responsible for channelling military hardware from countries like Israel through to a third party like Fiji.

Singapore and Thailand have also hosted highly sophisticated regional arms bazaars over the past few years. Since 1985 Indonesia has been boosting its weapons industry and streamlining defence production to lessen dependence on foreign arms and spare parts. Indonesia already produces or assembles, mostly under licence, fighter and trainer aircraft, missiles, torpedoes, helicopters, naval equipment and a range of spare parts. They come mostly from the State-owned Nurtanio aircraft plant at Bandung, the naval shipyard at Surabaya and the army industrial plant-all state corporations.

In the past, Indonesia has imported submarines from West Germany, patrol boats from Australia and South Korea, Exocet missiles from France, corvettes from the Netherlands, refitted frigates from Britain; more recently Sweden has decided that it can sell military equipment to Indonesia despite the ongoing war in East Timor and West Papua. I have argued principally against Australia's promotion of military exports on moral grounds but there are economic grounds for opposing Australia's moves in this direction. The market is shrinking but as I have indicated the competition is increasing. Australia cannot compete in areas of highly sophisticated equipment like aircraft nor can it compete with the cheaper labour markets in Asia-countries like India, Pakistan, South and North Korea and China.

One argument has been that this country should find openings where we can compete, areas such as the export of minesweepers to countries in the Persian Gulf. Fortunately, of course, the war ceased last year so, unfortunately for the marketeers, that market disappeared. One problem is that there are no prospects for long-term major conflict in this part of the world-again from the point of view of the arms sales merchants. Apart from Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia virtually all countries in the region are loosely or closely aligned with the West or are trying to be non-aligned and self-sufficient like China. There are longstanding counter-insurgency wars like those in the Philippines, Sri Lanka and Burma, however.

Then there are military forces whose main role is for internal repression, from Pakistan and Burma-or Myanmar as it is now called-to China and South Korea, as well as the national security states in between. It is my chief fear that the military hardware being promoted at AIDEX is either to keep the military happy in national security states like Malaysia and Thailand or for internal repression in other countries which proclaim to be democracies like the Philippines.

As we have seen in the last few years, countries such as Sweden and West Germany have been involved in arms deals reeking of corruption. As the competition increases, short cuts are taken. Add to this the transfer of arms through dummy companies, third and fourth country middlemen, the use of faked end-user certificates, ships which disappear from the seas only to reappear halfway around the world with new names painted on their bows and new flags flying from their masts, and weapons flood into tragic countries like the Lebanon, the Gulf states, Myanmar, Cambodia and Sri Lanka, though everyone publicly deplores the bloodshed. Only this year, we learned that South Africa is exporting to 32 countries despite the United Nations arms embargo. Everyone sold to friend and foe during the Gulf War, and dozens of countries to both sides.

Far larger than this blatantly illegal black market for weapons is the grey trade of selling through respectable and democratic countries to questionable regimes and terrorist movements around the globe. For example, Britain, which will be taking part in AIDEX, frowns on arms sales to Libya. However, it will readily issue one of its own companies an export licence to sell to, say, Greece which is a friendly country, a fellow North Atlantic Treaty Organisation ally. A company in Athens would then have little trouble persuading the Greek government to issue a licence to export to Syria. From Syria the weapons could be dispatched to Libya, the Palestine Liberation Organisation or almost anyone in the Middle East.

One of the military export companies now established in Canberra is Plessey Australia Pty Ltd which sold radar equipment to Iran in 1987 on the basis that it was a defensive system intended for use along the Soviet-Iranian border. One Ministry of Defence official commented that he knew the radar systems would not be used in the Gulf War because, `We have diplomats who can go and check these things out'. In reality, Britain's diplomatic presence in Tehran was limited to a section of the Swedish Embassy. The Iranian Government has often refused foreign diplomats permission to travel in sensitive areas of the country, especially along the Soviet and Iraqi frontiers. Needless to say, Britain will be well represented at AIDEX, and so will Plessey.

France has often been criticised for allowing French companies to sell arms to warring Iraq, Argentina and Chile, under military rule, and a whole range of despotic Third World regimes such as the Central African Republic under the Emperor Jean Bokassa and Papa Doc's Haiti. France, as I have already noted, will have the largest display area at AIDEX. This is the world that we are walking into.

It is also where HMAS Tobruk proposes to go next year in its capacity as a floating arms bazaar after delivering the old Diggers to Gallipoli. Yet when I asked a question about where it was going, all I received was a non-answer worthy of the ex-National Party Premier of Queensland in his heyday. I would suggest that the main reason we are doing this is to offset our own imbalance of payments, which at the military level is caused by the import of capital equipment costing well over $1 billion a year through the mid-1980s. I would therefore suggest that at the practical level Australia start by reducing its own military expenditure.

On Monday we read that the United States is reducing its defence expenditure by $10 billion. The Soviet Union has drastically reduced its inflated military budget by 14.2 per cent and factories that produced tanks are now producing many other socially useful products. Other countries have reduced or held back on the expansion of their military expenditure with a few tragic exceptions. The 1980s has been one of the bloodiest decades of history but as it draws to a close many of the longstanding conflicts seem also to be drawing to a close which is a very hopeful sign.

The outstanding question remains: Why is Australia increasing its defence expenditure as a proportion of the overall budget from 8.8 per cent in 1979 to 9.6 per cent this year? We have no perceived enemies. As the 1981 Katter report, Threats to Australia's Security; Their Nature and Probability observed, only one country has the ability to mount a successful invasion of Australia, and that is the United States which has no motive to do so. Some of us might cynically observe that it has no need to anyway as the cultural invasion took place long ago. Any other country would take five to ten years to develop that capability.

It is difficult to envisage why any country should invade or harass Australia. It is much cheaper to trade with than to invade Australia. The savage irony is that Australia could well become a base for arming the region-a self-fulfilling prophecy. There are no submarines to threaten Australian shipping in this part of the world, apart from those in Japan, China, Indonesia and India, yet we are contemplating the sale of submarines to Thailand, India and Canada and possibly other countries.

In terms of resolving potential regional conflicts, non-military solutions represent the best way forward. Working to promote common security, encouraging the creation of regional forums to promote cooperation and understanding, and developing mechanisms for negotiations, arbitration and non-violent conflict resolution would be more profitable than arming Australia and the region. That is the direction that Australia should take. By putting the emphasis on non-offensive defence for Australia and common security for the region, Australia need not import expensive military equipment from abroad. In turn, we do not need to seek a doubling of our military exports to offset these costs, nor the holding of exhibitions like AIDEX '89 to bring together the merchants of death from around the world. Our research can be directed into socially useful forms of production along with our exports.

I was cheered to read recently in Time magazine that Soviet defence plants are now cranking up their output of television sets, refrigerators, sausage machines, vacuum cleaners, pasta equipment and washing machines. This is a real peace conversion, but I would rather that Australian research and Australian industry never had to get into developing military hardware in the first place, apart from a modest production of items for our own coastal defence, and not for export.

One other area concerns me and that is the creation of a lobby group in Australia who have a vested interest in maintaining a strong military force in Australia. We have read recently of the problems that the United States and the Soviet Union are facing in beginning to run down rather than expand their military programs. There are people in the military, in intelligence and in industry who do not welcome the end of the Cold War. They thrive on secrecy and paranoia and threats. As an article in the Canberra Times observed on 2 October this year:
The arms world is a dirty business although run, on the face of it, by gentlemen and retired officers.

I do not want to see the creation of such a lobby in Australia. In the last decade, arms bazaars have been cancelled in Anaheim and San Mateo in the United States, and in Rotterdam and Wiesbaden in West Europe, as a result of the protests from churches and peace groups. After two years of growing protests, the organisers of the annual Military Electronics Expo announced in 1980 that they would hold no further arms fairs anywhere in the USA. It seems that the tendency is now to hold such events in Asia and Australia, and it is sad that having cancelled PADEX in 1986, the Government has taken a step backwards by allowing and encouraging AIDEX 89. I sincerely hope that this will be the last such arms bazaar ever held in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to comment briefly on some of the speeches made by honourable senators in this adjournment debate. Senator Schacht started the debate by saying that he was going to pay tribute to a major statesperson who had died. When he said that, I thought that he was referring to the twenty-sixth anniversary of the assassination in Dallas this day at 2.30 p.m., United States time, of John F. Kennedy. But he did not. He paid tribute to a great South Pacific statesman, Dr Timoci Bavadra. I join Senator Schacht in his expression of goodwill and recognition of the achievement of Dr Timoci Bavadra in the all too short time that he was the Prime Minister of his country.
—He does not even know which country.

—Fiji. Senator Parer, the second speaker in the debate, took the occasion to make an attack upon what he called the integrity of the Goss led Labor Party in Queensland. It is Senator Parer's right and privilege in the adjournment debate to do this, but it raises a number of questions. The first question it raises is a question of credibility. In the context of post-Fitzgerald-report-modern Queensland, is an attack upon the alleged lack of integrity of a Labor opposition credible from a Liberal senator when he has not one single word to say about the proven level of corruption in Queensland under the existing National Party Administration? Of course, there is no credibility in that. Senator Parer's lack of objectivity and of even-handedness paints him as someone who is defending the status quo and, by extension it could be argued, the corruption that he never referred to within Queensland. I reject all his remarks about a lack of integrity on the part of the Goss led Labor Party. To allege that problems in Queensland are associated with a leader of a party who is recognised universally for his integrity is a major act by Senator Parer that stretches credibility beyond measure.

SPEECH.PARA: The second question it raises is the question of ethics. Parliament has the right of privilege for the purpose that it should be free to discuss any matter. That is a prerequisite for open democracy. But there are times in which the limits of that privilege are extended. Senator Parer said today that the law had been broken in Queensland. True, he amended that by adding `in my opinion'. He also said that constituents alleged that Mr Hollis's campaign is being run out of Garry Johns's office. Then he asserted that taxpayers' money is being spent on trying to elect the Labor Party in Queensland. Those are allegations, it is true. The fact that not one shred of evidence was ever presented suggests that those allegations do not have too much to back them. To simply make an allegation and let it hang in a pre-election context is a reflection of bad faith on Senator Parer's part.

The third question it raises is the question of Senator Parer's judgment. He has had incorporated in Hansard a letter in order that he might make an attack upon Mr Frank Bradley, who it appears is a member of the Labor Party. It is interesting to read the letter that is exhibit A in Senator Parer's attack upon the integrity of the Labor Party. The letter is headed, `A Call To Restore Honour And Dignity To Queensland And Our Parliament'. It reads:
May I please raise the issue of the Queensland elections and the urgent need to restore the honour and dignity of our Parliament.
Our traditional institutions are in jeopardy. Public morale is at a low ebb. Corruption stalks the land.
The National Party is at fault through its contempt for the Parliamentary process and our long established Westminster system.
The power of Parliament as the people's house is in danger of disappearing altogether unless principled and farsighted folk take a strong stand at the forthcoming election.
It is plain that the Liberal Party cannot win enough seats to lead the coalition.
No matter what they say now, the Liberals will do a deal with the Nationals after the election. That's their usual politics. All they can promise is more of the same.
We are in such a mess! Only you, the electors, can save our State.
Wayne Goss and Labor are the only team who can be completely committed to a strong Parliament through Mr Fitzgerald's reforms.
It is time for those of us who usually vote Liberal to use Labor to stop the rot and restore the dignity of Parliament and the honour of our State.
We are fortunate that Wayne Goss, a sensible and sincere lawyer, is on hand to lead the Labor team and do the job for us.
Do your bit for the restoration of Queensland in the electorate of Redcliffe by voting-NO. 1 RAY HOLLIS-the Goss Labor candidate.
In the hope that together we can save Queensland,
Yours sincerely,
The Hon. Sir Vernon Christie
A.S.A.A., A.F.A.I.M., F.C.I.S., F.C.I.M.
M.P. (Liberal) 1955-73, Speaker (Parliament of Victoria) 1967-73, Resident of Queensland 1914-22, 1929-30, 1973-89

The letters after Sir Vernon's name indicate that he has served and is qualified in a range of occupations. Exhibit A from Senator Parer is nothing less than a letter from a confirmed Liberal and a past serving parliamentarian who rose to the distinction of being the Speaker of the Parliament in Victoria asking electors in Queensland to vote for the Labor Party. This is Senator Parer's weapon to allege corruption against the Goss Labor team. Thank you, Senator Parer.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 8.30 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 28 September 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In proposing a training levy or tax for all companies with a payroll exceeding $200,000, does the Minister also intend to provide a tax incentive to those companies which spend in excess of the required percentage of payroll on approved training schemes.

(2) Can the Minister also confirm that 40 per cent of submissions regarding industry training in Australia were opposed to government-initiated funding of industry training and that only 25 per cent supported the proposed training levy.

(3) Can the Minister also confirm that it is the Government's intention to collect a training levy or tax of 1 per cent of companies' payroll from 1 July 1990 and that the levy will rise to 1.5 per cent in 1991-92 and that at this stage no method of collection of the levy nor its distribution amongst training bodies has been verified.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The Training Guarantee is intended to provide a spur to those enterprises where training performance is inadequate. It is a minimum requirement and well below what best practice firms are already doing. Enterprises which have a strong commitment to training will not be penalised. However, the Government does not intend to provide incentives for training through the tax system.

(2) 40 per cent of submissions were opposed to Government-initiated funding, while 35 per cent of submissions supported a Training Guarantee to some extent. More importantly, however, about 60 per cent of submissions supported some form of collective action to improve the training effort. While peak employer bodies and individual employers were opposed to any form of government imposed levy no one has convincingly demonstrated how to maintain the momentum of training reform without some form of compulsory funding arrangement.

The Government's intention is to introduce a Training Guarantee set at 1 per cent of payroll with effect from 1990-91 rising to 1.5 per cent after two years. The emphasis is on requiring all enterprises with an annual payroll above a certain threshold, likely to be $200 000, to spend a minimum amount on approved training activities, with any shortfall between required and actual expenditures being collected as Government revenue to fund additional training activities. The Government has not taken a decision on collection or disbursement mechanisms for the Training Guarantee because it is seeking a co-operative implementation approach with the States. The Commonwealth will also be holding discussions with peak employer groups and the ACTU on implementation issues.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 October:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When will the review of psychology services in the defence forces, foreshadowed in the Auditor-General's Audit Report No. 11, 1989-90, into the Department of Defence's recruiting practices be carried out.
(2) Who will carry out the review, and what form will it take.
(3) When can the results be expected, and is it planned to make these public.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The terms of reference for the review and selection of a suitable consultant are presently being progressed. I expect the review will commence early in the new year.

(2) A short list of persons suitably qualified to conduct the review has been drawn up. They will be invited to tender for the work. The review will involve a professional scrutiny of the psychology services provided to the Defence Force recruiting function and an analysis of submissions and advice from the psychology directorates of the three Services and from interested elements of the three Services and HQ ADF.

(3) I expect the review should be completed by around the end of April 1990. The results of the review will be available to interested members of the public except in respect of any classified material.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 6 November 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which countries provide payment of social security benefits to Australian citizens resident in those countries.
(a) what types of social security benefits are payable; and
(b) does an Australian citizen need a period of residence before becoming eligible for payment, and if so, what period.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Many countries provide social security benefits to residents (including Australian citizens) on the basis of their affiliation with the particular country's social security scheme. Entitlement in most cases, particularly in Europe and the Americas, would depend on contributions made to the national social security scheme.

Contribution-based social security schemes which provide benefits on the basis of contributions made during periods of employment usually also credit contributions for deemed periods (such as army service, child raising etc). Deemed periods may not be available to non-citizens.

On available information, the only country which denies entitlement on the basis of citizenship is Lebanon which will not provide social security coverage to non-Lebanese citizens unless the non-citizen's country provides reciprocity. South Africa has restrictions on payment of age pension-only available to non-citizens after 5 years residence.

Many contribution-based schemes have underlying ``safety-net'' welfare schemes. These schemes provide income-tested benefits to residents, regardless of citizenship. Spain, Malta, Canada and Italy are some examples.

(2) Most social security schemes provide coverage for the main contingencies of old age, invalidity and death. Many have cash benefits or payments in kind for family allowance, unemployment and temporary incapacity for work while others also provide coverage for work-related accident or illness through national social security schemes or private insurance; and

(b) Contribution-based schemes require minimum periods of contributions from earnings for benefit eligibility. Specified contributions during nominated periods immediately before the contingency are usually also necessary-particularly for the short-term benefits.
Welfare schemes normally award income-tested benefits to legal residents without prior periods of residence.
